            <tei-docTitle data-origname="docTitle">


               <tei-titlePart type="main" data-origname="titlePart" data-origatts="type">FRANKENSTEIN;<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> OR,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> THE MODERN <tei-ref target="prometheus_" corresp="prometheus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">PROMETHEUS.</tei-ref><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/></tei-titlePart>


               <tei-note xml:id="prometheus" id="prometheus" target="prometheus_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-graphic url="https://visualpursuits.files.wordpress.com/2014/06/1959-5621-mf1-prometheus.jpeg" width="100%" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="width url" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="http://classics.oxfordre.com/abstract/10.1093/acrefore/9780199381135.001.0001/acrefore-9780199381135-e-5363?rskey=6Zn6ju" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Prometheus</tei-ref> (1750 illustration of Prometheus Attacked by an Eagle by
                     René-Michel Slodtz pictured from the Melbourne Museum) is a Greek trickster
                     Titan known as "Forethought". In one myth, Prometheus created man, but in the
                     more common myth, Prometheus protected man by tricking Zeus out of a prize
                     sacrifice of meat and giving it to humans. Zeus then prevented humans from
                     accessing fire, which Prometheus gave to humans by hiding it inside a
                     fennel-stalk. This slight against Zeus caused Zeus the Olympian to punish
                     Prometheus dearly; in one instance he is tied to a rock and his liver is
                     continually eaten and replenished every day. </tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"> While <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> was being published, Percy Shelley,
                     Mary Shelley’s husband, wrote a closet drama about the myth entitled <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Prometheus Unbound</tei-hi> which can be read <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/45136/prometheus-unbound" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">at
                        Poetry Foundation</tei-ref>. In Shelley’s poem Zeus falls from power, allowing
                     Prometheus to escape his fetters. This poem is a response to <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Prometheus-Bound-play-by-Aeschylus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Aeschylus’ drama <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Prometheus Bound</tei-hi></tei-ref>, one of the
                     first classical tragedies that pits Zeus’ power against Prometheus’ ego. <tei-ref target="http://classics.mit.edu/Aeschylus/prometheus.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">A full-text
                        version of the Aeschelus play is available at the Internet Classics
                        Archive</tei-ref>. Victor Frankenstein--the "modern Prometheus"--is more akin to
                     the Prometheus of Aeschylus’ drama, a creator who finds his creation
                     "wretched." Frankenstein is very different from the Hesiodic understanding of
                     Prometheus, which,<tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=pmJGK5yTLr8C" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                        as Norman Austin notes in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Meaning and Being in
                        Myth</tei-hi></tei-ref>, saw him as a benefactor and caretaker, not a creator who
                     abandoned his creation (77).</tei-p>
               </tei-note>


            </tei-docTitle>

            <tei-titlePart type="desc" data-origname="titlePart" data-origatts="type">IN THREE VOLUMES<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/></tei-titlePart>


            <tei-milestone unit="part" rend="line" data-origname="milestone" data-origatts="rend unit" data-empty=""/>


            <tei-epigraph data-origname="epigraph">


               <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
                  <tei-ref target="epigraph_" corresp="epigraph" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"><tei-lg data-origname="lg">


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">Did I request thee, Maker, from my clay</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">To mould me man? Did I solicit thee</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">From darkness to promote me?</tei-l>


                     </tei-lg>
                  </tei-ref>
                  <tei-note xml:id="epigraph" id="epigraph" target="epigraph_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">This epigraph quotes <tei-ref target="http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/26?msg=welcome_stranger" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                           <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi></tei-ref> (X.743-745), where Adam
                        laments his expulsion from Eden. Milton’s epic poem is one of many texts
                        that had a profound effect on Mary Shelley. Its influence can be seen
                        throughout the novel, particularly in relation to the creature’s
                        self-education, and it is one of the books that he finds and reads while he
                        is living near the De Lacey’s cottage (Volume II, Chapter 7). When the
                        creature confronts Victor Frankenstein, his "Maker," he compares himself to
                        Adam (Volume II, Chapter 2). For more information about the influence of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi> in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>,
                        see <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/2933709" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">John Lamb’s "Mary
                           Shelley's Frankenstein and Milton's Monstrous Myth"</tei-ref> and <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/john-milton-paradise-lost" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the
                           overview of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi>in the "Romantics and
                           Victorians" exhibit at the British Library </tei-ref>. </tei-p>
                     <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/></tei-note>
                  <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
                     <tei-ref target="paradise_lost_" corresp="paradise_lost" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">PARADISE LOST.</tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="paradise_lost" id="paradise_lost" target="paradise_lost_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-p data-origname="p">
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/john-milton" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">John
                              Milton</tei-ref> (1608-1674) was an English poet most notably known for
                              <tei-ref target="https://www.dartmouth.edu/~milton/reading_room/pl/intro/text.shtml" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                              <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi></tei-ref>, a twelve-volume epic poem
                           in blank verse about the fall of man. Milton’s poem is an important
                           intertext--even, as <tei-ref target="http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20170419-why-paradise-lost-is-one-of-the-worlds-most-important-poems" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"> BBC Britain’s Benjamin Ramm notes</tei-ref>, the inspiration, for
                           Shelley. The Romantics placed importance in feeling and nature, and
                           Milton epitomized that throughout his poem, showing the the evolution of
                           human consciousness and the building up of the human spirit. The
                           independence and individuality he gives to Satan creates sympathy for a
                           hated stock character, redeeming him in the reader’s eyes. This in turn
                           projects the idea of redemption of the spirit through internal means,
                           removing the need for deliverance through an omnipotent being. See more
                           in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?vid=9780199697885" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The
                                 Oxford Handbook of Milton</tei-ref></tei-hi> by Nicholas McDowell. </tei-p>
                        <tei-p data-origname="p"> At the beginning of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi>, Milton states
                           that the purpose of the poem is to "justifie the wayes of God to men"
                           (I.26). This idea speaks to Shelley’s themes of free will and theodicy.
                           The story of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi> is felt acutely by
                           Victor Frankenstein and his Creature, and many allusions to it appear
                           throughout the text. An interesting juxtaposition of religious thought to
                           her scientific filled novel, Mary Shelley combines the contemporary
                           understanding of science with an obvious allusion to the religious folly
                           and fall of man. For more information about the influence of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi> in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, see Burton Pollin’s <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/17699" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Philosophical and Literary
                              Sources of Frankenstein</tei-ref>, <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/2933709" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">John Lamb’s "Mary
                              Shelley's Frankenstein and Milton's Monstrous Myth"</tei-ref>, and <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/john-milton-paradise-lost" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the overview of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi>in the "Romantics
                              and Victorians" exhibit at the British Library</tei-ref>. </tei-p>
                     </tei-note>
                  </tei-bibl>
               </tei-quote>


            </tei-epigraph>

            <tei-docImprint data-origname="docImprint">
               <tei-pubPlace data-origname="pubPlace"><tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName></tei-pubPlace>:<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
               PRINTED FOR <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
               <tei-publisher rend="caps" data-origname="publisher" data-origatts="rend">
                  <tei-ref target="publisher_" corresp="publisher" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">LACKINGTON, HUGHES, HARDING, MAVOR,
                     & JONES</tei-ref>
              </tei-publisher>
               <tei-note xml:id="publisher" id="publisher" target="publisher_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-graphic url="https://www.bl.uk/britishlibrary/~/media/bl/global/dl%20romantics%20and%20victorians/collection-items-manual/consumerism-books-lackington-allen-074521.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein; or, the Modern Prometheus</tei-hi>, was published
                     by the Lackington firm, founded by James Lackington in 1774. Advertised as "The
                     Cheapest Bookseller in the World," Lackington's business--which both sold and
                     lent books as well as published them--capitalized on a new, middle-class
                     reading public. In 1791, the bookseller moved from Chiswell Street to a large
                     purpose-built store in Finsbury Square, dubbed "The Temple of the Muses"--above
                     the entrance, an inscription advertised "The Cheapest Books in the World."
                     Lackington's 1799-1800 catalog, according to the <tei-ref target="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lackington,_George_(DNB00)" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Dictionary of National Biography</tei-ref>, boasted nearly 300,000 volumes
                     available for sale. In 1789, the founder's cousin, George Lackington, took over
                     operations, and it was here that Shelley's book was sold. <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=1y3bS3Z0uY0C" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">William St. Clair,
                        in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Reading Nation in the Romantic Period</tei-hi>,
                        describes the publication of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi></tei-ref>.
                     Percy Bysshe Shelley, Shelley's husband and noted Romantic poet, arranged the
                     initial printing with Lackington & Co., which was known to specialize in
                     books about magic and the supernatural. Turned down by other publishers, likely
                     for reasons of self-censorship, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> found a
                     home at Lackington's. The first run--at 500 copies--was relatively small for
                     such a well-known shop, but the book was popular and sold well; St. Clair notes
                     that the first edition of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> "made more money
                     than all [Percy] Shelley's works were to fetch in his lifetime" (360). The book
                     was published anonymously, though because the publishing contract was
                     negotiated by Percy Shelley, <tei-ref target="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/apr/09/gender.books" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">early
                        reviewers assumed he had authored it, as Germaine Greer suggests</tei-ref>. The
                     image above, from the British Library, shows an 1809 engraving by Rudolph
                     Ackermann depicting the interior of "Messrs. Lackington Allen & Co: Temple
                     of the Muses, Finsbury Square." </tei-p>
               </tei-note>, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
               <tei-pubPlace data-origname="pubPlace">
                  <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7449907" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">FINSBURY SQUARE</tei-placeName></tei-pubPlace>. <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
               <tei-milestone unit="part" rend="line" data-origname="milestone" data-origatts="rend unit" data-empty=""/>
               <tei-docDate data-origname="docDate">
                  <tei-ref target="date_" corresp="date" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">1818.</tei-ref>
               </tei-docDate>
               <tei-note xml:id="date" id="date" target="date_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"> The first edition of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> was written while
                     Mary Shelley was in the prime of her life, but it was published in January of
                     1818, shortly after she buried her first child. The second edition, published
                     in 1831, came after the loss of her husband, most of her children, and her
                     family. There are many differences between the two texts, which <tei-ref target="http://juxtacommons.org/shares/Nme50n" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">can be viewed</tei-ref> in Dana
                     Wheeles’ public Juxta collation. One of the main structural differences between
                     the texts is the loss of the three volumes found in the 1818 edition. In the
                     1831 edition, after the first four letters, the chapters are numbered 1-24,
                     which not only removes the multiple volumes but also obscures the separated
                     narratives of Victor, the Creature, and Walton. Another noticeable difference
                     comes from the removal of the epigraph from Milton’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise
                        Lost</tei-hi>, which, in the beginning of the 1818 edition, announces the key
                     theme of the novel. Its removal from the 1831 edition obscures the importance
                     of the allusions to Milton’s work throughout the novel. In the <tei-ref target="https://www.rc.umd.edu/editions/frankenstein/1831v1/intro" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">newly-added forward to the 1831 edition</tei-ref>, Mary Shelley wrote, somewhat
                     disingenuously, "I have changed no portion of the story, nor introduced any new
                     ideas or circumstances." Shelley in fact makes many changes that drastically
                     change the interpretation and meaning of the text. </tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">First, many of the scientific ideas written about in the 1818 edition are
                     removed, detaching the novel from an intellectual context and further pressing
                     it into the fantastical. Shelley also removes many of Elizabeth’s more
                     independent thoughts about women’s rights as well as her indictment of the
                     justice system in regards to Justine. Finally, one of the largest differences
                     between the editions is Victor Frankenstein’s character. Whereas in the 1818
                     edition, Victor’s own hubris is to blame for the outcome of the Creature, in
                     the 1831 edition, Victor is at the mercy of fate or chance.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">To explore more about the differences between the editions, see Jill Lepore’s
                     article in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The New Yorker</tei-hi>, <tei-ref target="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/02/12/the-strange-and-twisted-life-of-frankenstein" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"The Strange and Twisted Life of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>"</tei-ref>, Jacqueline Foertsch’s <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1350098" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Right, the Wrong, and the
                        Ugly: Teaching Shelley's Several "Frankensteins"</tei-ref>, or James O’Rourke’s
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/25601400" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"The 1831 Introduction
                        and Revisions to <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>: Mary Shelley Dictates
                        Her Legacy</tei-ref>. To explore visual differences between the texts, see the
                        <tei-ref target="http://shelleygodwinarchive.org/contents/frankenstein/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Shelley-Godwin Archive</tei-ref>, which compares facsimiles of the original
                     manuscripts, and Brigit Katz’ article for <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Smithsonian
                        Magazine</tei-hi>, <tei-ref target="https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/frankenstein-manuscript-shows-evolution-mary-shelleys-monster-180968240/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"‘Frankenstein’ Manuscript Shows the Evolution of Mary Shelley’s
                        Monster."</tei-ref></tei-p>
               </tei-note></tei-docImprint>

            <tei-p data-origname="p">
               <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80024468" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">
                  <!-- ref target="william_godwin_" corresp="william_godwin">WILLIAM GODWIN</ref -->
                  <!--note xml:id="william_godwin" target="william_godwin_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AR"-->
                  <!-- -->
               </tei-persName>
               <tei-ref target="william_godwin_" corresp="william_godwin" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">WILLIAM GODWIN</tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="william_godwin" id="william_godwin" target="william_godwin_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AR" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a8/William_Godwin_by_Henry_William_Pickersgill.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Mary Shelley dedicated Frankenstein to her father, <tei-ref target="http://shelleysghost.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/william-godwin-index" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">William
                     Godwin</tei-ref>, the well known author of <tei-ref target="http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/godwin-an-enquiry-concerning-political-justice-vol-i" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">An Enquiry Concerning Political Justice</tei-ref> and <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=0bEVAAAAYAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Caleb Williams</tei-ref>.
                  William Godwin was an anarchist and supporter of the French Revolution, and many
                  of his theories of absolute sovereignty are alluded to within the text of
                  Frankenstein. Shelley learned much from her father’s library growing up, and thus
                  was highly influenced by her father’s beliefs. To learn more about Godwin, read
                  Chapter 4 of Rebecca Baumann’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein 200: The Birth,
                     Life, and Resurrection of Mary Shelley's Monster</tei-hi>, <tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt22p7j32.9" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Mary’s Father, William
                     Godwin"</tei-ref>. To learn more about Godwin’s influence on <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, listen to the University of Oxford’s <tei-ref target="https://podcasts.ox.ac.uk/godwin-and-frankenstein" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">podcast</tei-ref> on the
                  matter. The image above, via Wikimedia Commons, is a painting by Henry William
                  Pickersgill, housed in the National Portrait Gallery, London. </tei-note>,</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"> AUTHOR OF <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
                     <tei-ref target="political_justice_" corresp="political_justice" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">POLITICAL
                        JUSTICE</tei-ref>
                  </tei-bibl>
                  <tei-note xml:id="political_justice" id="political_justice" target="political_justice_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"> Published in 1793, William Godwin’s <tei-ref target="http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/godwin-an-enquiry-concerning-political-justice-vol-i" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                        <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Enquiry Concerning Political Justice and its Influence on
                           Morals and Happiness</tei-hi></tei-ref> is a philosophical text concerning
                     politics. Written after the French Revolution, a ten-year period of political
                     upheaval in France culminating in the overthrow of the monarchy and the
                     creation of a republic, Godwin’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Enquiry</tei-hi> also responds
                     to Edmund Burke’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Reflections on the Revolution in
                        France</tei-hi> and Thomas Paine’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Rights of
                     Man</tei-hi>--specifically, on questions of authority. Godwin wrote the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Enquiry</tei-hi> to advocate for the Enlightenment project of
                     social improvement. His radical writing resonated deeply with Romantic authors,
                     especially Samuel Taylor Coleridge and Percy Bysshe Shelley. For a more
                     in-depth look at how this work affected the authors of the Romantic Period see
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.litencyc.com/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Andrew McCann’s "William Godwin:
                        Enquiry Concerning Political Justice and its Influence on Modern Morals and
                        Manners"</tei-ref>, and for more information about Godwin’s influence on Mary
                     Shelley, see <tei-ref target="http://shelleysghost.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/william-godwin-and-mary-shelley" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">an online exhibit <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Shelley’s Ghost</tei-hi>, developed by the
                        Bodleian Libraries.</tei-ref></tei-note>, <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
                     <tei-ref target="caleb_williams_" corresp="caleb_williams" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">CALEB WILLIAMS</tei-ref>
                  </tei-bibl>
                  <tei-note xml:id="caleb_williams" id="caleb_williams" target="caleb_williams_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AR" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Published in May 1794, <tei-ref target="http://shelleygodwinarchive.org/contents/msl_1876_forster_223/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Things As They Are; or, The Adventures of Caleb
                           Williams</tei-hi></tei-ref> tells the story of an impoverished young man named
                     Caleb Williams, who learns that his wealthy employer, Ferdinando Falkland, is
                     guilty of murder. When Falkland realizes that Caleb suspects him, he falsely
                     accuses Caleb of attempted robbery, forcing him to flee the estate. Throughout
                     the novel, Caleb is accused of various crimes, pursued, robbed, beaten,
                     arrested, and convicted, but manages ultimately to escape captivity. The novel
                     is a pointed critique of the English judicial system, particularly its abuse of
                     power, and continues to develop themes that Godwin presented in his 1793
                     philosophical treatise, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">An Enquiry concerning Political
                        Justice</tei-hi>. For a detailed examination of Godwin’s writings and an
                     overview of Godwinian scholarship, see Pamela Clemit’s <tei-ref target="http://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199935338.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780199935338-e-47" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Revisiting William Godwin"</tei-ref> from Oxford Handbooks Online. </tei-note>,
                  &C.</tei-hi></tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">THESE VOLUMES</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Are respectfully inscribed</tei-hi></tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">BY</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="mary_shelley_" corresp="mary_shelley" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">THE AUTHOR</tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="mary_shelley" id="mary_shelley" target="mary_shelley_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-graphic url="https://collectionimages.npg.org.uk/large/mw05761/Mary-Wollstonecraft-Shelley.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley was born on August 30, 1797, in
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>, England, to William
                  Godwin and famed feminist writer Mary Wollstonecraft—the author of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Vindication of the Rights of Woman</tei-hi> (1792). Mary had a
                  difficult upbringing, as her mother died shortly after her birth and her father
                  remarried to Mary Jane Clairmont, who had a tenuous relationship with Mary. Mary
                  was never formally educated but read many of her father’s books and was introduced
                  to many influential writers like William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge.
                  Mary, while on a trip to Scotland visiting family friends, met and fell in love
                  with Percy Bysshe Shelley, who was already married and also a student of her
                  father. The two eloped in 1814 and travelled around Europe. It was in Switzerland,
                  with a cohort made up of the Shelleys, Jane Clairmont, Lord Byron, and John
                  Polidori, where Mary first began Frankenstein one rainy afternoon during a ghost
                  story writing exercise. <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> was published in 1818
                  anonymously with a foreword by Percy Shelley, whom many people assumed wrote the
                  novel. The novel was a huge success, and is now often considered the first science
                  fiction novel. After the success of her first novel, Shelley continued to write
                  but her personal life declined rapidly. She lost three children in her lifetime,
                  her half-sister committed suicide, and her marriage, riddled with affairs, ended
                  in 1822 when Percy Shelley drowned in the Gulf of Spezia. Mary died at 53 of brain
                  cancer on February 1, 1851 in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>, England. She was buried at St. Peter's Church in
                  Bournemouth, laid to rest with the cremated remains of her late husband's heart.
                  The portrait of Shelley included above, painted by Richard Rothwell (1840), is
                  housed in the National Portrait Gallery, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>. </tei-note></tei-p>







         </tei-div>


         <tei-div type="preface" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type">


            <tei-pb n="[1.vii]" facs="pageImages/vol1/vii.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


            <tei-head data-origname="head">Preface.</tei-head>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">
               <tei-ref target="event_" corresp="event" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">THE event on which this fiction is founded </tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="event" id="event" target="event_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> was created on a rainy afternoon in 1816 when
                  Mary Godwin (soon to be Mary Shelley), <tei-ref target="https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/percy-bysshe-shelley" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Percy Bysshe
                     Shelley</tei-ref>, <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/lord-byron" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Lord Byron</tei-ref>, and others were vacationing in Geneva. Lord Byron suggested
                  a gothic ghost story contest to alleviate their cabin fever--as 1816 was known as
                  the <tei-ref target="https://www.biography.com/news/mary-shelley-frankenstein-i-frankenstein-movie" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"year without a summer"</tei-ref> due to a <tei-ref target="https://www.npr.org/2007/08/13/12688403/did-climate-inspire-the-birth-of-a-monster" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">volcanic explosion</tei-ref> in the Dutch East Indies, causing a long winter in
                  most of the world. After working their way through established German ghost
                  stories, the group decided to try their hand at writing their own. For more
                  information on the circumstances of the creation of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> and how it affected the development of the text, see
                  Marshall Brown’s <tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/1346124" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Frankenstein":
                     A Child’s Tale"</tei-ref>, and for <tei-ref target="http://shelleygodwinarchive.org/contents/frankenstein/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">images</tei-ref> of
                  Shelley’s manuscript for <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> see the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Shelley-Godwin Archive</tei-hi>.</tei-note> has been supposed, by <tei-ref target="erasmus_darwin_" corresp="erasmus_darwin" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> Dr. <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n50037924" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type"> Darwin </tei-persName>
               </tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="erasmus_darwin" id="erasmus_darwin" target="erasmus_darwin_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://collectionimages.npg.org.uk/large/mw01731/Erasmus-Darwin.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Erasmus-Darwin" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Erasmus
                     Darwin</tei-ref> (1731-1802), grandfather of Charles Darwin, was a physician and
                  poet (pictured above is a reprint in the National Portrait Gallery, London by
                  Joseph Wright based on a work from the 1770’s). An industrialist, free thinker,
                  and inventor, he is well known for his for his classification novel, <tei-ref target="http://www.gutenberg.org/files/15707/15707-h/15707-h.htm" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Zoonomia, Or, The Laws Of Organic Life</tei-hi></tei-ref> which
                  created classes and categories for animals, and discussed pathology, anatomy, and
                  psychology. His works influenced many Romantic authors, such as William
                  Wordsworth, who referenced Darwin in <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books/about/Lyrical_Ballads_1798.html?id=n_kLiR3LSxQC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"The Tale of Goody Blake and Harry Gill."</tei-ref> For more information, see
                  Gavin Budge’s article <tei-ref target="https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/j.1754-0208.2007.tb00337.x" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Erasmus Darwin and the Poetics of William Wordsworth: ‘Excitement without the
                     Application of Gross and Violent Stimulants’"</tei-ref>. A radical thinker for the
                  time, Erasmus Darwin posited the development of life from "one living filament"
                  (Section XXXIX, Line 8); Darwin’s arguments would later be seen precursors to the
                  theory of evolution. Darwin also wrote poetry about nature and science, most
                  notably, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/ecco/004850944.0001.000?view=toc" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The
                        Loves of the Plants</tei-ref></tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Economy of
                  Vegetation</tei-hi>, and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://www.rc.umd.edu/editions/darwin_temple/index.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Temple
                        of Nature</tei-ref></tei-hi>. His views on living organisms and the creation of life
                  gives authority to] Victor’s ability to create life and offers a litmus for the
                  Romantic era skepticism about "playing God." For more information on Erasmus
                  Darwin in general see Michon Scott’s website <tei-ref target="https://www.strangescience.net/erasmus.htm" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Strange Science</tei-ref>; to
                  see Darwin’s influence on both Romantic and Victorian writers, see Thomas Hart’s
                  article on <tei-ref target="http://www.victorianweb.org/science/edarwin.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The
                     Victorian Web</tei-ref>. </tei-note> , and some of the physiological writers of
                  <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7000084" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Germany</tei-placeName>, as not of impossible
               occurrence. I shall not be supposed as according the remotest degree of serious faith
               to such an imagination; yet, in assuming it as the basis of a work of fancy, I have
               not considered myself as merely weaving a series of supernatural terrors. The event
               on <tei-pb n="[1.viii]" facs="pageImages/vol1/viii.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> which the interest of the story
               depends is exempt from the disadvantages of a mere tale of spectres or enchantment.
               It was recommended by the novelty of the situations which it developes; and, however
               impossible as a physical fact, affords a point of view to the imagination for the
               delineating of human passions more comprehensive and commanding than any which the
               ordinary relations of existing events can yield.</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">I have thus endeavoured to preserve the truth of the elementary principles of human
               nature, while I have not scrupled to innovate upon their combinations. <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-bibl data-origname="bibl"><tei-ref target="iliad_" corresp="iliad" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">The
                  Iliad</tei-ref></tei-bibl></tei-hi><tei-note xml:id="iliad" id="iliad" target="iliad_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Iliad</tei-hi>, composed in approximately
                  the 9th century BCE, is an epic poem in elevated and formal verse, narrating the
                  events that occurred in the ninth year of the attack on Troy. The story begins
                  with Agamemnon, the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"> wanax</tei-hi> of Mycenae and commander of the
                  various independent Achaean kingdoms, insulting Achilles. Turmoil ensues among the
                  Achaeans, who have been laying siege to the City of Troy for nearly ten years. The
                  story includes the death of Achilles’ closest friend Patroclus, which causes
                  Achilles to defeat and defile his murderer, Hector, Prince of Troy. The story
                  concludes with Achilles surrendering Hector’s body to King Priam, father of
                  Hector, and his recognition of a kinship between them through grief. See MIT’s
                     <tei-ref target="http://classics.mit.edu/Homer/iliad.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">full text</tei-ref> version
                  of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Iliad</tei-hi> translated by Samuel Butler.</tei-note>, <tei-ref target="tragedy_" corresp="tragedy" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">the tragic poetry of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Greece</tei-placeName></tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="tragedy" id="tragedy" target="tragedy_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Tragedy is an elevated literary form that originated in ancient Greece. According
                  to Aristotle’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0086.tlg034.perseus-eng1https://www.stmarys-ca.edu/sites/default/files/attachments/files/Poetics.pdf" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Poetics</tei-ref></tei-hi>, <tei-quote data-origname="quote">"Tragedy is, then, a representation of an action
                     that is heroic and complete and of a certain magnitude—by means of language
                     enriched with all kinds of ornament, each used separately in the different
                     parts of the play: it represents men in action and does not use narrative, and
                     through pity and fear it effects relief to these and similar emotions."</tei-quote>
                  (1449b), Romantic authors were <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/art/tragedy-literature/Romantic-theories" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">greatly influenced</tei-ref> by the ancient tragedies of <tei-ref target="http://www.ancient-literature.com/greece_aeschylus.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Aeschylus</tei-ref>, <tei-ref target="https://www.ancient.eu/sophocles/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Sophocles</tei-ref>, and <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Euripides" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Euripides</tei-ref>,
                  however they often turned the genre on its head. While tragedy in the original
                  sense featured a hero of noble birth, the Romantics, like <tei-ref target="https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/samuel-taylor-coleridge" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Samuel
                     Taylor Coleridge</tei-ref>, preferred to consider the common man. Often, Romantics
                  turned the argument inward, invoking Shakespeare’s tragedies in lieu of Ancient
                  ones (<tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Macbeth</tei-hi>,<tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Hamlet</tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Othello</tei-hi>).</tei-note>, <tei-ref target="william_shakespeare_" corresp="william_shakespeare" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                  <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n78095332" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Shakespeare</tei-persName>
               </tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="william_shakespeare" id="william_shakespeare" target="william_shakespeare_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://www.folger.edu/sites/default/files/TitlePageFirstFolio_005198.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> William Shakespeare (1564-1616) is one of the greatest writers
                  in the English language, known for composing 37 plays, 154 sonnets, and two long
                  narrative poems (pictured above is a digital print of Earl of Warwick’s 1623 first
                  folio of William Shakespeare’s works via the Folger Shakespeare Library).
                  Shakespeare’s works, known for his innovative, vivid use of language and his
                  exploration of individual subjectivity, were of special interest to the Romantics.
                     <tei-ref target="http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198129943.001.0001/acprof-9780198129943" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">As Jonathan Bate argues in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Shakespeare and the English
                        Romantic Imagination</tei-hi> (1989)</tei-ref>, the idea of natural genius and the
                  veneration of the creative imagination was essential to the Romantic ideology, and
                  Shakespeare became a key sign of natural creative genius. The "bardolatry" that
                  began in the mid-eighteenth century, <tei-ref target="https://www.britishcouncil.org/voices-magazine/how-one-actor-forever-changed-way-we-see-shakespeare" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">particularly through the actor David Garrick’s (1717-1779) energies</tei-ref>,
                  came to a head in the Romantic era, and has in many ways persisted to this day.
                  For more information on the role of Shakespeare in the Romantic era, see Bate’s
                  important monograph as well as <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=Zz5B2BP0lvAC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Joseph M. Ortiz’s
                     edited collection, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Shakespeare and the Culture of Romanticism
                     </tei-hi></tei-ref>. Mary Shelley would have been familiar with his works both through
                  her education at the hands of her father, William Godwin, and through her close
                  relationship with Byron, Shelley, Polidori, and other Romantics. <tei-ref target="http://exhibitions.nypl.org/biblion/outsiders/outsiders/story/storygodwinjuvenile" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Godwin, with his second wife Mary Jane Clairmont, created and published works
                     in a juvenlie library series for the improvement of young readers’ imaginations
                     that included, among histories of Greece and bible stories, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Tales From Shakespeare</tei-hi></tei-ref>.. All of these authors influenced her
                  writing, and Shakespeare colored her entire life; Shelley had lines from <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Tempest</tei-hi> carved into her husband’s tombstone. To read
                  more about Shakespeare’s influence on Mary Shelley’s life and writing see Robert
                  Sawyer’s article <tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/27784706


                                            " data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Mary Shelley and Shakespeare: Monstrous Creations"</tei-ref> or David Lee Clark’s
                  article, <tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/458637" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Shelley and
                     Shakespeare"</tei-ref>. For a full list of Shakespeare’s works, as well as
                  summaries and criticisms, see the <tei-ref target="https://www.folger.edu/shakespeares-works" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Folger Shakespeare
                     Library</tei-ref>.</tei-note>, in the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-bibl data-origname="bibl"><tei-ref target="tempest_" corresp="tempest" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">Tempest</tei-ref></tei-bibl></tei-hi><tei-note xml:id="tempest" id="tempest" target="tempest_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://shakespeare.mit.edu/tempest/full.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Tempest</tei-ref></tei-hi>
                  is a comedy written in 1610 by <tei-ref target="https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/william-shakespeare" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">William
                     Shakespeare</tei-ref> telling the story of the banished Duke of Milan, Prospero,
                  who has recreated his home on an island using magic--and usurped the native
                  inhabitants of the island to do so, imprisoning Sycorax and enslaving her son,
                  Caliban. Prospero causes the shipwreck of the King of Naples, Alonso, and his
                  brother, Antonio, who, twelve years earlier had conspired for Prospero’s position
                  thus banishing him from the kingdom. During the tale, Miranda, Prospero’s
                  daughter, and Ferdinand, Alonso’s son, fall in love, but must survive the tests
                  placed upon them by Prospero. Other castaways from the shipwreck land on the
                  island and conspire to destroy Prospero but in the end common ground and love
                  triumph. Explore more of the text on the <tei-ref target="https://www.folger.edu/tempest" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Folger Shakespeare
                  Library</tei-ref>.</tei-note> and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">
                  <tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">
                     <tei-pb n="[1.ix - page breaks after 'Mid-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/ix.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-ref target="midsummer_" corresp="midsummer" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">Midsummer Night's Dream</tei-ref>
                  </tei-bibl>
               </tei-hi>
               <tei-note xml:id="midsummer" id="midsummer" target="midsummer_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                  <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Oberon%2C_Titania_and_Puck_with_Fairies_Dancing._William_Blake._c.1786.jpg/800px-Oberon%2C_Titania_and_Puck_with_Fairies_Dancing._William_Blake._c.1786.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">
                     <tei-ref target="http://shakespeare.mit.edu/midsummer/full.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Midsummer Night’s
                        Dream</tei-ref>
                  </tei-hi> (1595) is a comedy by William Shakespeare. A play within a play, the story
                  is set in a fairyland Athenian forest during the marriage of Theseus, the Duke of
                  Athens, to Hippolyta, the Queen of the Amazons. The play’s complex subplots
                  involve a variety of complementary stories. The play opens with a love triangle
                  between Hermia, who is in love with Lysander but is being forced to marry
                  Demetrius by her father Egeus. Helena, Hermia’s best friend is in love with
                  Demetrius. On another side of the story are the "Rude Mechanicals," a group of six
                  skilled laborers who are planning a performance of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Pyramus and
                     Thisbe</tei-hi>. The last subplot involves the king and queen of the fairies,
                  Oberon and Titania, who are in an argument over a small child Titania is
                  protecting from Oberon. Oberon, in his frustration over Titania’s disobedience,
                  sends his sprite, Robin "Puck" Goodfellow, to create a love potion to shame
                  Titania into obedience. Puck wreaks havoc on all the characters, causing the men
                  to fall in love with Helena and rebuff Hermia, turning Bottom part donkey, and
                  prompting Titania to fall in love with Bottom. During this confusion, Oberon
                  steals the child from Titania, upon which success he orders Puck to set everything
                  straight. The play concludes with the Mechanicals’ inexpert play-within-a-play,
                  staged for the marriage festivities of Theseus and Hippolyta. Explore more about
                  the text at the <tei-ref target="https://www.folger.edu/midsummer-nights-dream" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Folger
                     Shakespeare Library</tei-ref> or see David Wiles <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books/about/Shakespeare_and_Carnival.html?id=Ft-SQgAACAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Shakespeare and Carnival: After Bakhtin</tei-hi></tei-ref>,
                  especially chapter 4, "The Carnivalesque in A Midsummer Night's Dream." The image
                  here is <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing</tei-hi> by
                  William Blake (1786) hosted by Tate Britain. </tei-note> and most especially <tei-ref target="john_milton_" corresp="john_milton" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                  <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n78095532" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Milton</tei-persName>
               </tei-ref>
               <tei-note xml:id="john_milton" id="john_milton" target="john_milton_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0c/John_Milton_portrait_painting.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>John Milton (1608-1674) was an English poet most notably known
                  for <tei-ref target="https://www.dartmouth.edu/~milton/reading_room/pl/intro/text.shtml" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paradise Lost</tei-hi></tei-ref>, a twelve-volume epic poem in blank
                     <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Milton" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Encyclopedia
                     Britannica</tei-ref>. The image included here is a portrait of Milton (1690) by
                  Godfrey Kneller, <tei-ref target="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Milton_portrait_painting.jpg" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">via Wikimedia Commons</tei-ref>.</tei-note> , in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-bibl data-origname="bibl">Paradise
                     Lost</tei-bibl></tei-hi>, conform to this rule; and <tei-ref target="novel_" corresp="novel" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">the most humble novelist</tei-ref><tei-note xml:id="novel" id="novel" target="novel_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Throughout the eighteenth century, the
                  novel as a modern form of entertainment accessible to a wide, middling-class, and
                  generally-educated audience grew. For more information on the "humble" novel, <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/restoration-18th-century-literature/articles/the-rise-of-the-novel" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">see John Mullan's "The Rise of the Novel" at the British Library</tei-ref>.</tei-note>
               , who seeks to confer or receive amusement from his labours, may, without
               presumption, apply to prose fiction a licence, or rather a rule, from the adoption of
               which so many exquisite combinations of human feeling have resulted in the highest
               specimens of poetry.</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="frankenstein_" corresp="frakenstein" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">The circumstance on which my story
                  rests was suggested in casual conversation.</tei-ref> It was commenced partly as a
               source of amusement, and partly as an expedient for exercising any untried resources
               of mind. Other motives were mingled with these as the work <tei-pb n="[1.x - page breaks after 'pro-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/x.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> proceeded. I
               am by no means indifferent to the manner in which whatever moral tendencies exist in
               the sentiments or characters it contains shall affect the reader; yet my chief
               concern in this respect has been limited to the avoiding the enervating effects of
               the novels of the present day, and to the exhibition of the amiableness of domestic
               affection, and the excellence of universal virtue. The opinions which naturally
               spring from the character and situation of the hero are by no means to be conceived
               as existing always in my own conviction; nor is any inference justly to be drawn from
               the following pages as prejudicing any philosophical doctrine of whatever kind.</tei-p>


            <tei-pb n="[1.xi]" facs="pageImages/vol1/xi.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">It is a subject also of additional interest to the author that this story was begun
               in the majestic region where the scene is principally laid, and in society which
               cannot cease to be regretted. I passed the summer of <tei-date data-origname="date">1816</tei-date> in the
               environs of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. The season was
               cold and rainy, and in the evenings we crowded around a blazing wood fire, and
               occasionally amused ourselves with some German stories of ghosts, which happened to
               fall into our hands. These tales excited in us a playful desire of imitation. Two
               other friends (a tale from the pen of one of whom would be far more acceptable to the
               public than any thing I can ever hope to produce) and <tei-pb n="[1.xii]" facs="pageImages/vol1/xii.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> myself agreed to write each a story founded on
               some supernatural occurrence.</tei-p>


            <tei-p data-origname="p">The weather, however, suddenly became serene; and my two friends left me on a journey
               among the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Alps</tei-placeName>, and lost, in the
               magnificent scenes which they present, all memory of their ghostly visions. The
               following tale is the only one which has been completed.</tei-p>
         </tei-div>
      </tei-front>




      <tei-body data-origname="body">












         <tei-div n="1" type="volume" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


            <tei-pb n="[1.1]" facs="pageImages/vol1/1.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


            <tei-head type="title" data-origname="head" data-origatts="type">FRANKENSTEIN<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>OR, THE<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">MODERN
                  PROMETHEUS.</tei-hi><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> [VOL. I.]</tei-head>







            <tei-div n="1.1" type="letter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-head data-origname="head">LETTER I</tei-head>

               <tei-opener data-origname="opener">
                  <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">To Mrs.</tei-hi> SAVILLE, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">ENGLAND</tei-placeName></tei-hi>
                  <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7010273" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">St. Petersburg</tei-placeName>. <tei-dateline data-origname="dateline"><tei-ref target="time_" corresp="time" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">Dec. 11, 17--</tei-ref></tei-dateline><tei-note xml:id="time" id="time" target="time_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">According to a footnote in the <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=UQc52fOn3hUC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">3rd Broadview
                           edition of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein, or; The Modern
                           Prometheus</tei-hi></tei-ref>, the novel takes place in 1796. If this is true,
                        the entire tale takes place around the date of the author's birth and her
                        mother Mary Wollstonecraft's death. </tei-p>
                  </tei-note>
               </tei-opener>







               <tei-p data-origname="p">YOU will rejoice to hear that no disaster has accompanied the commencement of an
                  enterprise which you have regarded with such evil forebodings. I arrived here
                  yesterday; and my first task is to assure my dear sister of my welfare, and
                  increasing confidence in the success of my undertaking.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">I am already far north of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>;
                  and as I walk in the streets of <tei-pb n="[1.2 - page breaks after 'Peters-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/2.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7010273" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Petersburgh</tei-placeName>, I feel a cold
                  northern breeze play upon my cheeks, which braces my nerves, and fills me with
                  delight. Do you understand this feeling? This breeze, which has travelled from the
                  regions towards which I am advancing, <tei-ref target="artic_" corresp="artic" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> gives
                     me a foretaste of those icy climes. </tei-ref> Inspirited by this wind of promise,
                  my day dreams become more fervent and vivid. I try in vain to be persuaded that
                  the pole is the seat of frost and desolation; it ever presents itself to my
                  imagination as the region of beauty and delight <tei-note xml:id="artic" id="artic" target="artic_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                     <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a2/John_Ross_%281777-1856%29%2C_by_British_school_of_the_19th_century.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-ref target="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/04/24/literatures-arctic-obsession" rend="rightAlign" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="rend target"> According to Kathryn Shultz in "Literature's Arctic
                        Obsession,"</tei-ref> Shelley--like many during the early nineteenth
                     century--was intrigued by the prospect of arctic exploration, as her frequent
                     allusions to Coleridge's "Rime of the Ancient Mariner" and her letters make
                     clear. While Shelley may have added the arctic setting as "an afterthought"
                     after reading about attempts to discover the long-elusive Northwest passage, by
                     the time <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> was published, two major
                     expeditions were underway; the Passage would be discovered in 1850 after many
                     deaths on the ice. As Shultz notes, "the book reminded readers that their world
                     was already full of Dr. Frankensteins." For further reading, see <tei-ref target="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0890549032000167826" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                        "'A Paradise of My Own Creation': Frankenstein and the Improbable Romance of
                        Polar Expedition," by Jessica Richard.</tei-ref> The image above, via WikiMedia
                     Commons, shows a portrait (c.1833) of the explorer John Ross (1777-1856).
                  </tei-note>. There, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>, the sun is for ever visible; its
                  broad disk just skirting the horizon, and diffusing a perpetual splendour.
                  There—for with your leave, my sister, I will put some trust in preceding
                  navigators—there snow and frost are banished; and, sailing over a calm sea, we may
                  be wafted to a land surpassing in wonders <tei-pb n="[1.3]" facs="pageImages/vol1/3.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and in beauty every region hitherto discovered
                  on the habitable globe. Its productions and features may be without example, as
                  the phænomena of the heavenly bodies undoubtedly are in those undiscovered
                  solitudes. What may not be expected in a country of eternal light? I may there
                  discover <tei-ref target="electromagnetism_" corresp="electromagnetism" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> the wondrous
                     power which attracts the needle</tei-ref>
                  <tei-note xml:id="electromagnetism" id="electromagnetism" target="electromagnetism_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                     url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Br%C3%BAjula_azimutal_espa%C3%B1ola_s.XVIII_%28M.A.N._Madrid%29_01.jpg/506px-Br%C3%BAjula_azimutal_espa%C3%B1ola_s.XVIII_%28M.A.N._Madrid%29_01.jpg"
                     /> From the <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/science/electromagnetism/Historical-survey" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"> 13th through the 19th centuries, scholars and scientists were
                        investigating the nature of electromagnetism</tei-ref>, though, as noted in the
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/200807/physicshistory.cfm" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                        American Physical Society newsletter of July 2008</tei-ref>, most people thought
                     they were separate forces. <tei-ref target="https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/ecco/004850944.0001.000/1:8.2" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Economy of Vegetation</tei-hi>, a 1791 poem by Erasmus
                        Darwin</tei-ref>, Charles Darwin’s grandfather, speculates on the nature of
                     electromagnetism (see canto 2 lines 193ff). In 1820, two years after the
                     publication of Frankenstein, Danish scientist Hans Christian Oersted discovered
                     that electric current could produce a magnetic effect on a compass, which
                     normally points due north--toward the Earth’s magnetic core. For more
                     information on Darwin’s influence in the late eighteenth century, see <tei-ref target="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2002/sep/21/featuresreviews.guardianreview30" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"> Jenny Uglow’s review of his work in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The
                        Guardian</tei-hi></tei-ref> The image above, via Wikimedia Commons, shows an
                     eighteenth-century compass of Spanish origin. </tei-note>; and may regulate a
                  thousand celestial observations, that require only this voyage to render their
                  seeming eccentricities consistent for ever. I shall satiate my ardent curiosity
                  with the sight of a part of the world never before visited, and may tread a land
                  never before imprinted by the foot of man. These are my enticements, and they are
                  sufficient to conquer all fear of danger or death, and to induce me to commence
                  this laborious voyage with the joy a child feels when he embarks <tei-pb n="[1.4]" facs="pageImages/vol1/4.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> in a little boat, with his holiday mates, on an
                  expedition of discovery up his native river. But, supposing all these conjectures
                  to be false, you cannot contest the inestimable benefit which I shall confer on
                  all mankind to the last generation, by discovering a passage near the pole to
                  those countries, to reach which at present so many months are requisite; or by
                  ascertaining the secret of the magnet, which, if at all possible, can only be
                  effected by an undertaking such as mine.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">These reflections have dispelled the agitation with which I began my letter, and I
                  feel my heart glow with an <tei-ref target="enthusiasm_" corresp="enthusiasm" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                     enthusiasm </tei-ref>
                  <tei-note xml:id="enthusiasm" id="enthusiasm" target="enthusiasm_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Enthusiasm is an important concept in the development of
                     Romanticism. Deriving from the Greek word "enthous," meannig possessed or
                     inspired by a god, the concept of enthusiasm was linked to <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books/about/Enlightening_Enthusiasm.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">religious fanaticism (particularly Methodism)</tei-ref> during the early
                     eighteenth century and described by philosophers like Locke and Hume as an
                     error in thinking that reason and reflection could correct. Enthusiasm was
                     also, however, understood as the ability to "see the truth transparently and
                     spontaneously without mediation" (Mee 8). <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books/about/Romanticism_Enthusiasm_and_Regulation.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Jon Mee, in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Romanticism, Enthusiasm, and
                        Regulation</tei-hi></tei-ref>, goes on to note: "Although it was often associated
                     with the sort of implosion of the self that came from the prophet retiring into
                     the wilderness, a species of melancholia and gloomy introspection, it was also
                     routinely construed in terms of the delirium of the senses that manifested
                     itself in the mania of the crowd" (10-11). Closely related to concepts of
                     imagination and fancy, enthusiasm is a complex term that suggests many of the
                     negative aspects of the Romantic sensibility. For Wordsworth and Coleridge,
                     enthusiasm is a kind of corruption of or detour in the imagination (Mee 12).
                  </tei-note> which elevates me to heaven; for nothing contributes so much to
                  tranquillize the mind as a steady purpose,—a point on which the soul may fix its
                  intellectual eye. This expedition has been the favourite dream of my <tei-pb n="[1.5]" facs="pageImages/vol1/5.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> early years. I have read with ardour the
                  accounts of the various voyages which have been made in the prospect of arriving
                  at the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7029367" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">North Pacific Ocean</tei-placeName> through
                  the seas which surround the pole. You may remember that a history of all the
                  voyages made for purposes of discovery composed the whole of our good
                  uncle <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Thomas</tei-persName>'s library. My education was neglected, yet I was
                  passionately fond of reading. These volumes were my study day and night, and my
                  familiarity with them increased that regret which I had felt, as a child, on
                  learning that my father's dying injunction had forbidden my uncle to allow me to
                  embark in a sea-faring life.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">These visions faded when I perused, for the first time, those poets whose
                  effusions entranced my soul, and lifted it to heaven. I also became a poet, <tei-pb n="[1.6]" facs="pageImages/vol1/6.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and for one year lived in a Paradise
                  of my own creation; I imagined that I also might obtain a niche in the temple
                  where the names of <tei-ref target="Homer_" corresp="Homer" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                     <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n78095639" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type"> Homer</tei-persName>
                  </tei-ref>
                  <tei-note xml:id="Homer" id="Homer" target="Homer_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-ref target="https://www.ancient.eu/homer/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Homer</tei-ref> is the figure credited
                     with the composition of two epic poems, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Iliad</tei-hi> and
                        <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Odyssey</tei-hi>, considered to be the first extant works
                     of Greek literature. Though modern scholarship questions the existence of a
                     single person called "Homer," the idea of such authorship has had an enduring
                     interpretive effect from ancient times to the present. Known as the "Father of
                     Western Literature," Homer is credited with a number of hymns and lesser works
                     in addition to <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Iliad</tei-hi> and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The
                        Odyssey</tei-hi>. If such an individual existed, scholars have suggested his
                     floruit as anywhere between the 9th to 7th centuries BCE. To learn more about
                     Homer, see Suzanne Saïd’s entry in the <tei-ref target="http://classics.oxfordre.com" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Oxford Classical
                     Dictionary</tei-ref>.</tei-note> and <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n78095332" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Shakespeare</tei-persName> are consecrated. You are well acquainted with my
                  failure, and how heavily I bore the disappointment. But just at that time I
                  inherited the fortune of my cousin, and my thoughts were turned into the channel
                  of their earlier bent.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Six years have passed since I resolved on my present undertaking. I can, even now,
                  remember the hour from which I dedicated myself to this great enterprise. I
                  commenced by inuring my body to hardship. I accompanied the whale-fishers on
                  several expeditions to the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7015931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">North
                     Sea</tei-placeName>; I voluntarily endured cold, famine, thirst, and want of sleep;
                  I often worked harder than the common sailors during the day, and devoted my <tei-pb n="[1.7]" facs="pageImages/vol1/7.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> nights to the study of mathematics,
                  the theory of medicine, and those branches of physical science from which a naval
                  adventurer might derive the greatest practical advantage. Twice I actually hired
                  myself as an under-mate in a <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7024573" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Greenland</tei-placeName> whaler, and acquitted myself to admiration. I must own I
                  felt a little proud, when my captain offered me the second dignity in the vessel,
                  and entreated me to remain with the greatest earnestness; so valuable did he
                  consider my services.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">And now, dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>, do I not deserve to accomplish some
