                  great purpose? My life might have been passed in ease and luxury; but I preferred
                  glory to every enticement that wealth placed in my path. Oh, that some encouraging
                  voice would answer in the affirmative! My courage and my resolution is firm; but
                  my hopes fluctuate, <tei-pb n="[1.8]" facs="pageImages/vol1/8.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and my spirits
                  are often depressed. I am about to proceed on a long and difficult voyage, the
                  emergencies of which will demand all my fortitude: I am required not only to raise
                  the spirits of others, but sometimes to sustain my own, when their's are
                  failing.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">This is the most favourable period for travelling in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002435" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Russia</tei-placeName>. They fly quickly over the snow in their
                  sledges; the motion is pleasant, and, in my opinion, far more agreeable than that
                  of an English stage-coach. The cold is not excessive, if you are wrapped in furs,
                  a dress which I have already adopted; for there is a great difference between
                  walking the deck and remaining seated motionless for hours, when no exercise
                  prevents the blood from actually freezing in your veins. I have no ambition to
                  lose my life on the post-road between <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7010273" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">St.
                     Petersburgh</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Archangel</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>


               <tei-pb n="[1.9]" facs="pageImages/vol1/9.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">I shall depart for the latter town in a fortnight or three weeks; and my intention
                  is to hire a ship there, which can easily be done by paying the insurance for the
                  owner, and to engage as many sailors as I think necessary among those who are
                  accustomed to the whale-fishing. I do not intend to sail until the month of
                     <tei-date data-origname="date">June</tei-date>: and when shall I return? Ah, dear sister, how can I answer
                  this question? If I succeed, many, many months, perhaps years, will pass before
                  you and I may meet. If I fail, you will see me again soon, or never.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Farewell, my dear, excellent <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>. Heaven shower down
                  blessings on you, and save me, that I may again and again testify my gratitude for
                  all your love and kindness.</tei-p>


               <tei-closer data-origname="closer">
                  <tei-salute data-origname="salute">Your affectionate brother,</tei-salute>
                  <tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">R. WALTON.</tei-persName></tei-signed>
               </tei-closer>


            </tei-div>






            <tei-div n="1.2" type="letter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[1.10]" facs="pageImages/vol1/10.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">LETTER II </tei-head>


               <tei-opener data-origname="opener">
                  <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">To Mrs.</tei-hi> SAVILLE, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">ENGLAND</tei-placeName></tei-hi>
                  <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Archangel</tei-placeName>, <tei-dateline data-origname="dateline">28th March,
                     17--.</tei-dateline>
               </tei-opener>












               <tei-p data-origname="p">HOW slowly the time passes here, encompassed as I am by frost and snow! yet a
                  second step is taken towards my enterprise. I have hired a vessel, and am occupied
                  in collecting my sailors; those whom I have already engaged appear to be men on
                  whom I can depend, and are certainly possessed of dauntless courage.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">But I have one want which I have never yet been able to satisfy; and the absence
                  of the object of which I <tei-pb n="[1.11]" facs="pageImages/vol1/11.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> now feel
                  as a most severe evil. I have no friend, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>: when I am
                  glowing with the enthusiasm of success, there will be none to participate my joy;
                  if I am assailed by disappointment, no one will endeavour to sustain me in
                  dejection. I shall commit my thoughts to paper, it is true; but that is a poor
                  medium for the communication of feeling. I desire the company of a man who could
                  sympathize with me; whose eyes would reply to mine. You may deem me romantic, my
                  dear sister, but I bitterly feel the want of a friend. I have no one near me,
                  gentle yet courageous, possessed of a cultivated as well as of a capacious mind,
                  whose tastes are like my own, to approve or amend my plans. How would such a
                  friend repair the faults of your poor brother! I am too ardent in execution, and
                  too impatient of <tei-pb n="[1.12 - page breaks after 'difficul-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/12.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> difficulties. But it is a still greater evil to
                  me that I am self-educated: for the first fourteen years of my life I ran wild on
                  a common, and read nothing but our uncle <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Thomas</tei-persName>'s books of
                  voyages. At that age I became acquainted with the celebrated poets of our own
                  country; but it was only when it had ceased to be in my power to derive its most
                  important benefits from such a conviction, that I perceived the necessity of
                  becoming acquainted with more languages than that of my native country. Now I am
                  twenty-eight, and am in reality more illiterate than many school-boys of fifteen.
                  It is true that I have thought more, and that my day dreams are more extended and
                  magnificent; but they want (as the painters call it) keeping; and I greatly need a
                  friend who would have sense enough not to despise me as romantic, and affection <tei-pb n="[1.13]" facs="pageImages/vol1/13.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> enough for me to endeavour to regulate my
                  mind.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Well, these are useless complaints; I shall certainly find no friend on the wide
                  ocean, nor even here in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Archangel</tei-placeName>,
                  among merchants and seamen. Yet some feelings, unallied to the dross of human
                  nature, beat even in these rugged bosoms. My lieutenant, for instance, is a man of
                  wonderful courage and enterprise; he is madly desirous of glory. He is an
                  Englishman, and in the midst of national and professional prejudices, unsoftened
                  by cultivation, retains some of the noblest endowments of humanity. I first became
                  acquainted with him on board a whale vessel: finding that he was unemployed in
                  this city, I easily engaged him to assist in my enterprise.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">The master is a person of an excellent disposition, and is remarkable in <tei-pb n="[1.14]" facs="pageImages/vol1/14.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the ship for his gentleness, and the
                  mildness of his discipline. He is, indeed, of so amiable a nature, that he will
                  not hunt (a favourite, and almost the only amusement here), because he cannot
                  endure to spill blood. He is, moreover, heroically generous. Some years ago he
                  loved a young Russian lady, of moderate fortune; and having amassed a considerable
                  sum in prize-money, the father of the girl consented to the match. He saw his
                  mistress once before the destined ceremony; but she was bathed in tears, and,
                  throwing herself at his feet, entreated him to spare her, confessing at the same
                  time that she loved another, but that he was poor, and that her father would never
                  consent to the union. My generous friend reassured the suppliant, and on being
                  informed of the name of her lover instantly abandoned his pursuit. He had <tei-pb n="[1.15]" facs="pageImages/vol1/15.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> already bought a farm with his
                  money, on which he had designed to pass the remainder of his life; but he bestowed
                  the whole on his rival, together with the remains of his prize-money to purchase
                  stock, and then himself solicited the young woman's father to consent to her
                  marriage with her lover. But the old man decidedly refused, thinking himself bound
                  in honour to my friend; who, when he found the father inexorable, quitted his
                  country, nor returned until he heard that his former mistress was married
                  according to her inclinations. <tei-said who="#margaretWalton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"What a noble
                     fellow!"</tei-said> you will exclaim. He is so; but then he has passed all his life
                  on board a vessel, and has scarcely an idea beyond the rope and the shroud.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">But do not suppose that, because I complain a little, or because I can conceive a
                  consolation for my toils which I <tei-pb n="[1.16]" facs="pageImages/vol1/16.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  may never know, that I am wavering in my resolutions. Those are as fixed as fate;
                  and my voyage is only now delayed until the weather shall permit my embarkation.
                  The winter has been dreadfully severe; but the spring promises well, and it is
                  considered as a remarkably early season; so that, perhaps, I may sail sooner than
                  I expected. I shall do nothing rashly; you know me sufficiently to confide in my
                  prudence and considerateness whenever the safety of others is committed to my
                  care.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">I cannot describe to you my sensations on the near prospect of my undertaking. It
                  is impossible to communicate to you a conception of the trembling sensation, half
                  pleasurable and half fearful, with which I am preparing to depart. I am going to
                  unexplored regions, to <tei-quote data-origname="quote">"the land of mist and <tei-pb n="[1.17]" facs="pageImages/vol1/17.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> snow;"</tei-quote>
                  <tei-ref target="the_Mariner_" corresp="the_Mariner" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> but I shall kill no albatross </tei-ref>
                  <tei-note xml:id="the_Mariner" id="the_Mariner" target="the_Mariner_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                     <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/26/Rime_of_the_Ancient_Mariner-Albatross-Dore.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>In this excerpt from <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/samuel-taylor-coleridge" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s</tei-ref>
                     <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/43997/the-rime-of-the-ancient-mariner-text-of-1834" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Rime of the Ancient Mariner</tei-hi></tei-ref> (451- 456),
                     the Mariner has killed the albatross and the other sailors turn on him, viewing
                     his act of violence as a sin against God and nature. The luck of the ship
                     dissipates, and they are becalmed on the ocean. The Mariner watches as each of
                     the sailors die of thirst, while he alone is saved. This direct allusion
                     highlights the similarities between the Mariner and Frankenstein, who are both
                     reeling after accomplishing their respective goals--killing the albatross and
                     creating a sentient being--and both in the process of telling their stories.
                     The use of the quote is two-fold; it highlights Frankenstein’s isolation and
                     his decision to abandon his creature, but it also juxtaposes the Mariner’s
                     violence with Frankenstein’s act of creation. Explore more about Coleridge’s
                     poem in William Christie’s <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt1d10h2h.10" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">“The Search for
                        Meaning in The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,"</tei-ref>. See Michelle Levy’s
                     article, <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/3844532" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">“Discovery and the
                        Domestic Affections in Coleridge and Shelley,"</tei-ref> for a discussion of
                     Samuel Taylor Coleridge’s influence on Mary Shelley. </tei-note>, therefore do not
                  be alarmed for my safety.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Shall I meet you again, after having traversed immense seas, and returned by
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">the most southern cape of
                     Africa</tei-placeName> or <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8698314" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">America</tei-placeName>?
                  I dare not expect such success, yet I cannot bear to look on the reverse of the
                  picture. Continue to write to me by every opportunity; I may receive your letters
                  (though the chance is very doubtful) on some occasions when I need them most to
                  support my spirits. I love you very tenderly. Remember me with affection, should
                  you never hear from me again.</tei-p>


               <tei-closer data-origname="closer">
                  <tei-salute data-origname="salute">Your affectionate brother,</tei-salute>
                  <tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ROBERT WALTON.</tei-persName></tei-signed>
               </tei-closer>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="1.3" type="letter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[1.18]" facs="pageImages/vol1/18.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">LETTER III</tei-head>


               <tei-opener data-origname="opener">To <tei-persName data-origname="persName"> Mrs. SAVILLE, </tei-persName><tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">ENGLAND</tei-placeName>. <tei-dateline data-origname="dateline">July 7th, 17--. </tei-dateline>
                  <tei-salute data-origname="salute">MY DEAR SISTER,</tei-salute>
               </tei-opener>







               <tei-p data-origname="p">I WRITE a few lines in haste, to say that I am safe, and well advanced on my
                  voyage. This letter will reach <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName> by a merchant-man now on its homeward voyage from
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Archangel</tei-placeName>; more fortunate than
                  I, who may not see my native land, perhaps, for many years. I am, however, in good
                  spirits: my men are bold, and apparently firm of purpose; nor do the floating
                  sheets of ice that continually pass us, <tei-pb n="[1.19 - page breaks after 'indi-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/19.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> indicating the dangers of the region towards
                  which we are advancing, appear to dismay them. We have already reached a very high
                  latitude; but it is the height of summer, and although not so warm as in
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>, the southern gales,
                  which blow us speedily towards those shores which I so ardently desire to attain,
                  breathe a degree of renovating warmth which I had not expected.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">No incidents have hitherto befallen us that would make a figure in a letter. One
                  or two stiff gales, and the breaking of a mast, are accidents which experienced
                  navigators scarcely remember to record; and I shall be well content, if nothing
                  worse happen to us during our voyage.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Adieu, my dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>. Be assured, that for my own sake, as
                  well as your's, I will not rashly encounter <tei-pb n="[1.20 - page breaks after 'dan-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/20.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> danger. I
                  will be cool, persevering, and prudent.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Remember me to all my English friends.</tei-p>







               <tei-closer data-origname="closer">
                  <tei-salute data-origname="salute">Most affectionately yours,</tei-salute>
                  <tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">R.W.</tei-persName></tei-signed>
               </tei-closer>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="1.4" type="letter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">







               <tei-pb n="[1.21]" facs="pageImages/vol1/21.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">LETTER IV</tei-head>







               <tei-div data-origname="div">


                  <tei-opener data-origname="opener">To <tei-persName data-origname="persName"> Mrs. SAVILLE, </tei-persName>
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">ENGLAND</tei-placeName>. <tei-dateline data-origname="dateline">August 5th,
                        17--.</tei-dateline>
                  </tei-opener>







                  <tei-p data-origname="p">So strange an accident has happened to us, that I cannot forbear recording it,
                     although it is very probable that you will see me before these papers can come
                     into your possession.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Last <tei-date data-origname="date">Monday (July 31st)</tei-date>, we were nearly surrounded by ice, which
                     closed in the ship on all sides, scarcely leaving her the searoom in which she
                     floated. Our situation was somewhat dangerous, especially as we were compassed
                     round by a very thick fog. We accordingly lay to, hoping that some <tei-pb n="[1.22]" facs="pageImages/vol1/22.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> change would take place in the
                     atmosphere and weather.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">About two o'clock the mist cleared away, and we beheld, stretched out in every
                     direction, vast and irregular plains of ice, which seemed to have no end. Some
                     of my comrades groaned, and my own mind began to grow watchful with anxious
                     thoughts, when a strange sight suddenly attracted our attention, and diverted
                     our solicitude from our own situation. We perceived a low carriage, fixed on a
                     sledge and drawn by dogs, pass on towards the north, at the distance of half a
                     mile: a being which had the shape of a man, but apparently of gigantic stature,
                     sat in the sledge, and guided the dogs. We watched the rapid progress of the
                     traveller with our telescopes, until he was lost among the distant inequalities
                     of the ice.</tei-p>


                  <tei-pb n="[1.23]" facs="pageImages/vol1/23.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This appearance excited our unqualified wonder. We were, as we believed, many
                     hundred miles from any land; but this apparition seemed to denote that it was
                     not, in reality, so distant as we had supposed. Shut in, however, by ice, it
                     was impossible to follow his track, which we had observed with the greatest
                     attention.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">About two hours after this occurrence, we heard the ground sea; and before
                     night the ice broke, and freed our ship. We, however, lay to until the morning,
                     fearing to encounter in the dark those large loose masses which float about
                     after the breaking up of the ice. I profited of this time to rest for a few
                     hours.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In the morning, however, as soon as it was light, I went upon the deck, and
                     found all the sailors busy on one side <tei-pb n="[1.24]" facs="pageImages/vol1/24.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of the vessel, apparently talking to some
                     one in the sea. It was, in fact, a sledge, like that we had seen before, which
                     had drifted towards us in the night, on a large fragment of ice. Only one dog
                     remained alive; but there was a human being within it, whom the sailors were
                     persuading to enter the vessel. He was not, as the other traveller seemed to
                     be, a savage inhabitant of some undiscovered island, but an European. When I
                     appeared on deck, the master said, <tei-said who="#master" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Here is our captain,
                        and he will not allow you to perish on the open sea."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">On perceiving me, the stranger addressed me in English, although with a foreign
                     accent. <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Before I come on board your vessel,"</tei-said> said
                     he, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"will you have the kindness to inform me whither you
                        are bound?"</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">You may conceive my astonishment <tei-pb n="[1.25]" facs="pageImages/vol1/25.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     on hearing such a question addressed to me from a man on the brink of
                     destruction, and to whom I should have supposed that my vessel would have been
                     a resource which he would not have exchanged for the most precious wealth the
                     earth can afford. I replied, however, that we were on a voyage of discovery
                     towards the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1112230" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">northern pole</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Upon hearing this he appeared satisfied, and consented to come on board. Good
                     God! <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>, if you had seen the man who thus
                     capitulated for his safety, your surprise would have been boundless. His limbs
                     were nearly frozen, and his body dreadfully emaciated by fatigue and suffering.
                     I never saw a man in so wretched a condition. We attempted to carry him into
                     the cabin; but as soon as he had quitted the fresh air, he fainted. We
                     accordingly <tei-pb n="[1.26]" facs="pageImages/vol1/26.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> brought him back to
                     the deck, and restored him to animation by rubbing him with brandy, and forcing
                     him to swallow a small quantity. As soon as he shewed signs of life, we wrapped
                     him up in blankets, and placed him near the chimney of the kitchen-stove. By
                     slow degrees he recovered, and ate a little soup, which restored him
                     wonderfully.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Two days passed in this manner before he was able to speak; and I often feared
                     that his sufferings had deprived him of understanding. When he had in some
                     measure recovered, I removed him to my own cabin, and attended on him as much
                     as my duty would permit. I never saw a more interesting creature: his eyes have
                     generally an expression of wildness, and even madness; but there are moments
                     when, if any-one performs an act of kindness <tei-pb n="[1.27]" facs="pageImages/vol1/27.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> towards him, or does him any the most
                     trifling service, his whole countenance is lighted up, as it were, with a beam
                     of benevolence and sweetness that I never saw equalled. But he is generally
                     melancholy and despairing; and sometimes he gnashes his teeth, as if impatient
                     of the weight of woes that oppresses him.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When my guest was a little recovered, I had great trouble to keep off the men,
                     who wished to ask him a thousand questions; but I would not allow him to be
                     tormented by their idle curiosity, in a state of body and mind whose
                     restoration evidently depended upon entire repose. Once, however, the
                     lieutenant asked, <tei-said who="#lieutenant" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Why he had come so far upon the ice
                        in so strange a vehicle?"</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">His countenance instantly assumed an aspect of the deepest gloom; and he <tei-pb n="[1.28]" facs="pageImages/vol1/28.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> replied, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"To
                        seek one who fled from me."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"And did the man whom you pursued travel in the same
                        fashion?"</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Yes."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Then I fancy we have seen him; for, the day before we
                        picked you up, we saw some dogs drawing a sledge, with a man in it, across
                        the ice."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This aroused the stranger's attention; and he asked a multitude of questions
                     concerning the route which the dæmon, as he called him, had pursued. Soon
                     after, when he was alone with me, he said, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I have,
                        doubtless, excited your curiosity, as well as that of these good people; but
                        you are too considerate to make inquiries."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Certainly; it would indeed be very impertinent and inhuman
                        in me to trouble you with any inquisitiveness of mine."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-pb n="[1.29]" facs="pageImages/vol1/29.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"And yet you rescued me from a strange and perilous
                        situation; you have benevolently restored me to life."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Soon after this <tei-said who="#victor" aloud="false" data-origname="said" data-origatts="aloud who">he inquired, if I thought
                        that the breaking up of the ice had destroyed the other sledge?</tei-said>
                     <tei-said who="#walton" aloud="false" data-origname="said" data-origatts="aloud who">I replied, that I could not answer with any
                        degree of certainty; for the ice had not broken until near midnight, and the
                        traveller might have arrived at a place of safety before that time; but of
                        this I could not judge.</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">From this time the stranger seemed very eager to be upon deck, to watch for the
                     sledge which had before appeared; but I have persuaded him to remain in the
                     cabin, for he is far too weak to sustain the rawness of the atmosphere. But I
                     have promised that some one should watch for him, and give him instant notice
                     if any new object should appear in sight.</tei-p>


                  <tei-pb n="[1.30]" facs="pageImages/vol1/30.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Such is my journal of what relates to this strange occurrence up to the present
                     day. The stranger has gradually improved in health, but is very silent, and
                     appears uneasy when any one except myself enters his cabin. Yet his manners are
                     so conciliating and gentle, that the sailors are all interested in him,
                     although they have had very little communication with him. For my own part, I
                     begin to love him as a brother; and his constant and deep grief fills me with
                     sympathy and compassion. He must have been a noble creature in his better days,
                     being even now in wreck so attractive and amiable.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I said in one of my letters, my dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>, that I
                     should find no friend on the wide ocean; yet I have found a man who, before his
                     spirit had been broken by misery, I should have been <tei-pb n="[1.31]" facs="pageImages/vol1/31.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> happy to have possessed as the brother of my
                     heart.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I shall continue my journal concerning the stranger at intervals, should I have
                     any fresh incidents to record.</tei-p>


               </tei-div>



               <tei-div data-origname="div">




                  <tei-opener data-origname="opener"><tei-dateline data-origname="dateline">August 13th, 17--.</tei-dateline></tei-opener>


                  <!-- question -->


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My affection for my guest increases every day. He excites at once my admiration
                     and my pity to an astonishing degree. How can I see so noble a creature
                     destroyed by misery without feeling the most poignant grief? He is so gentle,
                     yet so wise; his mind is so cultivated; and when he speaks, although his words
                     are culled with the choicest art, yet they flow with rapidity and unparalleled
                     eloquence.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He is now much recovered from his illness, and is continually on the deck,
                     apparently watching for the sledge that preceded his own. Yet, although <tei-pb n="[1.32 - page breaks after 'un-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/32.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     unhappy, he is not so utterly occupied by his own misery, but that he interests
                     himself deeply in the employments of others. He has asked me many questions
                     concerning my design; and I have related my little history frankly to him. He
                     appeared pleased with the confidence, and suggested several alterations in my
                     plan, which I shall find exceedingly useful. There is no pedantry in his
                     manner; but all he does appears to spring solely from the interest he
                     instinctively takes in the welfare of those who surround him. He is often
                     overcome by gloom, and then he sits by himself, and tries to overcome all that
                     is sullen or unsocial in his humour. These paroxysms pass from him like a cloud
                     from before the sun, though his dejection never leaves him. I have endeavoured
                     to win his confidence; and I trust that I have <tei-pb n="[1.33 - page breaks after 'suc-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/33.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     succeeded. One day I mentioned to him the desire I had always felt of finding a
                     friend who might sympathize with me, and direct me by his counsel. I said, I
                     did not belong to that class of men who are offended by advice. <tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am self-educated, and perhaps I hardly rely sufficiently
                        upon my own powers. I wish therefore that my companion should be wiser and
                        more experienced than myself, to confirm and support me; nor have I believed
                        it impossible to find a true friend."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I agree with you,"</tei-said> replied the stranger, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"in believing that friendship is not only a desirable, but a
                        possible acquisition. I once had a friend, the most noble of human
                        creatures, and am entitled, therefore, to judge respecting friendship. You
                        have hope, and the world before you, and have no cause for despair. But I—I
                        have lost <tei-pb n="[1.34]" facs="pageImages/vol1/34.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> every thing, and
                        cannot begin life anew."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As he said this, his countenance became expressive of a calm settled grief,
                     that touched me to the heart. But he was silent, and presently retired to his
                     cabin.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Even broken in spirit as he is, no one can feel more deeply than he does the
                     beauties of nature. The starry sky, the sea, and every sight afforded by these
                     wonderful regions, seems still to have the power of elevating his soul from
                     earth. Such a man has a double existence: he may suffer misery, and be
                     overwhelmed by disappointments; yet when he has retired into himself, he will
                     be like a celestial spirit, that has a halo around him, within whose circle no
                     grief or folly ventures.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Will you laugh at the enthusiasm I express concerning this divine <tei-pb n="[1.35 - page breaks after 'wan-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/35.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     wanderer? If you do, you must have certainly lost that simplicity which was
                     once your characteristic charm. Yet, if you will, smile at the warmth of my
                     expressions, while I find every day new causes for repeating them.</tei-p>







               </tei-div>

















               <tei-div data-origname="div">


                  <tei-opener data-origname="opener">
                     <tei-dateline data-origname="dateline">August 19th, 17--</tei-dateline>. </tei-opener>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"> Yesterday the stranger said to me, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You may easily
                        perceive, Captain <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Walton</tei-persName>, that I have suffered great
                        and unparalleled misfortunes. I had determined, once, that the memory of
                        these evils should die with me; but you have won me to alter my
                        determination. You seek for knowledge and wisdom, as I once did; and I
                        ardently hope that the gratification of your wishes may not be a serpent to
                        sting you, as mine has been. I do not know that the relation of my
                        misfortunes will be useful to you, yet, if you are inclined, <tei-pb n="[1.36]" facs="pageImages/vol1/36.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="Rime_of_the_Ancient_Mariner_" corresp="Rime_of_the_Acient_Mariner" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> listen to my tale </tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="Rime_of_the_Ancient_Mariner" id="Rime_of_the_Ancient_Mariner" target="Rime_of_the_Ancient_Mariner_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                           <tei-graphic url="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/c/coleridge/samuel_taylor/rime/plates/plate02.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> This is a reference to Samuel
                           Taylor Coleridge’s 1798 poem, <tei-ref target="https://rpo.library.utoronto.ca/poems/rime-ancient-mariner-text-1834" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                              <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Rime of the Ancient Mariner</tei-hi></tei-ref>. Coleridge’s
                           most famous poem is a tale narrated by an ancient sailor returned from a
                           long, ambitious journey during which, having shot and killed an
                           albatross, all other members of the crew die and the mariner is cursed.
                           The poem foregrounds the act of storytelling; the mariner with his <tei-ref target="https://rpo.library.utoronto.ca/poems/rime-ancient-mariner-text-1834" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"strange power of speech" (587)</tei-ref> is compelled to tell his story,
                           and others, due to its fantastical nature, are compelled to pay
                           attention. The 1876 illustration above, via <tei-ref target="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/c/coleridge/samuel_taylor/rime/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the University of Adelaide</tei-ref>, depicts the Ancient Mariner telling
                           his tale to the Wedding Guest, who "cannot chuse but to hear" (18). To
                           learn more about Coleridge’s poem, <tei-ref target="http://ec2-52-90-79-236.compute-1.amazonaws.com/editions/LB/html/Lb98-b.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">published as the opening poem in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Lyrical Ballads
                              </tei-hi></tei-ref>, read <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/romantics-and-victorians/articles/an-introduction-to-the-rime-of-the-ancient-mariner" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Seamus Perry’s introduction at the British Library</tei-ref>. </tei-note>. I
                        believe that the strange incidents connected with it will afford a view of
                        nature, which may enlarge your faculties and understanding. You will hear of
                        powers and occurrences, such as you have been accustomed to believe
                        impossible: but I do not doubt that my tale conveys in its series internal
                        evidence of the truth of the events of which it is composed."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">You may easily conceive that I was much gratified by the offered communication;
                     yet I could not endure that he should renew his grief by a recital of his
                     misfortunes. I felt the greatest eagerness to hear the promised narrative,
                     partly from curiosity, and partly from a strong desire to ameliorate his fate,
                     if it were in my power. I expressed these feelings in my answer.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I thank you,"</tei-said> he replied, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"for
                           <tei-pb n="[1.37]" facs="pageImages/vol1/37.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> your sympathy, but it is
                        useless; my fate is nearly fulfilled. I wait but for one event, and then I
                        shall repose in peace. I understand your feeling,"</tei-said> continued he,
                     perceiving that I wished to interrupt him; <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"but you are
                        mistaken, my friend, if thus you will allow me to name you; nothing can
                        alter my destiny: listen to my history, and you will perceive how
                        irrevocably it is determined."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He then told me, that he would commence his narrative the next day when I
                     should be at leisure. This promise drew from me the warmest thanks. I have
                     resolved every night, when I am not engaged, to record, as nearly as possible
                     in his own words, what he has related during the day. If I should be engaged, I
                     will at least make notes. This manuscript will doubtless afford you the
                     greatest pleasure: but to me, <tei-pb n="[1.38]" facs="pageImages/vol1/38.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     who know him, and who hear it from his own lips, with what interest and
                     sympathy shall I read it in some future day!</tei-p>


               </tei-div>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="1.1" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[1.39]" facs="pageImages/vol1/39.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter I</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">I AM by birth a Genevese; and my family is one of the most
                     distinguished of that republic. My ancestors had been for many years
                     counsellors and syndics; and my father had filled several public situations
                     with honour and reputation. He was respected by all who knew him for his
                     integrity and indefatigable attention to public business. He passed his younger
                     days perpetually occupied by the affairs of <tei-pb n="[1.40]" facs="pageImages/vol1/40.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> his country; and it was not until the
                     decline of life that he thought of marrying, and bestowing on the state sons
                     who might carry his virtues and his name down to posterity.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As the circumstances of his marriage illustrate his character, I cannot refrain
                     from relating them. One of his most intimate friends was a merchant, who, from
                     a flourishing state, fell, through numerous mischances, into poverty. This man,
                     whose name was <tei-pb n="[1.41 - page breaks after 'Beau-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/41.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beaufort</tei-persName>, was of a proud and unbending disposition, and
                     could not bear to live in poverty and oblivion in the same country where he had
                     formerly been distinguished for his rank and magnificence. Having paid his
                     debts, therefore, in the most honourable manner, he retreated with his daughter
                     to the town of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007280" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Lucerne</tei-placeName>, where
                     he lived unknown and in wretchedness. My father loved
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beaufort</tei-persName> with the truest friendship, and was deeply
                     grieved by his retreat in these unfortunate circumstances. He grieved also for
                     the loss of his society, and resolved to seek him out and endeavour to persuade
                     him to begin the world again through his credit and assistance.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beaufort</tei-persName> had taken effectual measures to conceal himself;
                     and it was ten months before my father discovered his abode. Overjoyed at this
                     discovery, he hastened to the house, which was situated in a mean street, near
                     the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1129085" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Reuss</tei-placeName>. But when he entered,
                     misery and despair alone welcomed him. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beaufort</tei-persName> had saved
                     but a very small sum of money from the wreck of his fortunes; but it was
                     sufficient to provide him with sustenance for some months, and in the meantime
                     he hoped to procure some respectable employment in a <tei-pb n="[1.42 - page breaks after 'mer-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/42.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     merchant's house. The interval was consequently spent in inaction; his grief
                     only became more deep and rankling, when he had leisure for reflection; and at
                     length it took so fast hold of his mind, that at the end of three months he lay
                     on a bed of sickness, incapable of any exertion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">His daughter attended him with the greatest tenderness; but she saw with
                     despair that their little fund was rapidly decreasing, and that there was no
                     other prospect of support. But <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Caroline Beaufort</tei-persName> possessed
                     a mind of an uncommon mould; and her courage rose to support her in her
                     adversity. She procured <tei-ref target="Plain_work_" corresp="Plain_work" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">plain
                        work</tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Plain_work" id="Plain_work" target="Plain_work_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">"Plain work" here refers to sewing and needlework that
                        is "plain," as opposed to "fancy." Caroline Beaufort, however, is also
                        making money by taking orders for piece work, which refers to any work paid
                        for "by the piece" or according to what is produced, like modern factory
                        work. </tei-note>; she plaited straw; and by various means contrived to earn a
                     pittance scarcely sufficient to support life.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Several months passed in this manner. Her father grew worse; her time <tei-pb n="[1.43]" facs="pageImages/vol1/43.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> was more entirely occupied in
                     attending him; her means of subsistence decreased; and in the tenth month her
                     father died in her arms, leaving her an orphan and a beggar. This last blow
                     overcame her; and she knelt by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Beaufort</tei-persName>'s coffin, weeping
                     bitterly, when my father entered the chamber. He came like a protecting spirit
                     to the poor girl, who committed herself to his care, and after the interment of
                     his friend he conducted her to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, and placed her under the protection of a relation. Two
                     years after this event <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Caroline</tei-persName> became his wife.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When my father became a husband and a parent, he found his time so occupied by
                     the duties of his new situation, that he relinquished many of his public
                     employments, and devoted himself to the education of his children. Of these I
                     was the eldest, and the destined <tei-pb n="[1.44 - page breaks after 'suc-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/44.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> successor to all his labours and utility. No
                     creature could have more tender parents than mine. My improvement and health
                     were their constant care, especially as I remained for several years their only
                     child. But before I continue my narrative, I must record an incident which took
                     place when I was four years of age.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father had a sister, whom he tenderly loved, and who had married early in
                     life an Italian gentleman. Soon after her marriage, she had accompanied her
                     husband into his native country, and for some years my father had very little
                     communication with her. About the time I mentioned she died; and a few months
                     afterwards he received a letter from her husband, acquainting him with his
                     intention of marrying an Italian lady, and requesting my father to take charge
                     of the <tei-pb n="[1.45 - page breaks after 'in-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/45.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     infant <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, the only child of his deceased sister.
                        <tei-said who="#brotherinlaw" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"It is my wish,"</tei-said> he said, <tei-said who="#brotherinlaw" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"that you should consider her as your own daughter, and
                        educate her thus. Her mother's fortune is secured to her, the documents of
                        which I will commit to your keeping. Reflect upon this proposition; and
                        decide whether you would prefer educating your niece yourself to her being
                        brought up by a stepmother."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father did not hesitate, and immediately went to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000080" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Italy</tei-placeName>, that he might accompany the little
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> to her future home. I have often heard my
                     mother say, that she was at that time the most beautiful child she had ever
                     seen, and shewed signs even then of a gentle and affectionate disposition.
                     These indications, and a desire to bind as closely as possible the ties of
                     domestic love, determined my mother to consider <tei-pb n="[1.46]" facs="pageImages/vol1/46.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName><tei-ref target="cousin_marriage_" corresp="cousin_marriage" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> as my future wife </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="cousin_marriage" id="cousin_marriage" target="cousin_marriage_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Marriage between cousins was a common practice in
                        history, often deployed to maintain family property and wealth. Read more
                        about marriage between cousins in Adam Kuper’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Incest and
                           Influence</tei-hi> especially the <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt13x0dq7.13" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Coda</tei-ref>, or his
                        article in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Past and Present</tei-hi> "<tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/3600719" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Incest, Cousin Marriage, and
                           the Origin of the Human Sciences in Nineteenth-Century England</tei-ref>." In
                        the 1818 edition of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, Elizabeth Lavenza,
                        is Victor’s first cousin on his father’s side; however, in the 2nd edition
                        of 1831, Mary Shelley revises this plot point to make Elizabeth an unknown
                        orphan and no longer related to the Frankensteins. She is instead rescued by
                        Victor Frankenstein’s mother. To learn more of Mary Shelley’s revisions
                        between the first and second editions see the annotation linked to the
                        publication date in the Preface of the novel, or head to Dana Wheeles’ Juxta
                        Commons <tei-ref target="http://juxtacommons.org/shares/Nme50n" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">comparison</tei-ref>
                        of the 1818 and 1831 editions of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>.
                     </tei-note>; a design which she never found reason to repent.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">From this time <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth Lavenza</tei-persName> became my playfellow,
                     and, as we grew older, my friend. She was docile and good tempered, yet gay and
                     playful as a summer insect. Although she was lively and animated, her feelings
                     were strong and deep, and her disposition uncommonly affectionate. No one could
                     better enjoy liberty, yet no one could submit with more grace than she did to
                     constraint and caprice. Her imagination was luxuriant, yet her capability of
                     application was great. Her person was the image of her mind; her hazel eyes,
                     although as lively as a bird's, possessed an attractive softness. Her figure
                     was light and airy; and, though capable of enduring great fatigue, she appeared
                     the most fragile creature in the world. While I <tei-pb n="[1.47 - page breaks after 'ad-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/47.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> admired
                     her understanding and fancy, I loved to tend on her, as I should on a favourite
                     animal; and I never saw so much grace both of person and mind united to so
                     little pretension.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Every one adored <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. If the servants had any
                     request to make, it was always through her intercession. We were strangers to
                     any species of disunion and dispute; for although there was a great
                     dissimilitude in our characters, there was an harmony in that very
                     dissimilitude. I was more calm and philosophical than my companion; yet my
                     temper was not so yielding. My application was of longer endurance; but it was
                     not so severe whilst it endured. I delighted in investigating the facts
                     relative to the actual world; she busied herself in following the aërial
                     creations of the poets. The world was to me a secret, which I desired to <tei-pb n="[1.48]" facs="pageImages/vol1/48.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> discover; to her it was a
                     vacancy, which she sought to people with imaginations of her own.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My brothers were considerably younger than myself; but I had a friend in one of
                     my schoolfellows, who compensated for this deficiency. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry
                        Clerval</tei-persName> was the son of a merchant of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, an intimate friend of my father. He was a
                     boy of singular talent and <tei-ref target="fancy_" corresp="fancy" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> fancy </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="fancy" id="fancy" target="fancy_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Fancy and imaginagion are important concepts in that shifted in meaning
                        througout the eighteenth century, being associated with mental creativity
                        and wit. For William Wordsworth, fancy is, like the imagination, a force for
                        association and creation; in his Preface of 1815, he writes that fancy is
                        "capricious as the accidents of things... Fancy depends upon the rapidity
                        and profusion with which she scatters her thoughts and images" (<tei-ref target="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page%3APoems_by_William_Wordsworth_(1815)_Volume_1.djvu/42" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">xxxiv</tei-ref>-<tei-ref target="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page:Poems_by_William_Wordsworth_(1815)_Volume_1.djvu/43" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">xxxv</tei-ref>). Fancy is more "given to quicken and to beguile the temporal
                        part of our nature," while "Imagination [works] to incite and to support the
                        eternal" (<tei-ref target="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page%3APoems_by_William_Wordsworth_(1815)_Volume_1.djvu/43" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">xxxv</tei-ref>). For Coleridge, fancy is inferior to imagination, lighter,
                        and is more like wit in terms of its power to make connections between
                        ideas; Coleridge explores the distinctions between primary imagination,
                        secondary imagination, and fancy in Book 13 of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Biographia
                           Literaria</tei-hi> (1817). For a good general historical overview, <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=mkcrDwAAQBAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">see <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Fancy and Imagination</tei-hi> (1969) by R. L. Brett</tei-ref>.
                     </tei-note>. I remember, when he was nine years old, he wrote a fairy tale, which
                     was the delight and amazement of all his companions. His favourite study
                     consisted in books of<tei-ref target="chivalric_romance_" corresp="chivalric_romance" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> chivalry and romance </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="chivalric_romance" id="chivalric_romance" target="chivalric_romance_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Chivalric romance, <tei-ref target="http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095608946" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">according Oxford Reference</tei-ref>, is a genre of literature that began in
                        Medieval Europe and flourished into the 17th century. Chivalric romances,
                        usually written in poetic verse, tell stories of the great deeds of
                        knight-errantry. Chivalry, in particular, refers to "an idealized code of
                        civilized behaviour that combines loyalty, honour, and courtly love." These
                        sorts of stories were often called "romans," from which the word "romance"
                        derives. Formally loose or episodic in structure, heroic romances written in
                        later periods "deliberately eschew[ed] contemporaneity"; their plots
                        featured courtly lovers engaged in "heroic stories of love and war in a
                        remote and idealized past" (1046), as Shellinger states in the <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=FPdRAwAAQBAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Encyclopedia of the Novel</tei-hi></tei-ref>. Some representative heroic
                        romances include <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Euphues</tei-hi> by John Lyly, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">L'Astrée</tei-hi> by Honore d'Urfé, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Artamène</tei-hi> by Madame de Scudéry, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Orlando
                           Furioso</tei-hi> by Ludovico Ariosto, and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Amadís de
                           Gaula</tei-hi> by Garci Rodríguez de Montalvo. Romance of this sort declined
                        in popularity during the 18th century, but during the Romantic period--so
                        named by later scholars for its turn toward these very romantic ideals of
                        individualism, heroism, and the imagination--such stories were revived. For
                        a fuller discussion of the origins and meaning of the word "romantic" see
                           <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=zpY4nX4fUvIC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Michael
                           Ferber’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Romanticism: A Very Short Introduction</tei-hi>
                           (3-7)</tei-ref>, and for a broader overview of the medieval genre, see <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/art/romance-literature-and-performance" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the Encyclopedia Britannica’s entry on Romance</tei-ref>. </tei-note>; and when
                     very young, I can remember, that we used to act plays composed by him out of
                     these favourite books, the principal characters of which were<tei-ref target="Orlando_Furioso_" corresp="Orlando_Furioso" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Orlando</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Orlando_Furioso" id="Orlando_Furioso" target="Orlando_Furioso_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/84/Jean_Auguste_Dominique_Ingres_-_Roger_Delivering_Angelica.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/orl/index.htm" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Orlando
                              Furioso</tei-ref></tei-hi> is an epic poem published in 1532 by the Italian
                        poet Ludovico Arisoto, and an example of the "books of chivalry and romance"
                        that Clerval enjoys. Set in the 8th century, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Orlando
                           Furioso</tei-hi> tells the story of the protagonist Orlando, leader of the
                        Christian knights, fighting the so-called <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Saracen" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Saracens</tei-ref> for
                        control of Europe during the reign of Charlemagne (Charles I). As the first
                        lines of the poem point out, its subject is "Dames, knights, and arms, and
                        love! The deeds that spring / From courteous minds, and venturous feats"
                        (1.1-2). The chivalric romance combines realism and fantasy throughout its
                        46 cantos. <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/ariostos-orlando-furioso-in-english-1591" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">First published in English translation in 1591, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Orlando Furioso</tei-hi> is a source for Shakespeare’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Much Ado about Nothing</tei-hi>.</tei-ref> While the story is episodic, one
                        of the most important plots focuses on Orlando’s dangerous passion for the
                        pagan princess Angelica, which is the cause of his titular madness. The
                        image above, via Wikimedia Commons, shows <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"> Ruggiero
                           Rescuing Angelica</tei-hi> (1818-1819), painted by Jean Auguste Domininque
                        Ingres. Ariosto’s tale was also <tei-ref target="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/d/dore/gustave/orlando/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">famously
                           illustrated by the late nineteenth-century artist Gustave Doré</tei-ref>.
                        </tei-note>,<tei-ref target="Robin_Hood_" corresp="Robin_Hood" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n79069719" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type"> Robin Hood </tei-persName></tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Robin_Hood" id="Robin_Hood" target="Robin_Hood_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f7/Richard_The_Lionheart_-_Robinhood.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Robin Hood is a legendary outlaw who stole from the rich
                        to give to the poor. Numerous ballads have been written about the character,
                        who may have been based on a <tei-ref target="https://www.history.com/topics/british-history/robin-hood" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">real
                           person</tei-ref>. Robin Hood lived the true heroic code, protecting women,
                        supporting the lowly, and remained faithful to the monarch. Read more about
                        Robin Hood in Howard Pyle’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://www.literaturepage.com/read/robinhood.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Merry
                              Adventures of Robin Hood</tei-ref></tei-hi>, one of the more popular
                        adaptations of the legend written in 1883. The photograph above, <tei-ref target="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Richard_The_Lionheart_-_Robinhood.jpg" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">by RichardUK2014 via Wikimedia Commons</tei-ref>, shows a relief plaque
                        outside Nottingham Castle ostensibly illustrating King Richard the Lionheart
                        marrying Robin Hood and Maid Marian. </tei-note>,<tei-ref target="Amadis_de_Gaula_" corresp="Amadis_de_Gaula" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Amadis</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Amadis_de_Gaula" id="Amadis_de_Gaula" target="Amadis_de_Gaula_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://cdn.britannica.com/668x448/59/143359-004-9F9322AE.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Amadis-of-Gaul" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Amadís de
                           Gaula</tei-ref> is a prose romance composed in Spain or Portugal in the 13th
                        or 14th century (title page of the 1533 Spanish edition by Olaf Simons
                        pictured above). The story’s protagonist is Amadís, the bravest and most
                        just of knights, who falls in love with Oriana, the daughter of Lisuarte,
                        the king of England. Amadís is an orphan who was separated from his English
                        parents at birth, but through this hardship becomes a better man. Arthurian
                        in nature, the story is one of chivalry, though more chaste and romanticized
                        than the Celtic tales of knights it was most likely based on. According to
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.rc.umd.edu/editions/frankenstein/V1notes/amadis" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Romantic Circles</tei-ref>, Mary Shelley was reading Robert Southey’s
                        translation of the poem while writing <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>.
                        The full text of the <tei-ref target="https://www.wdl.org/en/item/7330/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">1520
                           edition</tei-ref> printed by Juan Cromberger can be found online at the
                        National Library of Spain. </tei-note>, and <tei-ref target="St._George_" corresp="St._George" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">St. George</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="St._George" id="St._George" target="St._George_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://s3.amazonaws.com/lic-assets-staging/Shelley/notes/E10529.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> St. George, a converted Roman soldier martyred for his
                        newfound Christian faith, is often depicted slaying a dragon, a symbolic
                        rendering of the triumph of Christianity over evil. Not only is St. George
                        the patron saint of England, but by the 14th century, he had been declared
                        both the patron saint and protector of the <tei-ref target="https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/6849528" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">royal family</tei-ref>. For
                        more information on St. George, see <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://www.pitt.edu/~dash/stgeorge2.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Reliques of Ancient
                              English Poetry</tei-ref></tei-hi> collected by Thomas Percy and edited by D.L.
                        Ashliman. Pictured above is Saint George and the Dragon (c. 1432) by Rogier
                        van Der Weyden from the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.
                     </tei-note>.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">No youth could have passed more <tei-pb n="[1.49]" facs="pageImages/vol1/49.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     happily than mine. My parents were indulgent, and my companions amiable. Our
                     studies were never forced; and by some means we always had an end placed in
                     view, which excited us to ardour in the prosecution of them. It was by this
                     method, and not by emulation, that we were urged to application.
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> was not incited to apply herself to drawing,
                     that her companions might not outstrip her; but through the desire of pleasing
                     her aunt, by the representation of some favourite scene done by her own hand.
                     We learned Latin and English, that we might read the writings in those
                     languages; and so far from study being made odious to us through punishment, we
                     loved application, and our amusements would have been the labours of other
                     children. Perhaps we did not read so many books, or learn languages so <tei-pb n="[1.50]" facs="pageImages/vol1/50.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> quickly, as those who are
                     disciplined according to the ordinary methods; but what we learned was
                     impressed the more deeply on our memories.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In this description of our domestic circle I include <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry
                        Clerval</tei-persName>; for he was constantly with us. He went to school with
                     me, and generally passed the afternoon at our house: for being an only child,
                     and destitute of companions at home, his father was well pleased that he should
                     find associates at our house; and we were never completely happy when
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> was absent.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I feel pleasure in dwelling on the recollections of childhood, before
                     misfortune had tainted my mind, and changed its bright visions of extensive
                     usefulness into gloomy and narrow reflections upon self. But, in drawing the
                     picture of my early days, I must not omit to record those events which led, by
                        <tei-pb n="[1.51 - page breaks after 'in-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/51.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     insensible steps to my after tale of misery: for when I would account to myself
                     for the birth of that passion, which afterwards ruled my destiny, I find it
                     arise, like a mountain river, from ignoble and almost forgotten sources; but,
                     swelling as it proceeded, it became the torrent which, in its course, has swept
                     away all my hopes and joys.</tei-p>
