                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-ref target="Natural_Philosophy_" corresp="Natural_Philosophy" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">Natural
                        philosophy</tei-ref><tei-note xml:id="Natural_Philosophy" id="Natural_Philosophy" target="Natural_Philosophy_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-ref target="https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/natphil-ren/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Natural
                           Philosophy</tei-ref> is the study of nature through a philosophical lens. The
                        two canonical discussions of natural philosophy occur in Aristotle’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/heavens.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">On the
                              Heavens, Meteorology</tei-ref></tei-hi>, and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/gener_corr.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">On
                              Generation and Corruption</tei-ref></tei-hi>. In the eighteenth century,
                        natural philosophy was a form of science with an emphasis on scientific
                        inquiry, but in the Romantic period, it was seen as a method of unifying
                        physical nature with the spiritual. As Michael Manson and Robert Scott
                        Stewart point out in <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/3685283" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Heroes and Hideousness: "Frankenstein" and Failed Unity</tei-ref>, natural
                        philosophy fueled the Romantic idea of the natural world as a giant
                        organism, in stark contrast to the Enlightenment, which saw the natural
                        world as more like a mechanical machine. For more information about natural
                        philosophy and its influence on <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, see
                        Patricia Fara’s "<tei-ref target="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.shpsa.2007.06.004" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Hidden depths: Halley, Hell and Other People</tei-ref>" or Rebecca Baumann’s
                           "<tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt22p7j32.11" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Mad
                           Science</tei-ref>." </tei-note> is the genius that has regulated my fate; I
                     desire therefore, in this narration, to state those facts which led to my
                     predilection for that science. When I was thirteen years of age, we all went on
                     a party of pleasure to the baths near <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1035867" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Thonon</tei-placeName>: the inclemency of the weather obliged us to remain a
                     day confined to the inn. In this house I chanced to find a volume of the works
                     of <tei-ref target="Cornelius_Agrippa_" corresp="Cornelius_Agrippa" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type"> Cornelius Agrippa</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Cornelius_Agrippa" id="Cornelius_Agrippa" target="Cornelius_Agrippa_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#NPD" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/46/Heinrich_Cornelius_Agrippa00.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Heinrich-Cornelius-Agrippa-von-Nettesheim" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Cornelius Agrippa (1486-1535)</tei-ref> was a German alchemist and scholar.
                        He studied both medicine and law but did not receive a degree in either. His
                        most well-known work is the three-volume De Occulta Philosophiae, a defense
                        of "hidden philosophy" or magic, drawing from alchemy, astrology, and
                        Kabbalah. A later work, De Incertitudine et Vanitate Scientiarum (<tei-ref target="https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo/A26566.0001.001?view=toc" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Of the Uncertainty and Vanity of the
                        Sciences</tei-hi></tei-ref>), attacks contemporary renaissance scientific theory and
                        practice. To read more about his philosophy see his intellectual biography
                        in the <tei-ref target="https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/agrippa-nettesheim/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy</tei-hi></tei-ref>. The
                        engraved portrait of Agrippa above, via Wikimedia Commons, is housed at the
                        U.S. National Library of Medicine. </tei-note>. I opened it with apathy; the
                     theory which he attempts to demonstrate, and the <tei-pb n="[1.52]" facs="pageImages/vol1/52.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> wonderful facts which he relates, soon
                     changed this feeling into enthusiasm. A new light seemed to dawn upon my mind;
                     and, bounding with joy, I communicated my discovery to my father. I cannot help
                     remarking here the many opportunities instructors possess of directing the
                     attention of their pupils to useful knowledge, which they utterly neglect. My
                     father looked carelessly at the title-page of my book, and said, <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Ah! <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Cornelius
                           Agrippa</tei-persName>! My dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, do not waste
                        your time upon this; it is sad trash."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">If, instead of this remark, my father had taken the pains to explain to me,
                     that the principles of <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Agrippa</tei-persName> had been entirely exploded, and that a modern system of
                     science had been introduced, which possessed much greater powers than the
                     ancient, because the powers of the latter were <tei-ref target="Chimerical_" corresp="Chimerical" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">chimerical </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Chimerical" id="Chimerical" target="Chimerical_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Ligozzi_%28Una_quimera%29.jpg/800px-Ligozzi_%28Una_quimera%29.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Chimeric or chimerical was defined by
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/news/samuel-johnson-google-doodle-who-was-he-dictionary-james-boswell-writer-publisher-wit-a7952616.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Samuel Johnson</tei-ref> in his <tei-ref target="http://www.bl.uk/learning/langlit/dic/johnson/1755johnsonsdictionary.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">1755 <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Dictionary of the English Language</tei-hi></tei-ref> as
                           "<tei-ref target="https://archive.org/stream/dictionaryofengl01johnuoft#page/n373/mode/2up" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">A vain and wild fancy, as remote from reality as the existence of the
                           poetical <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Chimera</tei-hi>, a monster feigned to have the
                           head of a lion, the belly of a goat, and the tail of a dragon.</tei-ref>" The
                        image here is a 1590–1610 drawing of a chimera attributed to Jacopo Ligozzi
                        (1547–1627) hosted on Wikimedia Commons. </tei-note> , while <tei-pb n="[1.53]" facs="pageImages/vol1/53.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> those of the former were real and practical;
                     under such circumstances, I should certainly have thrown <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Agrippa</tei-persName> aside, and, with my imagination warmed as
                     it was, should probably have applied myself to the more rational theory of
                     chemistry which has resulted from modern discoveries. It is even possible, that
                     the train of my ideas would never have received the fatal impulse that led to
                     my ruin. But the cursory glance my father had taken of my volume by no means
                     assured me that he was acquainted with its contents; and I continued to read
                     with the greatest avidity.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When I returned home, my first care was to procure the whole works of this
                     author, and afterwards of <tei-ref target="Paracelsus_" corresp="Paracelsus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"><tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80120959" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Paracelsus</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Paracelsus" id="Paracelsus" target="Paracelsus_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Paracelsus.jpg/800px-Paracelsus.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Paracelsus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Paracelsus</tei-ref>, the adopted name of Philippus Aureolus Theophrastus
                        Bombastus von Hohenheim (1490-1541), was Swiss physician, alchemist, and
                        astrologer of the German Renaissance. He studied medicine and homeopathic
                        cures for disease, as well as alchemy and metals. A free thinker, he
                        believed in learning from more than just academics, and stressed experience
                        as a model for learning. To learn more about Paracelsus’ scientific and
                        medical advancements in the medieval ages see Joseph Borzelleca’s "<tei-ref target="https://academic.oup.com/toxsci/article/53/1/2/1673334" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Paracelsus: Herald of Modern Toxicology</tei-ref>". Pictured here is <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Paracelsus</tei-hi> by Quentin Matsys from the Musée du Louvre,
                        via Wikimedia Commons. </tei-note> and <tei-ref target="Albertus_Magnus_" corresp="Albertus_Magnus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n81007973" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Albertus Magnus</tei-persName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Albertus_Magnus" id="Albertus_Magnus" target="Albertus_Magnus_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Vincenzo_onofri%2C_sant%27alberto_magno%2C_1493.JPG/800px-Vincenzo_onofri%2C_sant%27alberto_magno%2C_1493.JPG" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/albert-great/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Albertus
                           Magnus</tei-ref> (c. 1200-1280), teacher of St. Thomas Aquinas, was a German
                        Catholic Dominican Friar. He was canonized a saint in 1931 (despite
                        contemporaries considering him neglectful of theology for sorcery), has been
                        referred to as the one of the greatest German philosophers and theologians
                        of the Middle Ages, and is distinguished as one of the 36 Doctors for the
                        Catholic Church. A student of many disciplines, influenced by Aristotle, and
                        a prolific writer, he composed <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Saint-Albertus-Magnus" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">38
                           volumes</tei-ref> encompassing many topics such as logic, theology, botany,
                        geography, astronomy, astrology, mineralogy, alchemy, zoology, physiology,
                        phrenology, justice, and law. Albertus’ work represents the entire body of
                        theological and philosophical knowledge during his time. His influence on
                        natural science is most important as he brought Aristotelian knowledge of
                        nature to the forefront as well as increasing knowledge through his
                        experiments promoting the idea that Christian faith and experimental science
                        were not hostile to one another. For more information on the alchemical
                        sciences, see <tei-ref target="https://library.brown.edu/exhibit/exhibits/show/evolution-of-chemistry/the-processes-of-alchemy/alchemy-as-theory--the-search-" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the Hay Library exhibit on the evolution of modern chemistry</tei-ref> and
                        the archived Getty Library colloquium on the <tei-ref target="http://www.getty.edu/research/exhibitions_events/events/alchemy/index.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Art of Alchemy."</tei-ref> To explore more of Albertus Magnus’ works see
                        the Beinecke Library’s digital edition of his <tei-ref target="https://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3441262" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Alchemical Miscellany."</tei-ref> For more information on the role of
                        alchemy and science in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, see <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=nkDbgXV9YnwC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Alan Rauch’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Useful Knowledge: The Victorians, Morality, and the
                              March of Intellect</tei-hi> (2001)</tei-ref>, especially chapter 3, "The
                        Monstrous Body of Knowledge in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>" Pictured
                        above is Vincenzo Onofri’s bust of Sant’ Alberto Magno (c. 1493), via
                        Wikimedia Commons. </tei-note>. I read and studied the wild fancies of these
                     writers with delight; they appeared to me <tei-pb n="[1.54 - page breaks after 'trea-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/54.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     treasures known to few beside myself; and although I have often wished to
                     communicate these secret stores of knowledge to my father, yet his indefinite
                     censure of my favourite <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Agrippa</tei-persName> always withheld me. I disclosed my discoveries to
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, therefore, under a promise of strict
                     secrecy; but she did not interest herself in the subject, and I was left by her
                     to pursue my studies alone.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It may appear very strange, that a disciple of <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n81007973" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Albertus Magnus</tei-persName> should arise in the eighteenth
                     century; but our family was not scientifical, and I had not attended any of the
                     lectures given at the schools of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. My dreams were therefore undisturbed by reality; and I
                     entered with the greatest diligence into the search of the <tei-ref target="Philosophers_Stone_" corresp="Philosophers_Stone" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> philosopher's
                        stone </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Philosophers_Stone" id="Philosophers_Stone" target="Philosophers_Stone_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">In the study of alchemy, "<tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophers-stone" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"the
                           Philosopher’s Stone</tei-ref>" is sometimes referred to as the 5th element
                        (the other four being earth, water, fire, and air). The Stone was understood
                        to turn base metals into gold, and it was thought to be able to create an
                        elixir of life. The Stone has been referenced throughout literature from the
                        Middle Ages to modern popular culture, from Geoffrey Chaucer’s "Yeoman’s
                        Tale" to J.K. Rowling’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Harry Potter</tei-hi>. Prior to the
                        conception of the Creature, Victor's fascination with this stone and its
                        apparent abilities highlights his willingness to step out of the human realm
                        and into the realm of the divine by "penetrating the secrets of nature"
                        (Shelley 38). Outside of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, much has been
                        written about alchemy and the Philosopher’s Stone, but Stanton Linden’s <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt130hpvq.13" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Darke Hierogliphicks: Alchemy in English Literature from Chaucer to
                              the Restoration</tei-hi></tei-ref> gives an overview of the history of alchemy
                        in literature. To read a book of alchemy from 1754, see <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=5eQvAAAAYAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Life of the Truly Eminent and Learned Hugo Grotius</tei-hi></tei-ref>, by
                        M. de Burigny. </tei-note> and the elixir of life. But the latter obtained my
                        <tei-pb n="[1.55 - page breaks after 'undi-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/55.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     undivided attention: wealth was an inferior object; but what glory would attend
                     the discovery, if I could banish disease from the human frame, and render man
                     invulnerable to any but a violent death!</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Nor were these my only visions. The raising of ghosts or devils was a promise
                     liberally accorded by my favourite authors, the fulfillment of which I most
                     eagerly sought; and if my incantations were always unsuccessful, I attributed
                     the failure rather to my own inexperience and mistake than to a want of skill
                     or fidelity in my instructors.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The natural phænomena that take place every day before our eyes did not escape
                     my examinations. Distillation, and <tei-ref target="Economy_of_Vegetation_" corresp="Economy_of_Vegetation" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> the wonderful effects of steam </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Economy_of_Vegetation" id="Economy_of_Vegetation" target="Economy_of_Vegetation_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">This is a direct reference to Erasmus
                        Darwin’s poem, the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=j7hEAAAAYAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Economy of
                              Vegetation</tei-ref></tei-hi>, which explores the new technological
                        innovations and scientific discoveries of the early nineteenth century. In
                        Darwin’s paean to "unconquer’d steam!" (289), he imagines it "[dragging] the
                        slow barge, or [driving] the rapid car;/ Or on wide-waving wings…[bearing]/
                        The flying-chariot through the fields of air" (290-292). His poems were
                        helpful to the Romantics’ exploration of science as he combined poetry, the
                        epitome of feeling, with scientific ideas. To see more of Darwin’s influence
                        on the Romantics, see D. King-Hele’s book, <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=ZkGvCwAAQBAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Erasmus Darwin and the Romantic Poets</tei-hi></tei-ref>.</tei-note>, processes
                     of which my favourite authors were utterly ignorant, excited my astonishment;
                     but my utmost wonder was <tei-pb n="[1.56]" facs="pageImages/vol1/56.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-ref target="Boyles_Law_" corresp="Boyles_Law" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> engaged by some experiments on
                        an air-pump </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Boyles_Law" id="Boyles_Law" target="Boyles_Law_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/An_Experiment_on_a_Bird_in_an_Air_Pump_by_Joseph_Wright_of_Derby%2C_1768.jpg/800px-An_Experiment_on_a_Bird_in_an_Air_Pump_by_Joseph_Wright_of_Derby%2C_1768.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.sciencehistory.org/historical-profile/robert-boyle" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Robert Boyle (1627-1691)</tei-ref>, the first modern chemist and originator
                        of <tei-ref target="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Boyle's%20law" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Boyle’s Law</tei-ref>--which describes the inversely proportional
                        relationship between the absolute pressure and volume of a gas--performed
                        experiments in the seventeenth century involving air-pumps, better known
                        today as vacuum pumps. Boyle’s pumps were created to his specific dimensions
                        by Robert Hooke (1635-1703) (also known for the bringing the use of
                        microscopes into the community of scientists). In his (1662) book, <tei-ref target="http://exhibits.library.yale.edu/document/8981" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">New Experiments Physico-Mechanicall, Touching the Spring of the Air,
                              and its Effects, (Made, for the Most Part, in a New Pneumatical
                              Engine)</tei-hi></tei-ref>, Boyle detailed all of his air-pump experiments,
                        most notably Experiment 41, in which he studied the reactions of animals to
                        a vacuum. In Experiment 41, Boyle placed birds, mice, and other small
                        creatures into the air pump and slowly removed the air to prove the
                        necessity of respiration. While watching a lark in one reiteration of the
                        experiment, he observed: "…the Bird for a while appear'd lively enough; but
                        upon a greater Exsuction of the Air, she began manifestly to droop and
                        appear sick, and very soon after was taken with as violent and irregular
                        Convulsions, as are wont to be observ'd in Poultry, when their heads are
                        wrung off: For the Bird threw her self over and over two or three times, and
                        dyed with her Breast upward, her Head downwards, and her Neck awry" (cite
                        page 98). These experiments intrigued the public. Joseph Wright’s
                        (1734-1797) oil paintings imagined these experiments as subjects of
                        middle-class, domestic education. To read more about Robert Boyle, see
                        Thomas Birch’s biography from 1772, <tei-ref target="https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_LqYrAQAAMAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The works of the Honourable Robert Boyle</tei-hi></tei-ref>.
                        Shelagh Stephenson’s (1955-) play <tei-ref target="https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/theatre-an-experiment-with-an-airpump-the-royal-exchange-manchester-whats-the-big-idea-1145615.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">An Experiment With an Air Pump</tei-hi></tei-ref>", a play
                        revolving around two overlapping plots 100 years apart which highlight the
                        lack of empathy scientific thought has over human emotions and affections.
                     </tei-note>, which I saw employed by a gentleman whom we were in the habit of
                     visiting.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The ignorance of the early philbosophers on these and several other points
                     served to decrease their credit with me: but I could not entirely throw them
                     aside, before some other system should occupy their place in my mind.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When I was about fifteen years old, we had retired to our house near <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8703247" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Belrive</tei-placeName>, when we witnessed a most
                     violent and terrible thunder-storm. It advanced from behind <tei-ref target="The_Swiss_Alps_" corresp="The_Swiss_Alps" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1109172" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type"> the mountains of Jura</tei-placeName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="The_Swiss_Alps" id="The_Swiss_Alps" target="The_Swiss_Alps_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d8/Francis_Towne_001.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>The Swiss Alps (including the Central
                        and the Bernese Alps) are a region in central Europe with expansive
                        mountains, considered both beautiful and dangerous, that span most the
                        southern and eastern area of Switzerland. The Jura are a range of mountains
                        in the northwest following the France-Switzerland border forming the
                        watersheds for both the Rhone and Rhine basins. These two ranges make up the
                        majority of the natural setting within the novel. Among the peaks named in
                        the novel are Mont Blanc (the highest), Mole, and Mont Saleve. Montanvert is
                        also part of the Alps, but is the eighteenth-century name for Mer de Glace,
                        a glacier on the Mont Blanc massif. <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/romantics-and-victorians/articles/landscape-and-the-sublime" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Romantic artists--including Percy Shelley, Coleridge, J.M.W. Turner, and
                           others--frequently visited, wrote about, and painted this sublime
                           landscape.</tei-ref> The image here shows landscape artist Francis Towne’s
                        (1739-1816) <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Arveyron River on the Mer de Glace</tei-hi>
                        (1781), via Wikimedia Commons. <tei-ref target="http://francistowne.ac.uk/collection/list-of-works/glacier-from-montanvert/page/16" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">See more works depicting the area described in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> in Richard Stephens’ Catalogue Raisonné of Francis
                           Towne.</tei-ref></tei-note>; and the thunder burst at once with frightful
                     loudness from various quarters of the heavens. I remained, while the storm
                     lasted, watching its progress with curiosity and delight. As I stood at the
                     door, on a sudden I beheld a stream of fire issue from an old and beautiful
                     oak, <tei-pb n="[1.57]" facs="pageImages/vol1/57.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> which stood about twenty
                     yards from our house; and so soon as the dazzling light vanished, the oak had
                     disappeared, and nothing remained but a blasted stump. When we visited it the
                     next morning, we found the tree shattered in a singular manner. It was not
                     splintered by the shock, but entirely reduced to thin ribbands of wood. I never
                     beheld anything so utterly destroyed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The catastrophe of this tree excited my extreme astonishment; and I eagerly
                     inquired of my father the nature and origin of thunder and lightning. He
                     replied, <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Electricity;"</tei-said> describing at the same time
                     the various effects of that power. <tei-ref target="Ben_Franklin_experiments_" corresp="Ben_Franklin_experiments" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> He constructed a small electrical
                        machine, and exhibited a few experiments; he made also a kite, with a wire
                        and string, which drew down that fluid from the clouds </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Ben_Franklin_experiments" id="Ben_Franklin_experiments" target="Ben_Franklin_experiments_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://static.scientificamerican.com/sciam/assets/media/promo/upload/miq611cart1.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> This is a direct allusion to
                        experiments performed by Benjamin Franklin and other scientists during the
                        eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Ben Franklin was a contemporary of Mary
                        Shelley’s parents, and he influenced the world of politics, culture, and
                        science. Well-known inventing bifocals, Franklin is also associated in the
                        popular imagination with his electrical experiments involving keys, storms,
                        and kites. Contrary to popular belief, Franklin did not discover
                        electricity, but he connected electrical conduits through substances like
                        water and metal, and he understood that electricity can be held and
                        discharged. Read more about his electrical experiment at <tei-ref target="https://www.fi.edu/benjamin-franklin/kite-key-experiment" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The
                           Franklin Institute</tei-ref>. Franklin’s experiments with electricity were
                        the precursor to Galvani’s and Volta’s experiments with electricity and
                        galvanism. These two scientists sought to prove that electricity could
                        animate deceased matter, namely frogs, but went so far as to momentarily
                        animate the bodies of beheaded criminals. To learn more about these
                        experiments, read Alan Brown’s "<tei-ref target="https://www.insidescience.org/news/science-made-frankenstein" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The
                           Science That Made Frankenstein</tei-ref>." This is not the first time
                        electrical experiments had been referenced in literature; Erasmus Darwin,
                        whose works are alluded to in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> often
                        referenced Franklin, in his <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Economy of Vegetation</tei-hi>.
                        Darwin describes Franklin as taming lightning through his invention of the
                        lightning rod, for instance: <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=j7hEAAAAYAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"-Led by the
                           phosphor-light, with daring tread/ Immortal Franklin sought the fiery
                           bed;/ Where, nursed in night, incumbent Tempest shrouds/ His embryon
                           Thunders in circumfluent clouds" (Canto 2.2 355-358).</tei-ref> To explore
                        more about Darwin, see Stephen Foster’s addition to <tei-ref target="http://www.victorianweb.org/science/edarwin/poetry.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the
                           Victorian Web</tei-ref>; to learn more about the science of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, see Sharon Ruskin’s <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/romantics-and-victorians/articles/the-science-of-life-and-death-in-mary-shelleys-frankenstein" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">article from the British Library</tei-ref>. The image used is a comic from
                        Dwayne Godwin and Jorge Cham hosted on Scientific American. </tei-note>.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This last stroke completed the <tei-pb n="[1.58 - page breaks after 'over-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/58.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> overthrow of <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Cornelius Agrippa</tei-persName>, <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n81007973" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Albertus Magnus</tei-persName>, and <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80120959" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Paracelsus</tei-persName>, who had so long reigned the lords of
                     my imagination. But by some fatality I did not feel inclined to commence the
                     study of any modern system; and this disinclination was influenced by the
                     following circumstance.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father expressed a wish that I should attend a course of lectures upon
                     natural philosophy, to which I cheerfully consented. Some accident prevented my
                     attending these lectures until the course was nearly finished. The lecture,
                     being therefore one of the last, was entirely incomprehensible to me. The
                     professor discoursed with the greatest fluency of potassium and boron, of
                     sulphates and oxyds, terms to which I could affix no idea; and I became
                     disgusted with the science of natural philosophy, although I still read <tei-pb n="[1.59]" facs="pageImages/vol1/59.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n79042075" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Pliny</tei-persName> and <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n50041361" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Buffon</tei-persName> with delight, authors, in my
                     estimation, of nearly equal interest and utility.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My occupations at this age were principally the mathematics, and most of the
                     branches of study appertaining to that science. I was busily employed in
                     learning languages; Latin was already familiar to me, and I began to read some
                     of the easiest Greek authors without the help of a lexicon. I also perfectly
                     understood English and German. This is the list of my accomplishments at the
                     age of seventeen; and you may conceive that my hours were fully employed in
                     acquiring and maintaining a knowledge of this various literature.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Another task also devolved upon me, when I became the instructor of my
                     brothers. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> was six years younger than myself, and
                     was my principal <tei-pb n="[1.60 - page breaks after 'pu']" facs="pageImages/vol1/60.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> pupil. He had been afflicted with ill health
                     from his infancy, through which <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> and I had been
                     his constant nurses: his disposition was gentle, but he was incapable of any
                     severe application. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>, the youngest of our family,
                     was yet an infant, and the most beautiful little fellow in the world; his
                     lively blue eyes, dimpled cheeks, and endearing manners, inspired the tenderest
                     affection.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Such was our domestic circle, from which care and pain seemed for ever
                     banished. My father directed our studies, and my mother partook of our
                     enjoyments. Neither of us possessed the slightest pre-eminence over the other;
                     the voice of command was never heard amongst us; but mutual affection engaged
                     us all to comply with and obey the slightest desire of each other.</tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>




            <tei-div n="1.2" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[1.61]" facs="pageImages/vol1/61.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter II</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">WHEN I had attained the age of seventeen, <tei-ref target="University_of_Ingolstadt_" corresp="University_of_Ingolstadt" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> my
                        parents resolved that I should become a student at the university of
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>
                     </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="University_of_Ingolstadt" id="University_of_Ingolstadt" target="University_of_Ingolstadt_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/80/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre-anatomique-Padoue.JPG" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Victor Frankenstein attends the <tei-ref target="http://knarf.english.upenn.edu/V1notes/univers.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">University
                           of Ingolstadt</tei-ref>, a university founded in 1472, known for its focus on
                        the natural sciences. The university had a massive chemistry laboratory and
                        one of the finest operating theatres at the time Frankenstein was written,
                        making it a perfect setting for his experiments. <tei-ref target="https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ingolstadt,+Germany/@48.7535159,11.2395665,11z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x479efe5188360abb:0xec5d7e2213748aea!8m2!3d48.7665351!4d11.4257541?shorturl=1" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Ingolstadt</tei-ref> is located in Germany, within the Free State of
                        Bavaria. In the eighteenth century, an <tei-ref target="http://knarf.english.upenn.edu/Places/ingolst.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">intellectual
                           movement</tei-ref> for the reconstruction of European society was centered in
                        the city. Mary Shelley would have been aware of this, and the significance
                        of the change of European society may have been the perfect historical
                        setting for a tale calling into question freedom, status, and autonomy. The
                        image here shows an Italian operating theatre built in the sixteenth century
                        to give an example of what the operating theatre may have looked like to
                        Victor Frankenstein. The image was taken by Kalibos and is hosted on
                        Wikimedia Commons. </tei-note>. I had hitherto attended the schools of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>; but my father
                     thought it necessary, for the completion of my education, that I should be made
                     acquainted with other customs than those of my native country. My departure was
                     therefore fixed at an early date; but, before the day resolved upon could
                     arrive, the first misfortune of my life occurred— an omen, as it were, of my
                     future misery.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.62]" facs="pageImages/vol1/62.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> had caught the scarlet fever; but her illness
                     was not severe, and she quickly recovered. During her confinement, many
                     arguments had been urged to persuade my mother to refrain from attending upon
                     her. She had, at first, yielded to our entreaties; but when she heard that her
                     favourite was recovering, she could no longer debar herself from her society,
                     and entered her chamber long before the danger of infection was past. The
                     consequences of this imprudence were fatal. On the third day my mother
                     sickened; her fever was very malignant, and the looks of her attendants
                     prognosticated the worst event. On her death-bed the fortitude and benignity of
                     this admirable woman did not desert her. She joined the hands of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> and myself: <tei-said who="#mother" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My
                        children,"</tei-said> she said, <tei-said who="#mother" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"my firmest hopes of future
                           <tei-pb n="[1.63]" facs="pageImages/vol1/63.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> happiness were placed on
                        the prospect of your union. This expectation will now be the consolation of
                        your father. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, my love, you must supply my
                        place to your younger cousins. Alas! I regret that I am taken from you; and,
                        happy and beloved as I have been, is it not hard to quit you all? But these
                        are not thoughts befitting me; I will endeavour to resign myself cheerfully
                        to death, and will indulge a hope of meeting you in another
                     world."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">She died calmly; and her countenance expressed affection even in death. I need
                     not describe the feelings of those whose dearest ties are rent by that most
                     irreparable evil, the void that presents itself to the soul, and the despair
                     that is exhibited on the countenance. It is so long before the mind can
                     persuade itself that she, whom we saw every day, and whose very existence <tei-pb n="[1.64]" facs="pageImages/vol1/64.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> appeared a part of our own, can
                     have departed for ever—that the brightness of a beloved eye can have been
                     extinguished, and the sound of a voice so familiar, and dear to the ear, can be
                     hushed, never more to be heard. These are the reflections of the first days;
                     but when the lapse of time proves the reality of the evil, then the actual
                     bitterness of grief commences. Yet from whom has not that rude hand rent away
                     some dear connexion; and why should I describe a sorrow which all have felt,
                     and must feel? The time at length arrives, when grief is rather an indulgence
                     than a necessity; and the smile that plays upon the lips, although it may be
                     deemed a sacrilege, is not banished. My mother was dead, but we had still
                     duties which we ought to perform; we must continue our course with the rest,
                     and learn to think <tei-pb n="[1.65]" facs="pageImages/vol1/65.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> ourselves
                     fortunate, whilst one remains whom the spoiler has not seized.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My journey to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>, which
                     had been deferred by these events, was now again determined upon. I obtained
                     from my father a respite of some weeks. This period was spent sadly; my
                     mother's death, and my speedy departure, depressed our spirits; but
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> endeavoured to renew the spirit of
                     cheerfulness in our little society. Since the death of her aunt, her mind had
                     acquired new firmness and vigour. She determined to fulfil her duties with the
                     greatest exactness; and she felt that that most imperious duty, of rendering
                     her uncle and cousins happy, had devolved upon her. She consoled me, amused her
                     uncle, instructed my brothers; and I never beheld her so enchanting as at this
                     time, when she was continually endeavouring to <tei-pb n="[1.66 - page breaks after 'con-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/66.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     contribute to the happiness of others, entirely forgetful of herself.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The day of my departure at length arrived. I had taken leave of all my friends,
                     excepting <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, who spent the last evening with us. He
                     bitterly lamented that he was unable to accompany me: but his father could not
                     be persuaded to part with him, intending that he should become a partner with
                     him in business, in compliance with his favourite theory, that learning was
                     superfluous in the commerce of ordinary life. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> had a
                     refined mind; he had no desire to be idle, and was well pleased to become his
                     father's partner, but he believed that a man might become a very good trader,
                     and yet possess a cultivated understanding.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We sat late, listening to his complaints, and making many little arrangements
                     for the future. The next <tei-pb n="[1.67]" facs="pageImages/vol1/67.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> morning
                     early I departed. Tears gushed from the eyes of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>;
                     they proceeded partly from sorrow at my departure, and partly because she
                     reflected that the same journey was to have taken place three months before,
                     when a mother's blessing would have accompanied me.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I threw myself into the chaise that was to convey me away, and indulged in the
                     most melancholy reflections. I, who had ever been surrounded by amiable
                     companions, continually engaged in endeavouring to bestow mutual pleasure, I
                     was now alone. In the university, whither I was going, I must form my own
                     friends, and be my own protector. My life had hitherto been remarkably secluded
                     and domestic; and this had given me invincible repugnance to new countenances.
                     I loved my brothers, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>; <tei-pb n="[1.68]" facs="pageImages/vol1/68.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     these were <tei-ref target="Old_Familiar_Faces_" corresp="Old_Familiar_Faces" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                        <tei-quote data-origname="quote">"old familiar faces;"</tei-quote></tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Old_Familiar_Faces" id="Old_Familiar_Faces" target="Old_Familiar_Faces_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">This is a direct allusion to Charles Lamb’s
                        (1775-1834) poem, <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44519/the-old-familiar-faces" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Old Familiar Faces"</tei-ref>, a poem about Lamb looking back on his life
                        through the lens of nostalgia. Victor uses the allusion at this point in the
                        text because he is retelling his story from a similar place once he leaves
                        his family and friends, will never find them or return to them the same way
                        again. </tei-note> but I believed myself totally unfitted for the company of
                     strangers. Such were my reflections as I commenced my journey; but as I
                     proceeded, my spirits and hopes rose. I ardently desired the acquisition of
                     knowledge. I had often, when at home, thought it hard to remain during my youth
                     cooped up in one place, and had longed to enter the world, and take my station
                     among other human beings. Now my desires were complied with, and it would,
                     indeed, have been folly to repent.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I had sufficient leisure for these and many other reflections during my journey
                     to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>, which was long
                     and fatiguing. At length the high white steeple of the town met my eyes. I
                     alighted, and was conducted to my solitary apartment, to spend the evening as I
                     pleased.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.69]" facs="pageImages/vol1/69.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The next morning I delivered my letters of introduction, and paid a visit to
                     some of the principal professors, and among others to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M.
                        Krempe</tei-persName>, professor of natural philosophy. He received me with
                     politeness, and asked me several questions concerning my progress in the
                     different branches of science appertaining to natural philosophy. I mentioned,
                     it is true, with fear and trembling, the only authors I had ever read upon
                     those subjects. The professor stared: <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Have you,"</tei-said> he
                     said, <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"really spent your time in studying such
                        nonsense?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I replied in the affirmative. <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Every minute,"</tei-said>
                     continued <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Krempe</tei-persName> with warmth, <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"every instant that you have wasted on those books is utterly and entirely
                        lost. You have burdened your memory with exploded systems, and useless
                        names. Good God! in what <tei-pb n="[1.70]" facs="pageImages/vol1/70.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        desert land have you lived, where no one was kind enough to inform you that
                        these fancies, which you have so greedily imbibed, are a thousand years old,
                        and as musty as they are ancient? I little expected in this enlightened and
                        scientific age to find a disciple of <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n81007973" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Albertus Magnus</tei-persName> and <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80120959" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Paracelsus</tei-persName>. My dear Sir, you must begin your studies entirely
                        anew."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">So saying, he stepped aside, and wrote down a list of several books treating of
                     natural philosophy, which he desired me to procure, and dismissed me, after
                     mentioning that in the beginning of the following week he intended to commence
                     a course of lectures upon natural philosophy in its general relations, and that
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Waldman</tei-persName>, a fellow-professor, would lecture upon
                     chemistry the alternate days that he missed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I returned home, not disappointed, <tei-pb n="[1.71]" facs="pageImages/vol1/71.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> for I had long considered those authors useless whom the professor had so
                     strongly reprobated; but I did not feel much inclined to study the books which
                     I had procured at his recommendation. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Krempe</tei-persName> was a
                     little squat man, with a gruff voice and repulsive countenance; the teacher,
                     therefore, did not prepossess me in favour of his doctrine. Besides, I had a
                     contempt for the uses of modern natural philosophy. It was very different, when
                     the masters of the science sought immortality and power; such views, although
                     futile, were grand: but now the scene was changed. The ambition of the inquirer
                     seemed to limit itself to the annihilation of those visions on which my
                     interest in science was chiefly founded. I was required to exchange chimeras of
                     boundless grandeur for realities of little worth.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Such were my reflections during the <tei-pb n="[1.72]" facs="pageImages/vol1/72.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> first two or three days spent almost in
                     solitude. But as the ensuing week commenced, I thought of the information which
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Krempe</tei-persName> had given me concerning the lectures. And
                     although I could not consent to go and hear that little conceited fellow
                     deliver sentences out of a pulpit, I recollected what he had said of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Waldman</tei-persName>, whom I had never seen, as he had hitherto
                     been out of town.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Partly from curiosity, and partly from idleness, I went into the lecturing
                     room, which <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Waldman</tei-persName> entered shortly after. <tei-ref target="Sir_Humphrey_Davy_" corresp="Sir_Humphrey_Davy" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> This professor </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Sir_Humphrey_Davy" id="Sir_Humphrey_Davy" target="Sir_Humphrey_Davy_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-graphic url="http://www.britishmuseum.org/collectionimages/AN00048/AN00048580_001_l.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Sir Humphrey Davy (1778-1829) was a
                        Cornish scientist as well as poet, and according to Richard Holmes’ <tei-ref target="http://clinchem.aaccjnls.org/content/57/11/1625" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Humphrey Davy
                           and the Chemical Moment,"</tei-ref> is best known today for his work on
                        nitrous oxide (which he coined "<tei-ref target="https://publicdomainreview.org/collections/the-nitrous-oxide-experiments-of-humphry-davy/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">laughing gas</tei-ref>"), his use of the Voltaic battery to resolve new
                        elements, sodium and potassium; his innovations in agricultural chemistry
                        and animal tanning; his invention of the arc light; and above all for his
                        design of the miner's safety lamp. He was the <tei-ref target="http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/davy_humphrey.shtml" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">first Englishman</tei-ref> knighted for service to science since Sir Issac
                        Newton and the first professional chemist to be elected President of the
                        Royal Society of London. Mary Shelley was intimately aware of Sir Humphrey
                        Davy, as he knew Coleridge, Wordsworth, and her father William Godwin.
                        Explore more of her background with these iconic figures in the NIH’s
                        History of Medicine Exhibit, <tei-ref target="https://www.nlm.nih.gov/frankenstein/exhibition2.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein: Penetrating the Secrets of
                           Nature</tei-hi></tei-ref>. Percy Shelley, Mary’s husband, was also interested in
                        the work of Sir Humphrey Davy. In school he was a <tei-ref target="http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/ockhamsrazor/mary-shelleys-frankenstein-and-the-birth-of-modern-science/6014790" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">political and religious radical</tei-ref>, having been expelled from Oxford
                        for supposedly writing a pamphlet <tei-ref target="http://www.oxfordtoday.ox.ac.uk/news/2015-11-11-long-lost-shelley-poem-written-while-he-was-oxford-revealed-bodleian" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">denouncing the existence of God</tei-ref>, he turned himself to Davy’s work.
                        The Shelleys were seduced by the study of galvanism, a branch of natural
                        philosophy discovered by <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Luigi-Galvani" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Luigi
                           Galvani</tei-ref> (1737-1798) who investigated the effect of electricity on
                        animal limbs. Sir Humphrey Davy corroborated the discovery and supported the
                        theory in a speech given to the Royal Society of London. Davy’s influence
                        can be found in all of the science of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>;
                        however, he is most obviously the inspiration for M. Waldman, Victor’s
                        mentor. Many of M. Waldman’s scientific ideas are very similar to Davy’s,
                        and Shelley frequently alludes to his 1802 <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Discourse
                           Introductory to a Course of Lectures on Chemistry (1802; <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=xAtQAAAAcAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">collected in
                              this accessible 1839 edition</tei-ref>)</tei-hi>. <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> is filled with allusions to Davy’s works. To read more
                        about Davy and his influence on the Shelleys, see Sharon Ruston’s literary
                        critique, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=J1J9DAAAQBAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Shelley and
                              Vitality</tei-ref></tei-hi>, the Smithsonian Institute’s exhibition <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://library.si.edu/exhibition/fantastic-worlds/body-electric" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Body Electric: Inspiring Frankenstein</tei-ref></tei-hi>, and Theodore
                        Ziolkowski’s article "<tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/27543797" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Science, Frankenstein, and Myth</tei-ref>." To explore more of Davy’s work,
                        see his 1812 <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://archive.org/details/ElementschemicaVol1Davy" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Elements
                              of Chemical Philosophy</tei-ref></tei-hi>, via the Internet Archive. The image
                        above, from <tei-ref target="http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">the British Museum</tei-ref>, shows <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Scientific Researches!
                           New Discoveries in Pneumaticks! An Experimental Lecture on the Powers of
                           Air</tei-hi> (1802) a satirical etching by James Gillray depicting Davy and
                        colleagues experimenting with nitrous oxide. </tei-note> was very unlike his
                     colleague. He appeared about fifty years of age, but with an aspect expressive
                     of the greatest benevolence; a few grey hairs covered his temples, but those at
                     the back of his head were nearly black. His person was short, but remarkably
                     erect; and his <tei-pb n="[1.73]" facs="pageImages/vol1/73.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> voice the
                     sweetest I had ever heard. He began his lecture by a recapitulation of the
                     history of chemistry, and the various improvements made by different men of
                     learning, pronouncing with fervour the names of the most distinguished
                     discoverers. He then took a cursory view of the present state of the science,
                     and explained many of its elementary terms. After having made a few preparatory
                     experiments, he concluded with a panegyric upon modern chemistry, the terms of
                     which I shall never forget:—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#waldman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                        <tei-ref target="Lectures_in_Chemistry_" corresp="Lectures_in_Chemistry" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> "The
                           ancient teachers of this science," </tei-ref>
                     </tei-said>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Lectures_in_Chemistry" id="Lectures_in_Chemistry" target="Lectures_in_Chemistry_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">Shelley references Humphry Davy and
                        his <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"> Discourse Introductory to a Course of Lectures in
                           Chemistry</tei-hi> (1802). Here, both Victor and Davy are gesturing toward
                        the history of the development of the sciences by way of alchemy and
                        discussing the height to which science and discovery have come in the early
                        nineteenth century. Both suggest that while the views of the "ancient
                        teachers" of alchemy are now seen as unscientific, modern study began there:
                        "[The alchemists’] views of things have passed away, and a new science has
                        gradually arisen. The dim and uncertain twilight of discovery, which gave to
                        objects false or indefinite appearances, has been succeeded by the steady
                        light of truth, which has shown the external world in its distinct forms,
                        and in its true relations to human powers. The composition of the
                        atmosphere, and the properties of the gases, have been ascertained; the
                        phenomena of electricity have been developed; the lightnings have been taken
                        from the clouds; and, lastly, a new influence has been discovered, which has
                        enabled man to produce from combinations of dead matter effects which were
                        formerly occasioned only by animal organs" (<tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=xAtQAAAAcAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Davy, "Discourse"
                           321</tei-ref>). Note the reference at the end of this passage to
                        galvanism.</tei-note> said he, <tei-said who="#waldman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"promised impossibilities,
                        and performed nothing. The modern masters promise very little; they know
                        that metals cannot be transmuted, and that the elixir of life is a chimera.
                        But these philosophers, whose hands seem only made to dabble <tei-pb n="[1.74]" facs="pageImages/vol1/74.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> in dirt,<tei-ref target="the_Microscope_" corresp="the_Microscope" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> and their eyes to pore over the microscope or
                           crucible, have indeed performed miracles. </tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="the_Microscope" id="the_Microscope" target="the_Microscope_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="https://www.bl.uk/britishlibrary/~/media/bl/global/dl%20shakespeare/renaissance%20items/micrographia-by-robert-hooke-435_e_19_facing_p210.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> While the idea of lenses and
                           magnification dates far back in time, the earliest known examples of
                           compound microscopes appeared in Europe around 1620, as explained in
                           David Bardell’s article “<tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/4608700" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Invention of the
                              Microscope</tei-ref>." The inventor of the microscope is unknown, yet many
                           have claimed it--including Galileo. However, it wasn’t until <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Hooke" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Robert
                              Hooke</tei-ref> (1635-1703) published <tei-ref target="https://archive.org/details/mobot31753000817897" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Micrographia</tei-hi></tei-ref> (1665) that the use of the
                           microscope became accepted and adopted by the scientific community. Hooke
                           held titles such as scientist, astronomer, philosopher, architect and
                           inventor, and was a polymath. In his book, Hooke describes in minute
                           detail the visions of insects, leaves, and other objects, accompanying
                           many of his descriptions with richly detailed illustrations. is work has
                           contributed to cell theories and even helped create the discipline of
                           paleontology. The image used is one of many that can be viewed, hosted by
                           the <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/micrographia-by-robert-hooke-1665" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">British Libraries online collection.</tei-ref></tei-note>
                        <tei-ref target="Penetrative_" corresp="Penetrative" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> They penetrate into the
                           recesses of nature </tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="Penetrative" id="Penetrative" target="Penetrative_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">In his <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Discourse Introductory to
                              a Course of Lectures on Chemistry</tei-hi> (1802), Humphry Davy describes
                           the "penetrative" agency of the masculine scientist-explorer in virtually
                           identical terms. Davy’s writes, "Not contented with what is found upon
                           the surface of the earth, he has penetrated into her bosom, and has even
                           searched the bottom of the ocean for the purpose of allaying the
                           restlessness of his desires, or of extending and increasing his power."
                           Davy, going on to state that "[h]e [the modern chemist] is to a certain
                           extent the ruler of all the elements around him," emphasizes the almost
                           unlimited power and omnipotent will of the scientist: "he is capable of
                           using not only common matter according to his will and inclinations, but
                           likewise of subjecting to his purposes the ethereal principles of heat
                           and light. By his inventions they are elicited from the atmosphere; and
                           under his control they become, according to circumstances, instruments of
                           comfort and enjoyment, or of terror and destruction" (<tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=xAtQAAAAcAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Davy,
                              "Discourses" 318</tei-ref>).</tei-note>, and shew how she works in her hiding
                        places. They ascend into the heavens; <tei-ref target="Circulation_of_the_Blood_" corresp="Circulation_of_the_Blood" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">they have discovered how the blood circulates </tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="Circulation_of_the_Blood" id="Circulation_of_the_Blood" target="Circulation_of_the_Blood_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id"><tei-graphic url="http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/anatomia/bloodcirc/images/qp101-h3_00002.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> The circulation of the blood in
                           the body was first demonstrated by William Harvey (1578-1657) in the
                           early 17th century, though his seminal work on the subject, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Exercitatio Anatomica de Motu Cordis et Sanguinis in
                              Animalibus</tei-hi>, was not published (in Latin) until 1628; the first
                           English translation appeared later. Harvey's theory derived from the
                           science of the Ancient Greek physician Galen, but he used direct
                           observation and experimentation--like vivisection--to illustrate and
                           explore his ideas. For more information, see <tei-ref target="https://archive.org/details/WilliamHarveycirculationoftheblood4-wellcome" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">William Harvey and the Circulation of the
                                 Blood</tei-hi></tei-ref>, an informational video produced by the Royal
                           College of Physicians (1971-72). For more information about anatomy
                           during the 16th and 17th centuries, see <tei-ref target="http://www.indiana.edu/%7Eliblilly/anatomia/index.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Anatomia Animata</tei-hi>, a digital exhibit of works in
                              the Lilly Library of Indiana University</tei-ref>. The image to the right,
                           via the Lilly Library exhibit, shows a page from Harvey's <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">De Motu Cordis</tei-hi>. </tei-note>, and the nature of the air
                        we breathe. <tei-ref target="unlimited_powers_" corresp="unlimited_powers" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> They
                           have acquired new and almost unlimited powers</tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="unlimited_powers" id="unlimited_powers" target="unlimited_powers_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">This language of “unlimited powers" refers an idea
                           perhaps best expressed in a <tei-ref target="https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Franklin/01-31-02-0325" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">letter</tei-ref> from <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Benjamin-Franklin" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Benjamin Franklin</tei-ref> to Joseph Priestley in 1780. Franklin writes,
                           “It is impossible to imagine the height to which may be carried in a
                           thousand years, the power of man over matter. We may perhaps learn to
                           deprive large masses of their gravity, and give them absolute levity, for
                           the sake of easy transport." This sentiment is reiterated in both
                           Godwin’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Political Justice</tei-hi> and Humphry Davy’s
                              “<tei-ref target="https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=xAtQAAAAcAAJ" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Lectures on Chemistry</tei-ref>." During this time science was thought to
                           be a source of unlimited powers. The idea that science was all powerful
                           forms an important context for Shelley’s <tei-hi rend="Italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>. Mary Shelley would have been very aware of
                           Franklin’s experiments with electricity. Her mother, Mary Wollstonecraft
                           was tutored Dr. Richard Price (a supporter of the American Revolution)
                           and uses the same publisher as Franklin, Joseph Johnson. Her father,
