                           William Godwin, was a member of the Royal Society of London, of which
                           Franklin was also a member. For more information on the reach of Ben
                           Franklin’s experiments and his views of science, see <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=xS9jvWe26OoC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Draw
                                 the Lightning Down: Benjamin Franklin and Electrical Technology in
                                 the Age of Enlightenment</tei-ref></tei-hi> by Michael Schiffer.</tei-note> ;
                        they can command the thunders of heaven, mimic the earthquake, and even mock
                        the invisible world with its own shadows."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I departed highly pleased with the professor and his lecture, and paid him a
                     visit the same evening. His manners in private were even more mild and
                     attractive than in public; for there was a certain dignity in his mien during
                     his lecture, which in his own house was replaced by the greatest <tei-pb n="[1.75]" facs="pageImages/vol1/75.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> affability and kindness. He heard with
                     attention my little narration concerning my studies, and smiled at the names of
                        <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Cornelius Agrippa</tei-persName> and
                        <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80120959" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Paracelsus</tei-persName>, but without
                     the contempt that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Krempe</tei-persName> had exhibited. He said, that
                        <tei-said who="#waldman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"these were men to whose indefatigable zeal modern
                        philosophers were indebted for most of the foundations of their knowledge.
                        They had left to us, as an easier task, to give new names, arrange in
                        connected classifications, the facts which they in a great degree had been
                        the instruments of bringing to light. The labours of men of genius, however
                        erroneously directed, scarcely ever fail in ultimately turning to the solid
                        advantage of mankind."</tei-said> I listened to his statement, which was
                     delivered without any presumption or affectation; and then added, that his
                     lecture had removed my prejudices against modern <tei-pb n="[1.76]" facs="pageImages/vol1/76.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> chemists; and I, at the same time, requested
                     his advice concerning the books I ought to procure.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#waldman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am happy,"</tei-said> said <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Waldman</tei-persName>,
                        <tei-said who="#waldman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"to have gained a disciple; and if your application
                        equals your ability, I have no doubt of your success. Chemistry is that
                        branch of natural philosophy in which the greatest improvements have been
                        and may be made; it is on that account that I have made it my peculiar
                        study; but at the same time I have not neglected the other branches of
                        science. A man would make but a very sorry chemist, if he attended to that
                        department of human knowledge alone. If your wish is to become really a man
                        of science, and not merely a petty experimentalist, I should advise you to
                        apply to every branch of natural philosophy, including
                     mathematics."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.77]" facs="pageImages/vol1/77.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He then took me into his laboratory, and explained to me the uses of his
                     various machines; instructing me as to what I ought to procure, and promising
                     me the use of his own, when I should have advanced far enough in the science
                     not to derange their mechanism. He also gave me the list of books which I had
                     requested; and I took my leave.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus ended a day memorable to me; it decided my future destiny.</tei-p></tei-said>







            </tei-div>









            <tei-div n="1.3" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[1.78]" facs="pageImages/vol1/78.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter III</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">FROM this day natural philosophy, and particularly chemistry,
                     in the most comprehensive sense of the term, became nearly my sole occupation.
                     I read with ardour those works, so full of genius and discrimination, which
                     modern inquirers have written on these subjects. I attended the lectures, and
                     cultivated the acquaintance, of the men of science of the university; and I
                     found even in <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M. Krempe</tei-persName> a great deal of sound sense and
                     real information, combined, it is true, with a repulsive physiognomy and
                     manners, but not on that account the less valuable. In <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M.
                        Waldman</tei-persName> I found <tei-pb n="[1.79]" facs="pageImages/vol1/79.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> a
                     true friend. His gentleness was never tinged by dogmatism; and his instructions
                     were given with an air of frankness and good nature that banished every idea of
                     pedantry. It was, perhaps, the amiable character of this man that inclined me
                     more to that branch of natural philosophy which he professed, than an intrinsic
                     love for the science itself. But this state of mind had place only in the first
                     steps towards knowledge: the more fully I entered into the science, the more
                     exclusively I pursued it for its own sake. That application, which at first had
                     been a matter of duty and resolution, now became so ardent and eager, that the
                     stars often disappeared in the light of morning whilst I was yet engaged in my
                     laboratory.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As I applied so closely, it may be easily conceived that I improved <tei-pb n="[1.80 - page breaks after 'ra-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/80.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     rapidly. My ardour was indeed the astonishment of the students; and my
                     proficiency, that of the masters. Professor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Krempe</tei-persName> often
                     asked me, with a sly smile, how <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Cornelius Agrippa</tei-persName> went on? whilst <tei-persName data-origname="persName">M.
                        Waldman</tei-persName> expressed the most heartfelt exultation in my progress.
                     Two years passed in this manner, during which I paid no visit to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, but was engaged, heart and
                     soul, in the pursuit of some discoveries, which I hoped to make. None but those
                     who have experienced them can conceive of the enticements of science. In other
                     studies you go as far as others have gone before you, and there is nothing more
                     to know; but in a scientific pursuit there is continual food for discovery and
                     wonder. A mind of moderate capacity, which closely pursues one study, must
                     infallibly arrive at great proficiency in that study; and I, who <tei-pb n="[1.81 - page breaks after 'con-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/81.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     continually sought the attainment of one object of pursuit, and was solely
                     wrapped up in this, improved so rapidly, that, at the end of two years, I made
                     some discoveries in the improvement of some chemical instruments, which
                     procured me great esteem and admiration at the university. When I had arrived
                     at this point, and had become as well acquainted with the theory and practice
                     of natural philosophy as depended on the lessons of any of the professors at
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>, my residence
                     there being no longer conducive to my improvements, I thought of returning to
                     my friends and my native town, when an incident happened that protracted my
                     stay.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">One of the phænomena which had peculiarly attracted my attention was the
                     structure of the human frame, and, indeed, any animal endued with life. Whence,
                     I often asked myself, did the <tei-pb n="[1.82]" facs="pageImages/vol1/82.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     principle of life proceed? It was a bold question, and one which has ever been
                     considered as a mystery; yet with how many things are we upon the brink of
                     becoming acquainted, if cowardice or carelessness did not restrain our
                     inquiries. I revolved these circumstances in my mind, and determined
                     thenceforth to apply myself more particularly to those branches of natural
                     philosophy which relate to physiology. Unless I had been animated by an almost
                     supernatural enthusiasm, my application to this study would have been irksome,
                     and almost intolerable. To examine the causes of life, we must first have
                     recourse to death. I became acquainted with the science of anatomy: but this
                     was not sufficient; I must also observe the natural decay and corruption of the
                     human body. In my education my father had taken the <tei-pb n="[1.83]" facs="pageImages/vol1/83.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> greatest precautions that my mind should be
                     impressed with no supernatural horrors. I do not ever remember to have trembled
                     at a tale of superstition, or to have feared the apparition of a spirit.
                     Darkness had no effect upon my fancy; and a churchyard was to me merely the
                     receptacle of bodies deprived of life, which, from being the seat of beauty and
                     strength, had become food for the worm. Now I was led to examine the cause and
                     progress of this decay, and forced to spend days and nights in vaults and
                     charnel houses. My attention was fixed upon every object the most insupportable
                     to the delicacy of the human feelings. I saw how the fine form of man was
                     degraded and wasted; I beheld the corruption of death succeed to the blooming
                     cheek of life; I saw how the worm inherited the wonders of the eye and brain. I
                        <tei-pb n="[1.84]" facs="pageImages/vol1/84.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> paused, examining and
                     analysing all the minutiae of causation, as exemplified in the change from life
                     to death, and death to life, until from the midst of this darkness a sudden
                     light broke in upon me—a light so brilliant and wondrous, yet so simple, that
                     while I became dizzy with the immensity of the prospect which it illustrated, I
                     was surprised that among so many men of genius, who had directed their
                     inquiries towards the same science, that I alone should be reserved to discover
                     so astonishing a secret.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Remember, I am not recording the vision of a madman. The sun does not more
                     certainly shine in the heavens, than that which I now affirm is true. Some
                     miracle might have produced it, yet the stages of the discovery were distinct
                     and probable. After days and nights of incredible labour and fatigue, <tei-pb n="[1.85]" facs="pageImages/vol1/85.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I succeeded in discovering the
                     cause of generation and life; nay, more, I became myself capable of bestowing
                     animation upon lifeless matter.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The astonishment which I had at first experienced on this discovery soon gave
                     place to delight and rapture. After so much time spent in painful labour, to
                     arrive at once at the summit of my desires, was the most gratifying
                     consummation of my toils. But this discovery was so great and overwhelming,
                     that all the steps by which I had been progressively led to it were
                     obliterated, and I beheld only the result. What had been the study and desire
                     of the wisest men since the creation of the world, was now within my grasp. Not
                     that, like a magic scene, it all opened upon me at once: the information I had
                     obtained was of a nature rather to direct my endeavours so soon as I should
                     point them towards <tei-pb n="[1.86]" facs="pageImages/vol1/86.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the object of
                     my search, than to exhibit that object already accomplished. I was like the
                     Arabian who had been buried with the dead, and found a passage to life aided
                     only by one glimmering, and seemingly ineffectual, light.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I see by your eagerness, and the wonder and hope which your eyes express, my
                     friend, that you expect to be informed of the secret with which I am
                     acquainted; that cannot be: listen patiently until the end of my story, and you
                     will easily perceive why I am reserved upon that subject. I will not lead you
                     on, unguarded and ardent as I then was, to your destruction and infallible
                     misery. Learn from me, if not by my precepts, at least by my example, how
                     dangerous is the acquirement of knowledge, and how much happier that man is who
                     believes his <tei-pb n="[1.87]" facs="pageImages/vol1/87.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> native town to be
                     the world, than he who aspires to become greater than his nature will
                     allow.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When I found so astonishing a power placed within my hands, I hesitated a long
                     time concerning the manner in which I should employ it. Although I possessed
                     the capacity of bestowing animation, yet to prepare a frame for the reception
                     of it, with all its intricacies of fibres, muscles, and veins, still remained a
                     work of inconceivable difficulty and labour. I doubted at first whether I
                     should attempt the creation of a being like myself or one of simpler
                     organization; but my imagination was too much exalted by my first success to
                     permit me to doubt of my ability to give life to an animal as complex and
                     wonderful as man. The materials at present within my command hardly appeared
                     adequate to so arduous an <tei-pb n="[1.88]" facs="pageImages/vol1/88.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     undertaking; but I doubted not that I should ultimately succeed. I prepared
                     myself for a multitude of reverses; my operations might be incessantly baffled,
                     and at last my work be imperfect: yet, when I considered the improvement which
                     every day takes place in science and mechanics, I was encouraged to hope my
                     present attempts would at least lay the foundations of future success. Nor
                     could I consider the magnitude and complexity of my plan as any argument of its
                     impracticability. It was with these feelings that I began the creation of a
                     human being. As the minuteness of the parts formed a great hindrance to my
                     speed, I resolved, contrary to my first intention, to make the being of a
                     gigantic stature; that is to say, about eight feet in height, and
                     proportionably large. After having formed this <tei-pb n="[1.89 - page breaks after 'de-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/89.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     determination, and having spent some months in successfully collecting and
                     arranging my materials, I began.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">No one can conceive the variety of feelings which bore me onwards, like a
                     hurricane, in the first enthusiasm of success. Life and death appeared to me
                     ideal bounds, which I should first break through, and pour a torrent of light
                     into our dark world. A new species would bless me as its creator and source;
                     many happy and excellent natures would owe their being to me. No father could
                     claim the gratitude of his child so completely as I should deserve their's.
                     Pursuing these reflections, I thought, that if I could bestow animation upon
                     lifeless matter, I might in process of time (although I now found it
                     impossible) renew life where death had apparently devoted the body to
                     corruption.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.90]" facs="pageImages/vol1/90.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">These thoughts supported my spirits, while I pursued my undertaking with
                     unremitting ardour. My cheek had grown pale with study, and my person had
                     become emaciated with confinement. Sometimes, on the very brink of certainty, I
                     failed; yet still I clung to the hope which the next day or the next hour might
                     realise. One secret which I alone possessed was the hope to which I had
                     dedicated myself; and the moon gazed on my midnight labours, while, with
                     unrelaxed and breathless eagerness, I pursued nature to her hiding-places. Who
                     shall conceive the horrors of my secret toil, as I dabbled among the unhallowed
                     damps of the grave, or tortured the living animal to animate the lifeless clay?
                     My limbs now tremble, and my eyes swim with the remembrance; but then a
                     resistless, and almost frantic impulse, urged me forward; I seemed to <tei-pb n="[1.91]" facs="pageImages/vol1/91.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> have lost all soul or sensation
                     but for this one pursuit. It was indeed but a passing trance, that only made me
                     feel with renewed acuteness so soon as, the unnatural stimulus ceasing to
                     operate, I had returned to my old habits. I collected bones from charnel
                     houses; and disturbed, with profane fingers, the tremendous secrets of the
                     human frame. In a solitary chamber, or rather cell, at the top of the house,
                     and separated from all the other apartments by a gallery and staircase, I kept
                     my workshop of filthy creation; my eyeballs were starting from their sockets in
                     attending to the details of my employment. The dissecting room and the
                     slaughter-house furnished many of my materials; and often did my human nature
                     turn with loathing from my occupation, whilst, still urged on by an eagerness
                     which perpetually increased, <tei-pb n="[1.92]" facs="pageImages/vol1/92.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I
                     brought my work near to a conclusion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The summer months passed while I was thus engaged, heart and soul, in one
                     pursuit. It was a most beautiful season; never did the fields bestow a more
                     plentiful harvest, or the vines yield a more luxuriant vintage: but my eyes
                     were insensible to the charms of nature. And the same feelings which made me
                     neglect the scenes around me caused me also to forget those friends who were so
                     many miles absent, and whom I had not seen for so long a time. I knew my
                     silence disquieted them; and I well remembered the words of my father: <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I know that while you are pleased with yourself, you will
                        think of us with affection, and we shall hear regularly from you. You must
                        pardon me, if I regard any interruption in your correspondence as a proof
                           <tei-pb n="[1.93]" facs="pageImages/vol1/93.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> that your other duties are
                        equally neglected."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I knew well therefore what would be my father's feelings; but I could not tear
                     my thoughts from my employment, loathsome in itself, but which had taken an
                     irresistible hold of my imagination. I wished, as it were, to procrastinate all
                     that related to my feelings of affection until the great object, which
                     swallowed up every habit of my nature, should be completed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I then thought that my father would be unjust if he ascribed my neglect to
                     vice, or faultiness on my part; but I am now convinced that he was justified in
                     conceiving that I should not be altogether free from blame. A human being in
                     perfection ought always to preserve a calm and peaceful mind, and never to
                     allow passion or a transitory desire to disturb his tranquillity. <tei-pb n="[1.94]" facs="pageImages/vol1/94.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I do not think that the pursuit
                     of knowledge is an exception to this rule. If the study to which you apply
                     yourself has a tendency to weaken your affections, and to destroy your taste
                     for those simple pleasures in which no alloy can possibly mix, then that study
                     is certainly unlawful, that is to say, not befitting the human mind. If this
                     rule were always observed; if no man allowed any pursuit whatsoever to
                     interfere with the tranquillity of his domestic affections, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Greece</tei-placeName> had not been enslaved; <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n79021400" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Caesar</tei-persName> would have spared his
                     country; <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8698314" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">America</tei-placeName> would have
                     been discovered more gradually; and the empires of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7005560" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mexico</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000056" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Peru</tei-placeName> had not been destroyed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But I forget that I am moralizing in the most interesting part of my tale; and
                     your looks remind me to proceed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father made no reproach in his <tei-pb n="[1.95]" facs="pageImages/vol1/95.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> letters; and only took notice of my silence by inquiring into my occupations
                     more particularly than before. Winter, spring, and summer passed away during my
                     labours; but I did not watch the blossom or the expanding leaves—sights which
                     before always yielded me supreme delight, so deeply was I engrossed in my
                     occupation. The leaves of that year had withered before my work drew near to a
                     close; and now every day shewed me more plainly how well I had succeeded. But
                     my enthusiasm was checked by my anxiety, and I appeared rather like one doomed
                     by slavery to toil in the mines, or any other unwholesome trade, than an artist
                     occupied by his favourite employment. Every night I was oppressed by a slow
                     fever, and I became nervous to a most painful degree; a disease that I
                     regretted the more because I had hitherto <tei-pb n="[1.96 - page breaks after 'en-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/96.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> enjoyed
                     most excellent health, and had always boasted of the firmness of my nerves. But
                     I believed that exercise and amusement would soon drive away such symptoms; and
                     I promised myself both of these, when my creation should be
                  complete.</tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>






            <tei-div n="1.4" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[1.97]" facs="pageImages/vol1/97.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter IV</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">IT was on a dreary night of <tei-date data-origname="date">November</tei-date>, that I
                     beheld the accomplishment of my toils. With an anxiety that almost amounted to
                     agony, I collected the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a
                     spark of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It was already one
                     in the morning; the rain pattered dismally against the panes, and my candle was
                     nearly burnt out, when, by the glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I saw
                     the dull yellow eye of the creature open; it breathed <tei-pb n="[1.98]" facs="pageImages/vol1/98.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> hard, and a convulsive motion agitated its
                     limbs.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how delineate the wretch
                     whom with such infinite pains and care I had endeavoured to form? His limbs
                     were in proportion, and I had selected his features as beautiful.
                     Beautiful!—Great God! His yellow skin scarcely covered the work of muscles and
                     arteries beneath; his hair was of a lustrous black, and flowing; his teeth of a
                     pearly whiteness; but these luxuriances only formed a more horrid contrast with
                     his watery eyes, that seemed almost of the same colour as the dun white sockets
                     in which they were set, his shrivelled complexion, and straight black lips.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The different accidents of life are not so changeable as the feelings of human
                     nature. I had worked hard for <tei-pb n="[1.99]" facs="pageImages/vol1/99.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     nearly two years, for the sole purpose of infusing life into an inanimate body.
                     For this I had deprived myself of rest and health. I had desired it with an
                     ardour that far exceeded moderation; but now that I had finished, the beauty of
                     the dream vanished, and breathless horror and disgust filled my heart. Unable
                     to endure the aspect of the being I had created, I rushed out of the room, and
                     continued a long time traversing my bed-chamber, unable to compose my mind to
                     sleep. At length lassitude succeeded to the tumult I had before endured; and I
                     threw myself on the bed in my clothes, endeavouring to seek a few moments of
                     forgetfulness. But it was in vain: I slept indeed, but I was disturbed by the
                     wildest dreams. I thought I saw <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, in the bloom of
                     health, walking in the streets of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>. Delighted and surprised, I <tei-pb n="[1.100 - page breaks after 'em-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/100.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     embraced her; but as I imprinted the first kiss on her lips, they became livid
                     with the hue of death; her features appeared to change, and I thought that I
                     held the corpse of my dead mother in my arms; a shroud enveloped her form, and
                     I saw the grave-worms crawling in the folds of the flannel. I started from my
                     sleep with horror; a cold dew covered my forehead, my teeth chattered, and
                     every limb became convulsed; when, by the dim and yellow light of the moon, as
                     it forced its way through the window-shutters, I beheld the wretch—the
                     miserable monster whom I had created. He held up the curtain of the bed; and
                     his eyes, if eyes they may be called, were fixed on me. His jaws opened, and he
                     muttered some inarticulate sounds, while a grin wrinkled his cheeks. He might
                     have spoken, but I did not hear; one hand was <tei-pb n="[1.101]" facs="pageImages/vol1/101.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> stretched out, seemingly to detain me, but
                     I escaped, and rushed down stairs. I took refuge in the court-yard belonging to
                     the house which I inhabited; where I remained during the rest of the night,
                     walking up and down in the greatest agitation, listening attentively, catching
                     and fearing each sound as if it were to announce the approach of the demoniacal
                     corpse to which I had so miserably given life.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Oh! no mortal could support the horror of that countenance. A mummy again
                     endued with animation could not be so hideous as that wretch. I had gazed on
                     him while unfinished; he was ugly then; but when those muscles and joints were
                     rendered capable of motion, it became a thing such as even <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n78095495" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Dante</tei-persName>
                      could not have
                     conceived.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I passed the night wretchedly. Sometimes my pulse beat so quickly and <tei-pb n="[1.102]" facs="pageImages/vol1/102.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> hardly, that I felt the
                     palpitation of every artery; at others, I nearly sank to the ground through
                     languor and extreme weakness. Mingled with this horror, I felt the bitterness
                     of disappointment: dreams that had been my food and pleasant rest for so long a
                     space, were now become a hell to me; and the change was so rapid, the overthrow
                     so complete!</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Morning, dismal and wet, at length dawned, and discovered to my sleepless and
                     aching eyes the church of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>, its white steeple and clock, which indicated the
                     sixth hour. The porter opened the gates of the court, which had that night been
                     my asylum, and I issued into the streets, pacing them with quick steps, as if I
                     sought to avoid the wretch whom I feared every turning of the street would
                     present to my view. I did not dare return to the apartment which I inhabited,
                     but felt <tei-pb n="[1.103]" facs="pageImages/vol1/103.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> impelled to hurry on,
                     although wetted by the rain, which poured from a black and comfortless sky.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I continued walking in this manner for some time, endeavouring, by bodily
                     exercise, to ease the load that weighed upon my mind. I traversed the streets,
                     without any clear conception of where I was, or what I was doing. My heart
                     palpitated in the sickness of fear; and I hurried on with irregular steps, not
                     daring to look about me:</tei-p>
                  <tei-quote data-origname="quote">
                     <tei-lg data-origname="lg">







                        <tei-l data-origname="l">Like one who, on a lonely road,</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">Doth walk in fear and dread,</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">And, having once turn'd round, walks on,</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">And turns no more his head;</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">Because he knows a frightful fiend</tei-l>


                        <tei-l data-origname="l">Doth close behind him tread.*</tei-l>


                     </tei-lg>
                  </tei-quote>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Continuing thus, I came at length opposite to the inn at which the various
                     diligences and carriages usually stopped. <tei-pb n="[1.104]" facs="pageImages/vol1/104.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> Here I paused, I knew not why; but I
                     remained some minutes with my eyes fixed on a coach that was coming towards me
                     from the other end of the street. As it drew nearer, I observed that it was the
                     Swiss diligence: it stopped just where I was standing; and, on the door being
                     opened, I perceived <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry Clerval</tei-persName>, who, on seeing me,
                     instantly sprung out. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>,"</tei-said> exclaimed he, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how glad I am to see you! how fortunate that you should be
                        here at the very moment of my alighting!"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Nothing could equal my delight on seeing <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>; his
                     presence brought back to my thoughts my father, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>,
                     and all those scenes of home so dear to my recollection. I grasped his hand,
                     and in a moment forgot my horror and misfortune; I felt suddenly, and for the
                     first time during many months, <tei-pb n="[1.105]" facs="pageImages/vol1/105.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     calm and serene joy. I welcomed my friend therefore, in the most cordial
                     manner, and we walked towards my college. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>
                     continued talking for some time about our mutual friends, and his own good
                     fortune in being permitted to come to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You may easily
                        believe,"</tei-said> said he, <tei-said data-origname="said">"how great was the difficulty to persuade my
                        father that it was not absolutely necessary for a merchant not to understand
                        any thing except book-keeping; and, indeed, I believe I left him incredulous
                        to the last, for his constant answer to my unwearied entreaties was the same
                        as that of the Dutch school-master in the <tei-title data-origname="title">Vicar of Wakefield</tei-title>:
                           <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I have ten thousand florins a year without Greek, I
                           eat heartily without Greek."</tei-said> But his affection for me at length
                        overcame his dislike of learning, and he has permitted me to undertake <tei-pb n="[1.106]" facs="pageImages/vol1/106.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> a voyage of discovery to the
                        land of knowledge."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"It gives me the greatest delight to see you; but tell me
                        how you left my father, brothers, and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Very well, and very happy, only a little uneasy that they
                        hear from you so seldom. By the bye, I mean to lecture you a little upon
                        their account myself.—But, my dear
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>,"</tei-said> continued he, stopping short, and
                     gazing full in my face, <tei-said data-origname="said">"I did not before remark how very ill you appear;
                        so thin and pale; you look as if you had been watching for several
                        nights."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You have guessed right; I have lately been so deeply
                        engaged in one occupation, that I have not allowed myself sufficient rest,
                        as you see: but I hope, I sincerely hope, that all these employments are now
                        at an end, and that I am at length free."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.107]" facs="pageImages/vol1/107.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I trembled excessively; I could not endure to think of, and far less to allude
                     to the occurrences of the preceding night. I walked with a quick pace, and we
                     soon arrived at my college. I then reflected, and the thought made me shiver,
                     that the creature whom I had left in my apartment might still be there, alive,
                     and walking about. I dreaded to behold this monster; but I feared still more
                     that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> should see him. Entreating him therefore to
                     remain a few minutes at the bottom of the stairs, I darted up towards my own
                     room. My hand was already on the lock of the door before I recollected myself.
                     I then paused; and a cold shivering came over me. I threw the door forcibly
                     open, as children are accustomed to do when they expect a spectre to stand in
                     waiting for them on the other side; but nothing <tei-pb n="[1.108]" facs="pageImages/vol1/108.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> appeared. I stepped fearfully in: the
                     apartment was empty; and my bed-room was also freed from its hideous guest. I
                     could hardly believe that so great a good-fortune could have befallen me; but
                     when I became assured that my enemy had indeed fled, I clapped my hands for
                     joy, and ran down to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We ascended into my room, and the servant presently brought breakfast; but I
                     was unable to contain myself. It was not joy only that possessed me; I felt my
                     flesh tingle with excess of sensitiveness, and my pulse beat rapidly. I was
                     unable to remain for a single instant in the same place; I jumped over the
                     chairs, clapped my hands, and laughed aloud. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> at
                     first attributed my unusual spirits to joy on his arrival; but when he observed
                     me more attentively, he saw a wildness in <tei-pb n="[1.109]" facs="pageImages/vol1/109.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> my eyes for which he could not account; and
                     my loud, unrestrained, heartless laughter, frightened and astonished him.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>,"</tei-said> cried he,
                        <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"what, for God's sake, is the matter? Do not laugh in
                        that manner. How ill you are! What is the cause of all this?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Do not ask me,"</tei-said> cried I, putting my hands before my
                     eyes, for I thought I saw the dreaded spectre glide into the room; <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"he can tell. —Oh, save me! save me!"</tei-said> I imagined that
                     the monster seized me; I struggled furiously, and fell down in a fit.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>! what must have been his feelings? A meeting,
                     which he anticipated with such joy, so strangely turned to bitterness. But I
                     was not the witness of his grief; for I was lifeless, and did not recover my
                     senses for a long, long time.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.110]" facs="pageImages/vol1/110.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This was the commencement of a nervous fever, which confined me for several
                     months. During all that time <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> was my only nurse. I
                     afterwards learned that, knowing my father's advanced age, and unfitness for so
                     long a journey, and how wretched my sickness would make
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, he spared them this grief by concealing the
                     extent of my disorder. He knew that I could not have a more kind and attentive
                     nurse than himself; and, firm in the hope he felt of my recovery, he did not
                     doubt that, instead of doing harm, he performed the kindest action that he
                     could towards them.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But I was in reality very ill; and surely nothing but the unbounded and
                     unremitting attentions of my friend could have restored me to life. The form of
                     the monster on whom I had bestowed existence was for ever before <tei-pb n="[1.111]" facs="pageImages/vol1/111.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> my eyes, and I raved
                     incessantly concerning him. Doubtless my words surprised
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>: he at first believed them to be the wanderings
                     of my disturbed imagination; but the pertinacity with which I continually
                     recurred to the same subject persuaded him that my disorder indeed owed its
                     origin to some uncommon and terrible event.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">By very slow degrees, and with frequent relapses that alarmed and grieved my
                     friend, I recovered. I remember the first time I became capable of observing
                     outward objects with any kind of pleasure, I perceived that the fallen leaves
                     had disappeared, and that the young buds were shooting forth from the trees
                     that shaded my window. It was a divine spring; and the season contributed
                     greatly to my convalescence. I felt also sentiments of joy and affection revive
                     in my bosom; my <tei-pb n="[1.112]" facs="pageImages/vol1/112.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> gloom
                     disappeared, and in a short time I became as cheerful as before I was attacked
                     by the fatal passion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Dearest <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>,"</tei-said> exclaimed I,
                        <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how kind, how very good you are to me. This whole
                        winter, instead of being spent in study, as you promised yourself, has been
                        consumed in my sick room. How shall I ever repay you? I feel the greatest
                        remorse for the disappointment of which I have been the occasion; but you
                        will forgive me."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You will repay me entirely, if you do not discompose
                        yourself, but get well as fast as you can; and since you appear in such good
                        spirits, I may speak to you on one subject, may I not?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I trembled. One subject! what could it be? Could he allude to an object on whom
                     I dared not even think?</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.113]" facs="pageImages/vol1/113.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Compose yourself,"</tei-said> said
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, who observed my change of colour, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I will not mention it, if it agitates you; but your father
                        and cousin would be very happy if they received a letter from you in your
                        own handwriting. They hardly know how ill you have been, and are uneasy at
                        your long silence."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Is that all? my dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>. How could
                        you suppose that my first thought would not fly towards those dear, dear
                        friends whom I love, and who are so deserving of my love."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"If this is your present temper, my friend, you will
                        perhaps be glad to see a letter that has been lying here some days for you:
                        it is from your cousin, I believe."</tei-said></tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="1.5" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[1.114]" facs="pageImages/vol1/114.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter V</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">CLERVAL</tei-persName> then put the following letter
                     into my hands.</tei-p>
                  <tei-floatingText data-origname="floatingText">


                     <tei-body data-origname="body">


                        <!-- question -->


                        <tei-opener data-origname="opener">To <tei-persName data-origname="persName">V. FRANKENSTEIN </tei-persName>
                           <tei-salute data-origname="salute">MY DEAR COUSIN</tei-salute></tei-opener>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I cannot describe to you the uneasiness we have all felt concerning your
                           health. We cannot help imagining that your friend
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> conceals the extent of your disorder: for
                           it is now several months since we have seen your hand-writing; and all
                           this time you have been obliged to dictate your letters to
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>. Surely, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, you
                           must have <tei-pb n="[1.115]" facs="pageImages/vol1/115.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> been
                           exceedingly ill; and this makes us all very wretched, as much so nearly
                           as after the death of your dear mother. My uncle was almost persuaded
                           that you were indeed dangerously ill, and could hardly be restrained from
                           undertaking a journey to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> always writes
                           that you are getting better; I eagerly hope that you will confirm this
                           intelligence soon in your own hand-writing; for indeed, indeed,
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, we are all very miserable on this
                           account. Relieve us from this fear, and we shall be the happiest
                           creatures in the world. Your father's health is now so vigorous, that he
                           appears ten years younger since last winter. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>
                           also is so much improved, that you would hardly know him: he is now
                           nearly sixteen, and has lost that sickly appearance which he had some
                           years ago; he is grown quite robust and active.</tei-p>


                        <tei-pb n="[1.116]" facs="pageImages/vol1/116.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">My uncle and I conversed a long time last night about what profession
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> should follow. His constant illness when
                           young has deprived him of the habits of application; and now that he
                           enjoys good health, he is continually in the open air, climbing the
                           hills, or rowing on the lake. I therefore proposed that he should be a
                           farmer; which you know, Cousin, is a favourite scheme of mine. A farmer's
                           is a very healthy happy life; and the least hurtful, or rather the most
                           beneficial profession of any. My uncle had an idea of his being educated
                           as an advocate, that through his interest he might become a judge. But,
                           besides that he is not at all fitted for such an occupation, it is
                           certainly more creditable to cultivate the earth for the sustenance of
                           man, than to be the confidant, and sometimes the accomplice, of his
                           vices; which is <tei-pb n="[1.117]" facs="pageImages/vol1/117.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the
                           profession of a lawyer. I said, that the employments of a prosperous
                           farmer, if they were not a more honourable, they were at least a happier
                           species of occupation than that of a judge, whose misfortune it was
                           always to meddle with the dark side of human nature. My uncle smiled, and
                           said, that I ought to be an advocate myself, which put an end to the
                           conversation on that subject.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">And now I must tell you a story that will please, and perhaps amuse you.
                           Do you not remember <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine Moritz</tei-persName>? Probably you do
                           not; I will relate her history, therefore, in a few words. Madame
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Moritz</tei-persName>, her mother, was a widow with four
                           children, of whom <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was the third. This girl
                           had always been the favourite of her father; but, through a strange
                           perversity, her mother could not endure <tei-pb n="[1.118]" facs="pageImages/vol1/118.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> her, and, after the death of M.
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Moritz</tei-persName>, treated her very ill. My aunt observed
                           this; and, when <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was twelve years of age,
                           prevailed on her mother to allow her to live at her house. The republican
                           institutions of our country have produced simpler and happier manners
                           than those which prevail in the great monarchies that surround it. Hence
                           there is less distinction between the several classes of its inhabitants;
                           and the lower orders being neither so poor nor so despised, their manners
                           are more refined and moral. A servant in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName> does not mean the same thing as a
                           servant in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName> and
                              <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>.
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, thus received in our family, learned the
                           duties of a servant; a condition which, in our fortunate country, does
                           not include the idea of ignorance, and a sacrifice of the dignity of a
                           human being.</tei-p>


                        <tei-pb n="[1.119]" facs="pageImages/vol1/119.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">After what I have said, I dare say you well remember the heroine of my
                           little tale: for <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was a great favourite of
                           your's; and I recollect you once remarked, that if you were in an ill
                           humour, one glance from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> could dissipate it,
                           for the same reason that <tei-ref target="Ariosto_" corresp="Ariosto" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">
                              <tei-persName type="n79041715" key="n79041715" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type"> Ariosto </tei-persName>
                           </tei-ref> gives concerning the beauty of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Angelica</tei-persName>
                           <tei-note xml:id="Ariosto" id="Ariosto" target="Ariosto_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                              <tei-graphic url="http://www.britishmuseum.org/collectionimages/AN01270/AN01270858_001_l.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/> Victor references <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Ludovico-Ariosto" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Ludovico Ariosto (1474-1533)</tei-ref>, an Italian poet from the 16th
                              century, when talking about Justine’s "frank-hearted and happy"
                              expression. In <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://archive.org/stream/orlandofuriosoin01arioiala?ref=ol#page/n5" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Orlando Furioso</tei-ref></tei-hi>, the first 10 stanzas of Canto 10
                              describe the cause of female desirability as resistance and flight,
                              using in stanza 7 a classical hunting metaphor to do so: "So the keen
                              hunter follows up the hare / In heat and cold, on shore, or
                              mountain-height; / Nor, when 'tis taken, more esteems the prize; / And
                              only hurries after that which flies" (10.7.5-8). While it is not clear
                              that this is "the reason…[for] the beauty of Angelica," Ita Mac Carthy
                              points out in <tei-ref target="https://books.google.com/books?id=HNKB32q1dJoC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Women and the Making of Poetry in Ariosto's
                                    Orlando Furioso</tei-hi></tei-ref> (Chapter 3) that Angelica is the
                              "supreme object of [unattainable] desire" who repeatedly flees sexual
                              pursuit and generates the narrative of the poem. Her beauty is
                              described as angelic, and capable of making her suitors--like the
                              titular Orlando--lose their wits. In Ariosto’s epic romance, Angelica
                              is a pagan princess besought by many knights. The image here shows a
                              scene from <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Orlando Furioso</tei-hi> of a man bending
                              over and holding the hand of a woman, presumably Angelica, who sits on
                              the ground beneath a tree, the trunk inscribed "ANCE MEDO," created by
                              Angelica Kauffman (1740-1807) and hosted by the British museum.
                           </tei-note>—she looked so frank-hearted and happy. My aunt conceived a great
                           attachment for her, by which she was induced to give her an education
                           superior to that which she had at first intended. This benefit was fully
                           repaid; <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was the most grateful little
                           creature in the world: I do not mean that she made any professions, I
                           never heard one pass her lips; but you could see by her eyes that she
                           almost adored her protectress. Although her disposition was gay, and in
                           many respects inconsiderate, yet she paid the <tei-pb n="[1.120]" facs="pageImages/vol1/120.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> greatest attention to every gesture
                           of my aunt. She thought her the model of all excellence, and endeavoured
                           to imitate her phraseology and manners, so that even now she often
                           reminds me of her.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">When my dearest aunt died, everyone was too much occupied in their own
                           grief to notice poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, who had attended her
                           during her illness with the most anxious affection. Poor
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was very ill; but other trials were
                           reserved for her.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">One by one, her brothers and sister died; and her mother, with the
                           exception of her neglected daughter, was left childless. The conscience
                           of the woman was troubled; she began to think that the deaths of her
                           favourites was a judgment from heaven to chastise her partiality. She was
                           a Roman Catholic; and I believe her confessor confirmed <tei-pb n="[1.121]" facs="pageImages/vol1/121.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the idea which she had conceived.
                           Accordingly, a few months after your departure for <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was
                           called home by her repentant mother. Poor girl! she wept when she quitted
                           our house: she was much altered since the death of my aunt; grief had
                           given softness and a winning mildness to her manners, which had before
                           been remarkable for vivacity. Nor was her residence at her mother's house
                           of a nature to restore her gaiety. The poor woman was very vacillating in
                           her repentance. She sometimes begged <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> to
                           forgive her unkindness, but much oftener accused her of having caused the
                           deaths of her brothers and sister. Perpetual fretting at length threw
                           Madame <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Moritz</tei-persName> into a decline, which at first
                           increased her irritability, but she is now at peace forever. She died on
                           the first approach of cold <tei-pb n="[1.122 - page breaks after 'wea']" facs="pageImages/vol1/122.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> weather, at the beginning of this
                           last winter. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> has returned to us; and I
                           assure you I love her tenderly. She is very clever and gentle, and
                           extremely pretty; as I mentioned before, her mien and her expressions
                           continually remind me of my dear aunt.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I must say also a few words to you, my dear cousin, of little darling
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>. I wish you could see him; he is very
                           tall of his age, with sweet laughing blue eyes, dark eye-lashes, and
                           curling hair. When he smiles, two little dimples appear on each cheek,
                           which are rosy with health. He has already had one or two little wives,
                           but <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Louisa Biron</tei-persName> is his favourite, a pretty little
                           girl of five years of age.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">Now, dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, I dare say you wish to be indulged
                           in a little gossip concerning the good people of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. The pretty Miss
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mansfield</tei-persName> has already <tei-pb n="[1.123]" facs="pageImages/vol1/123.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> received the congratulatory visits on
                           her approaching marriage with a young Englishman, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">John
                              Melbourne</tei-persName>, Esq. Her ugly sister,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Manon</tei-persName>, married M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Duvillard</tei-persName>,
                           the rich banker, last autumn. Your favourite schoolfellow,
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Louis Manoir</tei-persName>, has suffered several misfortunes
                           since the departure of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> from Geneva. But he
                           has already recovered his spirits, and is reported to be on the point of
                           marrying a very lively pretty Frenchwoman, Madame
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Tavernier</tei-persName>. She is a widow, and much older than
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Manoir</tei-persName>; but she is very much admired, and a
                           favourite with every body.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I have written myself into good spirits, dear cousin; yet I cannot
                           conclude without again anxiously inquiring concerning your health. Dear
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, if you are not very ill, write yourself,
                           and make your father and all <tei-pb n="[1.124]" facs="pageImages/vol1/124.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of us happy; or -- I cannot bear to
                           think of the other side of the question; my tears already flow. Adieu, my
                           dearest cousin.</tei-p>


                        <tei-closer data-origname="closer"><tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ELIZABETH LAVENZA</tei-persName></tei-signed>. <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, <tei-date data-origname="date">March 18th,
                              17--</tei-date>.</tei-closer>


                     </tei-body>


                  </tei-floatingText>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Dear, dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>!"</tei-said> I
                     exclaimed when I had read her letter, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I will write
                        instantly, and relieve them from the anxiety they must feel."</tei-said> I
                     wrote, and this exertion greatly fatigued me; but my convalescence had
                     commenced, and proceeded regularly. In another fortnight I was able to leave my
                     chamber.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">One of my first duties on my recovery was to introduce
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> to the several professors of the university. In
                     doing this, I underwent a kind of rough usage, ill befitting the wounds that my
                     mind had sustained. Ever since the <tei-pb n="[1.125]" facs="pageImages/vol1/125.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> fatal night, the end of my labours, and the
                     beginning of my misfortunes, I had conceived a violent antipathy even to the
                     name of natural philosophy. When I was otherwise quite restored to health, the
                     sight of a chemical instrument would renew all the agony of my nervous
                     symptoms. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> saw this, and had removed all my apparatus
                     from my view. He had also changed my apartment; for he perceived that I had
                     acquired a dislike for the room which had previously been my laboratory. But
                     these cares of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> were made of no avail when I
                     visited the professors. M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Waldman</tei-persName> inflicted torture when
                     he praised, with kindness and warmth, the astonishing progress I had made in
                     the sciences. He soon perceived that I disliked the subject; but, not guessing
                     the real cause, he attributed my feelings to modesty, and <tei-pb n="[1.126]" facs="pageImages/vol1/126.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> changed the subject from my improvement to
                     the science itself, with a desire, as I evidently saw, of drawing me out. What
                     could I do? He meant to please, and he tormented me. I felt as if he had placed
                     carefully, one by one, in my view those instruments which were to be afterwards
                     used in putting me to a slow and cruel death. I writhed under his words, yet
                     dared not exhibit the pain I felt. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, whose eyes and
                     feelings were always quick in discerning the sensations of others, declined the
                     subject, alleging, in excuse, his total ignorance; and the conversation took a
                     more general turn. I thanked my friend from my heart, but I did not speak. I
                     saw plainly that he was surprised, but he never attempted to draw my secret
                     from me; and although I loved him with a mixture of affection and reverence
                     that knew no <tei-pb n="[1.127]" facs="pageImages/vol1/127.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> bounds, yet I
                     could never persuade myself to confide to him that event which was so often
                     present to my recollection, but which I feared the detail to another would only
                     impress more deeply.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Krempe</tei-persName> was not equally docile; and in my condition at
                     that time, of almost insupportable sensitiveness, his harsh blunt encomiums
                     gave me even more pain than the benevolent approbation of M.
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Waldman</tei-persName>. <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"D--n the fellow!"</tei-said>
                     cried he; <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"why, M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, I assure
                        you he has outstript us all. Aye, stare if you please; but it is
                        nevertheless true. A youngster who, but a few years ago, believed <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n80043375" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Cornelius Agrippa</tei-persName> as firmly as
                        the gospel, has now set himself at the head of the university; and if he is
                        not soon pulled down, we shall all be out of countenance.—Aye, aye,"</tei-said>
                     continued he, <tei-pb n="[1.128 - page breaks after 'ob-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/128.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> observing my face expressive of suffering,
                        <tei-said who="#krempe" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName> is modest; an
                        excellent quality in a young man. Young men should be diffident of
                        themselves, you know, M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>; I was myself when
                        young; but that wears out in a very short time."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">M. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Krempe</tei-persName> had now commenced an eulogy on himself, which
                     happily turned the conversation from a subject that was so annoying to me.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> was no natural philosopher. His imagination was
                     too vivid for the minutiae of science. Languages were his principal study; and
                     he sought, but acquiring their elements, to open a field for self-instruction
                     on his return to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>.
                     Persian, Arabic, and Hebrew, gained his attention, after he had made himself
                     perfectly master of Greek and Latin. For my own part, idleness had ever been
                     irksome to me, and now that I wished <tei-pb n="[1.129]" facs="pageImages/vol1/129.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> to fly from reflection, and hated my former
                     studies, I felt great relief in being the fellow-pupil with my friend, and
                     found not only instruction but consolation in the works of the orientalists.
                     Their melancholy is soothing, and their joy elevating to a degree I never
                     experienced in studying the authors of any other country. When you read their
                     writings, life appears to consist in a warm sun and garden of roses, in the
                     smiles and frowns of a fair enemy, and the fire that consumes your own heart.
                     How different from the manly and heroical poetry of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Greece</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7000874" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rome</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
