                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Summer passed away in these occupations, and my return to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName> was fixed for the latter end of autumn; but
                     being delayed by several accidents, winter and snow arrived, the roads were
                     deemed impassable, and my journey was retarded until the ensuing spring. <tei-pb n="[1.130]" facs="pageImages/vol1/130.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I felt this delay very
                     bitterly; for I longed to see my native town, and my beloved friends. My return
                     had only been delayed so long from an unwillingness to leave
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> in a strange place, before he had become
                     acquainted with any of its inhabitants. The winter, however, was spent
                     cheerfully; and although the spring was uncommonly late, when it came, its
                     beauty compensated for its dilatoriness.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The month of <tei-date data-origname="date">May</tei-date> had already commenced, and I expected the letter
                     daily which was to fix the date of my departure, when
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> proposed a pedestrian tour in the environs of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName> that I might bid
                     a personal farewell to the country I had so long inhabited. I acceded with
                     pleasure to this proposition: I was fond of exercise, and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> had always been my favourite companion in the
                     rambles of this nature that I had <tei-pb n="[1.131]" facs="pageImages/vol1/131.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> taken among the scenes of my native
                     country.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We passed a fortnight in these perambulations; my health and spirits had long
                     been restored, and they gained additional strength from the salubrious air I
                     breathed, the natural incidents of our progress, and the conversation of my
                     friend. Study had before secluded me from the intercourse of my
                     fellow-creatures, and rendered me unsocial; but <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>
                     called forth the better feelings of my heart; he again taught me to love the
                     aspect of nature, and the cheerful faces of children. Excellent friend! how
                     sincerely did you love me, and endeavour to elevate my mind, until it was on a
                     level with your own. A selfish pursuit had cramped and narrowed me, until your
                     gentleness and affection warmed and opened my senses; I became the same happy
                     creature who, <tei-pb n="[1.132]" facs="pageImages/vol1/132.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> a few years ago,
                     loving and beloved by all, had no sorrow or care. When happy, inanimate nature
                     had the power of bestowing on me the most delightful sensations. A serene sky
                     and verdant fields filled me with ecstasy. The present season was indeed
                     divine; the flowers of spring bloomed in the hedges, while those of summer were
                     already in bud: I was undisturbed by thoughts which during the preceding year
                     had pressed upon me, notwithstanding my endeavours to throw them off, with an
                     invincible burden.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> rejoiced in my gaiety, and sincerely sympathized in
                     my feelings: he exerted himself to amuse me, while he expressed the sensations
                     that filled his soul. The resources of his mind on this occasion were truly
                     astonishing: his conversation was full of imagination; and very often, in
                     imitation <tei-pb n="[1.133]" facs="pageImages/vol1/133.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of the Persian and
                     Arabic writers, he invented tales of wonderful fancy and passion. At other
                     times he repeated my favourite poems, or drew me out into arguments, which he
                     supported with great ingenuity.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We returned to our college on a Sunday afternoon: the peasants were dancing,
                     and every one we met appeared gay and happy. My own spirits were high, and I
                     bounded along with feelings of unbridled joy and hilarity.</tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="1.6" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[1.134]" facs="pageImages/vol1/134.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter VI</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">ON my return, I found the following letter from my
                     father:—</tei-p>
                  <tei-floatingText data-origname="floatingText">


                     <tei-body data-origname="body">


                        <tei-opener data-origname="opener">To <tei-persName data-origname="persName">V. FRANKENSTEIN.</tei-persName>
                           <tei-salute data-origname="salute">MY DEAR VICTOR,</tei-salute></tei-opener>







                        <tei-p data-origname="p">You have probably waited impatiently for a letter to fix the date of your
                           return to us; and I was at first tempted to write only a few lines,
                           merely mentioning the day on which I should expect you. But that would be
                           a cruel kindness, and I dare not do it. What would be your surprise, my
                           son, when <tei-pb n="[1.135]" facs="pageImages/vol1/135.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> you expected a
                           happy and gay welcome, to behold, on the contrary, tears and
                           wretchedness? And how, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, can I relate our
                           misfortune? Absence cannot have rendered you callous to our joys and
                           griefs; and how shall I inflict pain on an absent child? I wish to
                           prepare you for the woeful news, but I know it is impossible; even now
                           your eye skims over the page, to seek the words which are to convey to
                           you the horrible tidings.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> is dead!—that sweet child, whose smiles
                           delighted and warmed my heart, who was so gentle, yet so gay!
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, he is murdered!</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">I will not attempt to console you; but will simply relate the
                           circumstances of the transaction.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">Last Thursday (<tei-date data-origname="date">May 7th</tei-date>) I, my niece, and your two brothers,
                           went to walk in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="4012616" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Plainpalais</tei-placeName>. The evening was <tei-pb n="[1.136]" facs="pageImages/vol1/136.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> warm and serene, and we prolonged our
                           walk farther than usual. It was already dusk before we thought of
                           returning; and then we discovered that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> and
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>, who had gone on before, were not to be
                           found. We accordingly rested on a seat until they should return.
                           Presently <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> came, and inquired if we had seen
                           his brother: he said, that they had been playing together, that
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> had run away to hide himself, and that he
                           vainly sought for him, and afterwards waited for him a long time, but
                           that he did not return.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">This account rather alarmed us, and we continued to search for him until
                           night fell, when <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> conjectured that he might
                           have returned to the house. He was not there. We returned again, with
                           torches; for I could not rest, when I thought that my sweet <tei-pb n="[1.137]" facs="pageImages/vol1/137.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> boy had lost himself, and
                           was exposed to all the damps and dews of night;
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> also suffered extreme anguish. About
                           five in the morning I discovered my lovely boy, whom the night before I
                           had seen blooming and active in health, stretched on the grass livid and
                           motionless: the print of the murderer's finger was on his neck.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">He was conveyed home, and the anguish that was visible in my countenance
                           betrayed the secret to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. She was very
                           earnest to see the corpse. At first I attempted to prevent her; but she
                           persisted, and entering the room where it lay, hastily examined the neck
                           of the victim, and clasping her hands, exclaimed, O God! I have murdered
                           my darling infant!</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">She fainted, and was restored with extreme difficulty. When she again
                           lived, it was only to weep and sigh. <tei-pb n="[1.138]" facs="pageImages/vol1/138.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> She told me that that same evening
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> had teazed her to let him wear a very
                           valuable miniature that she possessed of your mother. This picture is
                           gone, and was doubtless the temptation which urged the murderer to the
                           deed. We have no trace of him at present, although our exertions to
                           discover him are unremitted; but they will not restore my beloved
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>.</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">Come, dearest <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>; you alone can console
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. She weeps continually, and accuses
                           herself unjustly as the cause of his death; her words pierce my heart. We
                           are all unhappy; but will not that be an additional motive for you, my
                           son, to return and be our comforter? Your dear mother! Alas,
                              <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>! I now say, Thank God she did not live to
                           witness the cruel, miserable death of her youngest darling!</tei-p>


                        <tei-p data-origname="p">Come, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>; not brooding thoughts <tei-pb n="[1.139]" facs="pageImages/vol1/139.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of vengeance against the assassin,
                           but with feelings of peace and gentleness, that will heal, instead of
                           festering the wounds of our minds. Enter the house of mourning, my
                           friend, but with kindness and affection for those who love you, and not
                           with hatred for your enemies.</tei-p>







                        <tei-closer data-origname="closer"><tei-salute data-origname="salute">Your affectionate and afflicted father,</tei-salute>
                           <tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ALPHONSE FRANKENSTEIN</tei-persName>.</tei-signed>
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, <tei-date data-origname="date">May 12th,
                              17--</tei-date>.</tei-closer>


                     </tei-body>


                  </tei-floatingText>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, who had watched my countenance as I read this
                     letter, was surprised to observe the despair that succeeded to the joy I at
                     first expressed on receiving news from my friends. I threw the letter on the
                     table, and covered my face with my hands.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>,"</tei-said>
                     exclaimed <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>, when he perceived me weep with
                     bitterness, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"are you always to be <tei-pb n="[1.140]" facs="pageImages/vol1/140.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> unhappy? My dear friend, what has
                        happened?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I motioned to him to take up the letter, while I walked up and down the room in
                     the extremest agitation. Tears also gushed from the eyes of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, as he read the account of my misfortune.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I can offer you no consolation, my friend,"</tei-said> said
                     he; <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"your disaster is irreparable. What do you intend to
                        do?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"To go instantly to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>: come with me, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>, to order
                        the horses."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">During our walk, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> endeavoured to raise my spirits.
                     He did not do this by common topics of consolation, but by exhibiting the
                     truest sympathy. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Poor
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>!"</tei-said> said he, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"that
                        dear child; he now sleeps with his angel mother. His friends mourn and weep,
                        but he is at rest: he does not <tei-pb n="[1.141]" facs="pageImages/vol1/141.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> now feel the murderer's grasp; a sod
                        covers his gentle form, and he knows no pain. He can no longer be a fit
                        subject for pity; the survivors are the greatest sufferers, and for them
                        time is the only consolation. Those maxims of the Stoics, that death was no
                        evil, and that the mind of man ought to be superior to despair on the
                        eternal absence of a beloved object, ought not to be urged. Even <tei-ref target="_cato" corresp="cato" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> Cato </tei-ref>
                        <tei-note xml:id="cato" id="cato" target="_cato" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                           <tei-graphic url="http://www.britishmuseum.org/collectionimages/AN00530/AN00530505_001_l.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Marcus-Porcius-Cato-Roman-senator-95-46-BC" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Marcus Porcius Cato Uticensis</tei-ref> (95 BC-46 BC), also known as Cato
                           the Younger, was a Roman statesman known for his sense of justice and
                           fairness. Cato was immensely close to his brother, Caepio, and when his
                           brother passed, Cato spared no expense for his funeral. Clerval invokes
                           this sentiment when he tells Victor, "even Cato wept over the dead body
                           of his brother." Read more about Cato in Plutarch’s <tei-ref target="http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Cato_Minor*.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Parallel Lives</tei-hi></tei-ref>. <tei-ref target="http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=3021685" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The image of Cato, above, housed in the British Museum</tei-ref>, is an
                           etching from Lucan's <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Pharsalia</tei-hi>, Book IX (1718).
                        </tei-note> wept over the dead body of his brother."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> spoke thus as we hurried through the streets; the
                     words impressed themselves on my mind, and I remembered them afterwards in
                     solitude. But now, as soon as the horses arrived, I hurried into a cabriole,
                     and bade farewell to my friend.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My journey was very melancholy. At first I wished to hurry on, for I longed to
                     console and sympathize with <tei-pb n="[1.142]" facs="pageImages/vol1/142.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> my
                     loved and sorrowing friends; but when I drew near my native town, I slackened
                     my progress. I could hardly sustain the multitude of feelings that crowded into
                     my mind. I passed through scenes familiar to my youth, but which I had not seen
                     for nearly six years. How altered every thing might be during that time? One
                     sudden and desolating change had taken place; but a thousand little
                     circumstances might have by degrees worked other alterations, which, although
                     they were done more tranquilly, might not be the less decisive. Fear overcame
                     me; I dared not advance, dreading a thousand nameless evils that made me
                     tremble, although I was unable to define them.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I remained two days at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007299" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Lausanne</tei-placeName>, in this painful state of mind. I contemplated the lake:
                     the waters were placid; all around was calm, and the snowy <tei-pb n="[1.143]" facs="pageImages/vol1/143.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> mountains, <tei-quote data-origname="quote">"<tei-ref target="_Byron" corresp="Byron" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target">the palaces of nature</tei-ref>,"</tei-quote> were not changed.
                     By degrees the calm and heavenly scene restored me, and I continued my journey
                     towards <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>.</tei-p><tei-note xml:id="Byron" id="Byron" target="_Byron" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#TH" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">An
                     allusion to <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Childe Harold's Pilgrimage</tei-hi> (1812-1818), a
                     somewhat autobiographical narrative poem in four cantos by Romantic poet <tei-ref target="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Byron" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">George Gordon Lord Byron
                        (1788-1824)</tei-ref>, which "The poem tells of a disillusioned young man, a
                     melancholy, solitary, cynical ‘Byronic hero’, who tires of his sinful,
                     pleasure-seeking lifestyle and decides to travel" (<tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/works/childe-harolds-pilgrimage" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">British
                        Library</tei-ref>). This line is from Canto III: <tei-quote data-origname="quote">But these recede. Above
                        me are the Alps,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠The Palaces of Nature, whose vast walls<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠Have pinnacled in clouds their snowy scalps,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠And throned Eternity in icy halls<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠Of cold Sublimity, where forms and falls<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠The
                        Avalanche—the thunderbolt of snow!<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠All that
                        expands the spirit, yet appals,<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> ⁠<tei-hi rend="indent" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend" data-empty=""/>⁠Gather around
                        these summits, as to show<tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/> How Earth may pierce to Heaven, yet leave
                        vain man below.</tei-quote>
                     <tei-ref target="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/aug/12/byron-childe-harold-benjamin-markovits" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Read more about Byron's poem at <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The
                     Guardian</tei-hi>.</tei-ref></tei-note>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The road ran by the side of the lake, which became narrower as I approached my
                     native town. I discovered more distinctly the black sides of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1109172" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Jura</tei-placeName>, and the bright summit of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7617157" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont Blanc</tei-placeName>; I wept like a
                     child: <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Dear mountains! my own beautiful lake! how do you
                        welcome your wanderer? Your summits are clear; the sky and lake are blue and
                        placid. Is this to prognosticate peace, or to mock at my
                        unhappiness?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I fear, my friend, that I shall render myself tedious by dwelling on these
                     preliminary circumstances; but they were days of comparative happiness, and I
                     think of them with pleasure. My <tei-pb n="[1.144]" facs="pageImages/vol1/144.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> country, my beloved country! who but a native can tell the delight I took in
                     again beholding thy streams, thy mountains, and, more than all, thy lovely
                     lake!</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Yet, as I drew nearer home, grief and fear again overcame me. Night also closed
                     around; and when I could hardly see the dark mountains, I felt still more
                     gloomily. The picture appeared a vast and dim scene of evil, and I foresaw
                     obscurely that I was destined to become the most wretched of human beings.
                     Alas! I prophesied truly, and failed only in one single circumstance, that in
                     all the misery I imagined and dreaded, I did not conceive the hundredth part of
                     the anguish I was destined to endure.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It was completely dark when I arrived in the environs of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>; the gates of the town were already shut;
                     and I was obliged to pass the night at <tei-pb n="[1.145]" facs="pageImages/vol1/145.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8703954" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Secheron</tei-placeName>, a village half a
                     league to the east of the city. The sky was serene; and, as I was unable to
                     rest, I resolved to visit the spot where my poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>
                     had been murdered. As I could not pass through the town, I was obliged to cross
                     the lake in a boat to arrive at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="4012616" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Plainpalais</tei-placeName>. During this short voyage I saw the lightnings
                     playing on the summit of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7617157" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont
                        Blanc</tei-placeName> in the most beautiful figures. The storm appeared to
                     approach rapidly; and, on landing, I ascended a low hill, that I might observe
                     its progress. It advanced; the heavens were clouded, and I soon felt the rain
                     coming slowly in large drops, but its violence quickly increased.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I quitted my seat, and walked on, although the darkness and storm increased
                     every minute, and the thunder burst with a terrific crash over my head. It was
                     echoed from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1106285" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Salêve</tei-placeName>, the <tei-pb n="[1.146]" facs="pageImages/vol1/146.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1109172" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Juras</tei-placeName>, and the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007768" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Alps of Savoy</tei-placeName>; vivid flashes of
                     lightning dazzled my eyes, illuminating the lake, making it appear like a vast
                     sheet of fire; then for an instant everything seemed of a pitchy darkness,
                     until the eye recovered itself from the preceding flash. The storm, as is often
                     the case in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">
                        <tei-ref target="Switzerland_Frankenstein_Trail_" corresp="Switzerland_Frankenstein_Trail" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> Switzerland </tei-ref>
                     </tei-placeName>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Switzerland_Frankenstein_Trail" id="Switzerland_Frankenstein_Trail" target="Switzerland_Frankenstein_Trail_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                        <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Genf_panorama.jpg" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/place/Switzerland" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Switzerland</tei-ref>
                        is not only the setting of most of the novel but also the place that
                        inspired Mary Shelley to write <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>. As
                        Switzerland was the birthplace of the novel, many people follow the
                        "Frankenstein Trail" and have written about the experience. See Tony
                        Perrottet’s article in <tei-ref target="https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/29/travel/lake-geneva-as-byron-and-shelley-knew-it.html" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                           <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The New York Times</tei-hi></tei-ref> and Nigel Richardson’s in
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/switzerland/articles/on-the-frankenstein-trail-in-switzerland/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">
                           <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Telegraph</tei-hi></tei-ref> for wonderful descriptions of
                        the landscape and countryside. In honor of the 200th anniversary of the
                        novel, an art collective KLAT created and erected a bronze cast statue of
                        the <tei-ref target="https://youtu.be/oKa2-d_9IBU" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Creature</tei-ref> in the city of
                        Plainpolis. The image here is a panorama taken by Attila Terbócs of the view
                        of Geneva from the top of St. Peter’s Cathedral and it is hosted on
                        Wikimedia Commons. In the summer of 1814, Mary Shelley and her then-lover,
                        Percy Shelley, travelled in secret to the continent, visiting France,
                        Switzerland, Germany, and the Netherlands. The couple published a collection
                        of letters about their travels, titled <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://archive.org/details/sixweekhistoryof00shelrich" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">History of a Six-Week Tour</tei-ref></tei-hi>. In Letter II, Switzerland is
                        depicted as a place "with more equality of classes...than in England" (103);
                        this interest in the freer and more natural lives of the "lower orders"
                        (103) was also central to the Romantic ideology. <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/collection-items/mary-shelleys-history-of-a-six-weeks-tour" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">As the discussion of the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Six Week History</tei-hi> on the
                           British Library website makes clear</tei-ref>, this idea is "echoed in
                        chapter 6 of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, where Elizabeth writes
                        ‘the lower orders, being neither so poor nor so despised, their manners are
                        more refined and moral’."</tei-note> , appeared at once in various parts of the
                     heavens. The most violent storm hung exactly north of the town, over that part
                     of the lake which lies between the promontory of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8703247" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Belrive</tei-placeName> and the village of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1064001" cert="medium" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="cert key type">Copêt</tei-placeName>. Another storm enlightened
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1109172" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Jura</tei-placeName> with faint flashes; and
                     another darkened and sometimes disclosed the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7631625" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Môle</tei-placeName>, a peaked mountain to the east of the
                     lake.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-ref target="Romanticism_" corresp="Romanticism" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> While I watched the storm, so
                        beautiful yet terrific , I wandered on with a hasty step. This noble war in
                        the sky elevated my spirits; I clasped my hands, </tei-ref>
                     <tei-note xml:id="Romanticism" id="Romanticism" target="Romanticism_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">In order to truly explain the Romantic imagery
                        throughout the text, one must have a full understanding of what constitutes
                        Romanticism. Romanticism has little to do with feelings of romance and more
                        to do with a philosophical way of thinking that prioritizes imagination,
                        nature, and the self. Romanticism began in England and Germany (two
                        countries not home to the romance languages begotten from Vulgar Latin),
                        most notably with the poets <tei-ref target="https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/william-wordsworth" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">William
                           Wordsworth</tei-ref>, <tei-ref target="https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/john-keats" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">John
                           Keats</tei-ref>, <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Taylor-Coleridge" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Samuel Taylor Coleridge</tei-ref>, and <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/biography/Johann-Wolfgang-von-Goethe" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</tei-ref>. The early Romantic period is one of
                        revolutionary thought heavily influenced with the American and French
                        revolutions. These revolutions are important to note as they changed the
                        political and individual structure and thought of their countries,
                        overthrowing monarchies and creating democracies. The Romantics valued
                        imagination over reason as the imagination was the primary method of
                        creation. Nature, to the Romantics, was a work of art created by the divine
                        imagination, full of symbolism and meaning. Nature plays a central symbolic
                        role in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>. Victor’s mood is often
                        reflected in the nature he observes around him, and once he creates the
                        Creature, he describes storms and ominous natural elements meant to instill
                        foreboding in the reader. However, nature is also beautiful and could only
                        be created by a higher power, so while it mimics Victor’s interior state of
                        duress, it is also a reminder that something is a more powerful and a better
                        creator than Victor, whose creation is “grotesque" and “malformed." To learn
                        more about Romanticism, read Glen Levin Swiggett’s article <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/27530553" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"What is
                           Romanticism?"</tei-ref> or explore the <tei-ref target="https://www.bl.uk/romantics-and-victorians/themes/romanticism" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">British Library’s resources on Romanticism</tei-ref>.</tei-note><tei-pb n="[1.147]" facs="pageImages/vol1/147.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and exclaimed aloud, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"<tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>, dear angel! this is thy funeral, this thy
                        dirge!"</tei-said> As I said these words, I perceived in the gloom a figure
                     which stole from behind a clump of trees near me; I stood fixed, gazing
                     intently: I could not be mistaken. A flash of lightning illuminated the object,
                     and discovered its shape plainly to me; its gigantic stature, and the deformity
                     of its aspect, more hideous than belongs to humanity, instantly informed me
                     that it was the wretch, the filthy dæmon, to whom I had given life. What did he
                     there? Could he be (I shuddered at the conception) the murderer of my brother?
                     No sooner did that idea cross my imagination, than I became convinced of its
                     truth; my teeth chattered, and I was forced to lean against a tree for support.
                     The figure passed me quickly, and I lost <tei-pb n="[1.148]" facs="pageImages/vol1/148.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> it in the gloom. Nothing in human shape
                     could have destroyed that fair child. He was the murderer! I could not doubt
                     it. The mere presence of the idea was an irresistible proof of the fact. I
                     thought of pursuing the devil; but it would have been in vain, for another
                     flash discovered him to me hanging among the rocks of the nearly perpendicular
                     ascent of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1106285" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont Salêve</tei-placeName>, a hill
                     that bounds <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="4012616" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Plainpalais</tei-placeName> on the
                     south. He soon reached the summit, and disappeared.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I remained motionless. The thunder ceased; but the rain still continued, and
                     the scene was enveloped in an impenetrable darkness. I revolved in my mind the
                     events which I had until now sought to forget: the whole train of my progress
                     towards the creation; the appearance of the work of my own hands alive at my
                     bed-side; its <tei-pb n="[1.149 - page breaks after 'depar-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/149.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> departure. Two years had now nearly elapsed
                     since the night on which he first received life; and was this his first crime?
                     Alas! I had turned loose into the world a depraved wretch, whose delight was in
                     carnage and misery; had he not murdered my brother?</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">No one can conceive the anguish I suffered during the remainder of the night,
                     which I spent, cold and wet, in the open air. But I did not feel the
                     inconvenience of the weather; my imagination was busy in scenes of evil and
                     despair. I considered the being whom I had cast among mankind, and endowed with
                     the will and power to effect purposes of horror, such as the deed which he had
                     now done, nearly in the light of my own vampire, my own spirit let loose from
                     the grave, and forced to destroy all that was dear to me.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Day dawned; and I directed my steps <tei-pb n="[1.150]" facs="pageImages/vol1/150.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> towards the town. The gates were open; and
                     I hastened to my father's house. My first thought was to discover what I knew
                     of the murderer, and cause instant pursuit to be made. But I paused when I
                     reflected on the story that I had to tell. A being whom I myself had formed,
                     and endued with life, had met me at midnight among the precipices of an
                     inaccessible mountain. I remembered also the nervous fever with which I had
                     been seized just at the time that I dated my creation, and which would give an
                     air of delirium to a tale otherwise so utterly improbable. I well knew that if
                     any other had communicated such a relation to me, I should have looked upon it
                     as the ravings of insanity. Besides, the strange nature of the animal would
                     elude all pursuit, even if I were so far credited as to persuade my relatives
                     to commence it. <tei-pb n="[1.151]" facs="pageImages/vol1/151.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> Besides, of
                     what use would be pursuit? Who could arrest a creature capable of scaling the
                     overhanging sides of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1106285" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont
                        Salêve</tei-placeName>? These reflections determined me, and I resolved to
                     remain silent.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It was about five in the morning when I entered my father's house. I told the
                     servants not to disturb the family, and went into the library to attend their
                     usual hour of rising.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Six years had elapsed, passed as a dream but for one indelible trace, and I
                     stood in the same place where I had last embraced my father before my departure
                     for <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>. Beloved and
                     respectable parent! He still remained to me. I gazed on the picture of my
                     mother, which stood over the mantlepiece. It was an historical subject, painted
                     at my father's desire, and represented <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Caroline Beaufort</tei-persName>
                     in an <tei-pb n="[1.152 - page breaks after 'ago-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/152.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> agony of despair, kneeling by the coffin of her dead father. Her garb was
                     rustic, and her cheek pale; but there was an air of dignity and beauty, that
                     hardly permitted the sentiment of pity. Below this picture was a miniature of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>; and my tears flowed when I looked upon it.
                     While I was thus engaged, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> entered: he had heard me
                     arrive, and hastened to welcome me. He expressed a sorrowful delight to see me:
                        <tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Welcome, my dearest
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>,"</tei-said> said he. <tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Ah! I
                        wish you had come three months ago, and then you would have found us all
                        joyous and delighted. But we are now unhappy; and, I am afraid, tears
                        instead of smiles will be your welcome. Our father looks so sorrowful: this
                        dreadful event seems to have revived in his mind his grief on the death of
                        Mamma. Poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> also is quite
                        inconsolable."</tei-said>
                     <tei-pb n="[1.153 - page breaks after 'Er-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/153.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> began to weep as he said these words.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Do not,"</tei-said> said I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"welcome me
                        thus; try to be more calm, that I may not be absolutely miserable the moment
                        I enter my father's house after so long an absence. But, tell me, how does
                        my father support his misfortunes? and how is my poor
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"She indeed requires consolation; she accused herself of
                        having caused the death of my brother, and that made her very wretched. But
                        since the murderer has been discovered—"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"The murderer discovered! Good God! how can that be? who
                        could attempt to pursue him? it is impossible; one might as well try to
                        overtake the winds, or confine a mountain-stream with a straw."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I do not know what you mean; but we were all very unhappy
                        when <tei-pb n="[1.154]" facs="pageImages/vol1/154.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> she was discovered. No
                        one would believe it at first; and even now <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>
                        will not be convinced, notwithstanding all the evidence. Indeed, who would
                        credit that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine Moritz</tei-persName>, who was so amiable, and
                        fond of all the family, could all at once become so extremely
                        wicked?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine Moritz</tei-persName>! Poor, poor girl, is
                        she the accused? But it is wrongfully; every one knows that; no one believes
                        it, surely, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"No one did at first; but several circumstances came out,
                        that have almost forced conviction upon us: and her own behaviour has been
                        so confused, as to add to the evidence of facts a weight that, I fear,
                        leaves no hope for doubt. But she will be tried to-day, and you will then
                        hear all."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He related that, the morning on which the murder of poor
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> had <tei-pb n="[1.155]" facs="pageImages/vol1/155.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> been discovered,
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> had been taken ill, and confined to her bed;
                     and, after several days, one of the servants, happening to examine the apparel
                     she had worn on the night of the murder, had discovered in her pocket the
                     picture of my mother, which had been judged to be the temptation of the
                     murderer. The servant instantly shewed it to one of the others, who, without
                     saying a word to any of the family, went to a magistrate; and, upon their
                     deposition, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was apprehended. On being charged with
                     the fact, the poor girl confirmed the suspicion in a great measure by her
                     extreme confusion of manner.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This was a strange tale, but it did not shake my faith; and I replied
                     earnestly, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You are all mistaken; I know the murderer.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, poor, good <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, is
                        innocent."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.156]" facs="pageImages/vol1/156.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">At that instant my father entered. I saw unhappiness deeply impressed on his
                     countenance, but he endeavoured to welcome me cheerfully; and, after we had
                     exchanged our mournful greeting, would have introduced some other topic than
                     that of our disaster, had not <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName> exclaimed, <tei-said who="#ernest" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Good God, Papa! <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName> says that he
                        knows who was the murderer of poor William."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"We do also, unfortunately,"</tei-said> replied my father;
                        <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"for indeed I had rather have been for ever ignorant
                        than have discovered so much depravity and ingratitude in one I valued so
                        highly."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear father, you are mistaken;
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> is innocent."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"If she is, God forbid that she should suffer as guilty.
                        She is to be tried to-day, and I hope, I sincerely hope, that she will be
                        acquitted."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.157]" facs="pageImages/vol1/157.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This speech calmed me. I was firmly convinced in my own mind that
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, and indeed every human being, was guiltless of
                     this murder. I had no fear, therefore, that any circumstantial evidence could
                     be brought forward strong enough to convict her; and, in this assurance, I
                     calmed myself, expecting the trial with eagerness, but without prognosticating
                     an evil result.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We were soon joined by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. Time had made great
                     alterations in her form since I had last beheld her. Six years before she had
                     been a pretty, good-humoured girl, whom every one loved and caressed. She was
                     now a woman in stature and expression of countenance, which was uncommonly
                     lovely. An open and capacious forehead gave indications of a good
                     understanding, joined to great frankness of disposition. Her eyes were hazel,
                     and <tei-pb n="[1.158]" facs="pageImages/vol1/158.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> expressive of mildness,
                     now through recent affliction allied to sadness. Her hair was of a rich dark
                     auburn, her complexion fair, and her figure slight and graceful. She welcomed
                     me with the greatest affection. <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Your arrival, my dear
                        cousin,"</tei-said> said she, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"fills me with hope. You
                        perhaps will find some means to justify my poor guiltless
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>. Alas! who is safe, if she be convicted of
                        crime? I rely on her innocence as certainly as I do upon my own. Our
                        misfortune is doubly hard to us; we have not only lost that lovely darling
                        boy, but this poor girl, whom I sincerely love, is to be torn away by even a
                        worse fate. If she is condemned, I never shall know joy more. But she will
                        not, I am sure she will not; and then I shall be happy again, even after the
                        sad death of my little <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"She is innocent, my
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>,"</tei-said>
                     <tei-pb n="[1.159]" facs="pageImages/vol1/159.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> said I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"and that shall be proved; fear nothing, but let your spirits be cheered by
                        the assurance of her acquittal."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"How kind you are! every one else believes in her guilt,
                        and that made me wretched; for I knew that it was impossible: and to see
                        every one else prejudiced in so deadly a manner, rendered me hopeless and
                        despairing."</tei-said> She wept.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Sweet niece,"</tei-said> said my father, <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"dry your tears. If she is, as you believe, innocent, rely on the justice
                        of our judges, and the activity with which I shall prevent the slightest
                        shadow of partiality."</tei-said></tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>


            <tei-div n="1.7" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[1.160]" facs="pageImages/vol1/160.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter VII</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">WE passed a few sad hours, until eleven o'clock, when the
                     trial was to commence. My father and the rest of the family being obliged to
                     attend as witnesses, I accompanied them to the court. During the whole of this
                     wretched mockery of justice, I suffered living torture. It was to be decided,
                     whether the result of my curiosity and lawless devices would cause the death of
                     two of my fellow-beings: one a smiling babe, full of innocence and joy; the
                     other far more dreadfully murdered, with every aggravation of <tei-pb n="[1.161 - page breaks after 'in-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/161.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     infamy that could make the murder memorable in horror.
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> also was a girl of merit, and possessed
                     qualities which promised to render her life happy: now all was to be
                     obliterated in an ignominious grave; and I the cause! A thousand times rather
                     would I have confessed myself guilty of the crime ascribed to
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>; but I was absent when it was committed, and
                     such a declaration would have been considered as the ravings of a madman, and
                     would not have exculpated her who suffered through me.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The appearance of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was calm. She was dressed in
                     mourning; and her countenance, always engaging, was rendered, by the solemnity
                     of her feelings, exquisitely beautiful. Yet she appeared confident in
                     innocence, and did not tremble, although gazed on and execrated by thousands;
                     for all the <tei-pb n="[1.162]" facs="pageImages/vol1/162.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> kindness which her
                     beauty might otherwise have excited, was obliterated in the minds of the
                     spectators by the imagination of the enormity she was supposed to have
                     committed. She was tranquil, yet her tranquillity was evidently constrained;
                     and as her confusion had before been adduced as a proof of her guilt, she
                     worked up her mind to an appearance of courage. When she entered the court, she
                     threw her eyes round it, and quickly discovered where we were seated. A tear
                     seemed to dim her eye when she saw us; but she quickly recovered herself, and a
                     look of sorrowful affection seemed to attest her utter guiltlessness.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The trial began; and after the advocate against her had stated the charge,
                     several witnesses were called. Several strange facts combined against her,
                     which might have staggered any one <tei-pb n="[1.163]" facs="pageImages/vol1/163.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> who had not such proof of her innocence as
                     I had. She had been out the whole of the night on which the murder had been
                     committed, and towards morning had been perceived by a market-woman not far
                     from the spot where the body of the murdered child had been afterwards found.
                     The woman asked her what she did there; but she looked very strangely, and only
                     returned a confused and unintelligible answer. She returned to the house about
                     eight o'clock; and when one inquired where she had passed the night, she
                     replied, that she had been looking for the child, and demanded earnestly, if
                     any thing had been heard concerning him. When shewn the body, she fell into
                     violent hysterics, and kept her bed for several days. The picture was then
                     produced, which the servant had found in her pocket; and when
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, in <tei-pb n="[1.164]" facs="pageImages/vol1/164.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> a faltering voice, proved that it was the
                     same which, an hour before the child had been missed, she had placed round his
                     neck, a murmur of horror and indignation filled the court.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was called on for her defence. As the trial had
                     proceeded, her countenance had altered. Surprise, horror, and misery, were
                     strongly expressed. Sometimes she struggled with her tears; but when she was
                     desired to plead, she collected her powers, and spoke in an audible although
                     variable voice:—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"God knows,"</tei-said> she said, <tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how
                        entirely I am innocent. But I do not pretend that my protestations should
                        acquit me: I rest my innocence on a plain and simple explanation of the
                        facts which have been adduced against me; and I hope the character I have
                        always borne will incline my judges to a favourable interpretation, where
                           <tei-pb n="[1.165]" facs="pageImages/vol1/165.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> any circumstance appears
                        doubtful or suspicious."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">She then related that, by the permission of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, she
                     had passed the evening of the night on which the murder had been committed, at
                     the house of an aunt at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8700245" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Chêne</tei-placeName>,
                     a village situated at about a league from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. On her return, at about nine o'clock, she met a man,
                     who asked her if she had seen any thing of the child who was lost. She was
                     alarmed by this account, and passed several hours in looking for him, when the
                     gates of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName> were shut, and
                     she was forced to remain several hours of the night in a barn belonging to a
                     cottage, being unwilling to call up the inhabitants, to whom she was well
                     known. Unable to rest or sleep, she quitted her asylum early, that she might
                     again endeavour to find my brother. If she had gone near the spot <tei-pb n="[1.166]" facs="pageImages/vol1/166.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> where his body lay, it was
                     without her knowledge. That she had been bewildered when questioned by the
                     market-woman, was not surprising, since she had passed a sleepless night, and
                     the fate of poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> was yet uncertain. Concerning the
                     picture she could give no account.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I know,"</tei-said> continued the unhappy victim, <tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how heavily and fatally this one circumstance weighs against
                        me, but I have no power of explaining it; and when I have expressed my utter
                        ignorance, I am only left to conjecture concerning the probabilities by
                        which it might have been placed in my pocket. But here also I am checked. I
                        believe that I have no enemy on earth, and none surely would have been so
                        wicked as to destroy me wantonly. Did the murderer place it there? I know of
                        no opportunity afforded him <tei-pb n="[1.167]" facs="pageImages/vol1/167.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        for so doing; or if I had, why should he have stolen the jewel, to part with
                        it again so soon?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I commit my cause to the justice of my judges, yet I see
                        no room for hope. I beg permission to have a few witnesses examined
                        concerning my character; and if their testimony shall not overweigh my
                        supposed guilt, I must be condemned, although I would pledge my salvation on
                        my innocence."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Several witnesses were called, who had known her for many years, and they spoke
                     well of her; but fear, and hatred of the crime of which they supposed her
                     guilty, rendered them timorous, and unwilling to come forward.
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> saw even this last resource, her excellent
                     dispositions and irreproachable conduct, about to fail the accused, when,
                     although violently <tei-pb n="[1.168 - page breaks after 'agi']" facs="pageImages/vol1/168.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> agitated, she desired permission to address
                     the court.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am,"</tei-said> said she, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"the
                        cousin of the unhappy child who was murdered, or rather his sister, for I
                        was educated by and have lived with his parents ever since and even long
                        before his birth. It may therefore be judged indecent in me to come forward
                        on this occasion; but when I see a fellow-creature about to perish through
                        the cowardice of her pretended friends, I wish to be allowed to speak, that
                        I may say what I know of her character. I am well acquainted with the
                        accused. I have lived in the same house with her, at one time for five, and
                        at another for nearly two years. During all that period she appeared to me
                        the most amiable and benevolent of human creatures. She nursed Madame
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>, my aunt, in her last illness with the
                        greatest affection and care; and <tei-pb n="[1.169]" facs="pageImages/vol1/169.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> afterwards attended her own mother
                        during a tedious illness, in a manner that excited the admiration of all who
                        knew her. After which she again lived in my uncle's house, where she was
                        beloved by all the family. She was warmly attached to the child who is now
                        dead, and acted towards him like a most affectionate mother. For my own
                        part, I do not hesitate to say, that, notwithstanding all the evidence
                        produced against her, I believe and rely on her perfect innocence. She had
                        no temptation for such an action: as to the bauble on which the chief proof
                        rests, if she had earnestly desired it, I should have willingly given it to
                        her; so much do I esteem and value her."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Excellent <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>! A murmur of approbation was heard;
                     but it was excited by her generous interference, and not in favor of poor
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, on whom <tei-pb n="[1.170]" facs="pageImages/vol1/170.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the public indignation was turned with
                     renewed violence, charging her with the blackest ingratitude. She herself wept
                     as <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> spoke, but she did not answer. My own
                     agitation and anguish was extreme during the whole trial. I believed in her
                     innocence; I knew it. Could the dæmon, who had (I did not for a minute doubt)
                     murdered my brother, also in his hellish sport have betrayed the innocent to
                     death and ignominy? I could not sustain the horror of my situation; and when I
                     perceived that the popular voice, and the countenances of the judges, had
                     already condemned my unhappy victim, I rushed out of the court in agony. The
                     tortures of the accused did not equal mine; she was sustained by innocence, but
                     the fangs of remorse tore my bosom, and would not forego their hold.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I passed a night of unmingled <tei-pb n="[1.171 - page breaks after 'wretch-']" facs="pageImages/vol1/171.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> wretchedness. In the morning I went to the
                     court; my lips and throat were parched. I dared not ask the fatal question; but
                     I was known, and the officer guessed the cause of my visit. The ballots had
                     been thrown; they were all black, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> was
                     condemned.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I cannot pretend to describe what I then felt. I had before experienced
                     sensations of horror; and I have endeavoured to bestow upon them adequate
                     expressions, but words cannot convey an idea of the heart-sickening despair
                     that I then endured. The person to whom I addressed myself added, that
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName> had already confessed her guilt. <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"That evidence,"</tei-said> he observed, <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"was hardly required in so glaring a case, but I am glad of it; and,
                        indeed, none of our judges like to condemn a criminal upon circumstantial
                        evidence, be it ever so decisive."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[1.172]" facs="pageImages/vol1/172.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">When I returned home, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> eagerly demanded the
                     result.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My cousin,"</tei-said> replied I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"it is
                        decided as you may have expected; all judges had rather that ten innocent
                        should suffer, than that one guilty should escape. But she has
                        confessed."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This was a dire blow to poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, who had relied
                     with firmness upon <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>'s innocence. <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Alas!"</tei-said> said she, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how shall
                        I ever again believe in human benevolence? <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>,
                        whom I loved and esteemed as my sister, how could she put on those smiles of
                        innocence only to betray; her mild eyes seemed incapable of any severity or
                        ill-humour, and yet she has committed a murder."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Soon after we heard that the poor victim had expressed a wish to see my cousin.
                     My father wished her not to go; but said, that he left it to her own <tei-pb n="[1.173]" facs="pageImages/vol1/173.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> judgment and feelings to
                     decide. <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Yes,"</tei-said> said
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I will go, although
                        she is guilty; and you, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, shall accompany me: I
                        cannot go alone."</tei-said> The idea of this visit was torture to me, yet I
                     could not refuse.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We entered the gloomy prison-chamber, and beheld <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>
                     sitting on some straw at the further end; her hands were manacled, and her head
                     rested on her knees. She rose on seeing us enter; and when we were left alone
                     with her, she threw herself at the feet of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>,
                     weeping bitterly. My cousin wept also.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Oh, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>!"</tei-said> said she,
                        <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"why did you rob me of my last consolation? I relied
                        on your innocence; and although I was then very wretched, I was not so
                        miserable as I am now."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"And do you also believe that I am so very, very wicked? Do
                        you also <tei-pb n="[1.174]" facs="pageImages/vol1/174.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> join with my
                        enemies to crush me?"</tei-said> Her voice was suffocated with sobs.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Rise, my poor girl,"</tei-said> said
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"why do you kneel, if
                        you are innocent? I am not one of your enemies; I believed you guiltless,
                        notwithstanding every evidence, until I heard that you had yourself declared
                        your guilt. That report, you say, is false; and be assured, dear
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, that nothing can shake my confidence in you
                        for a moment, but your own confession."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#moritz" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I did confess; but I confessed a lie. I confessed, that I
                        might obtain absolution; but now that falsehood lies heavier at my heart
                        than all my other sins. The God of heaven forgive me! Ever since I was
                        condemned, my confessor has besieged me; he threatened and menaced, until I
                        almost began to think that I was the monster that he <tei-pb n="[1.175]" facs="pageImages/vol1/175.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> said I was. He threatened
