                        younger was slight and graceful in his figure, and his features were moulded
                        with the finest symmetry; yet his eyes and attitude expressed the utmost
                        sadness and despondency. The old man returned to the cottage; and the youth,
                        with tools different from those he had used in the morning, directed his
                        steps across the fields.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.51]" facs="pageImages/vol2/51.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Night quickly shut in; but, to my extreme wonder, I found that the cottagers
                        had a means of prolonging light, by the use of tapers, and was delighted to
                        find, that the setting of the sun did not put an end to the pleasure I
                        experienced in watching my human neighbours. In the evening, the young girl
                        and her companion were employed in various occupations which I did not
                        understand; and the old man again took up the instrument, which produced the
                        divine sounds that had enchanted me in the morning. So soon as he had
                        finished, the youth began, not to play, but to utter sounds that were
                        monotonous, and neither resembling the harmony of the old man's instrument
                        or the songs of the birds; I since found that he read aloud, but at that
                        time I knew nothing of the science of words or letters.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.52]" facs="pageImages/vol2/52.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The family, after having been thus occupied for a short time, extinguished
                        their lights, and retired, as I conjectured, to rest.</tei-p>
                  </tei-said></tei-said>


            </tei-div>






            <tei-div n="2.4" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[2.53]" facs="pageImages/vol2/53.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter IV</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who"><tei-p data-origname="p">I LAY on my straw, but I could not
                        sleep. I thought of the occurrences of the day. What chiefly struck me was
                        the gentle manners of these people; and I longed to join them, but dared
                        not. I remembered too well the treatment I had suffered the night before
                        from the barbarous villagers, and resolved, whatever course of conduct I
                        might hereafter think it right to pursue, that for the present I would
                        remain quietly in my hovel, watching, and endeavouring to discover the
                        motives which influenced their actions.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.54]" facs="pageImages/vol2/54.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The cottagers arose the next morning before the sun. The young woman
                        arranged the cottage, and prepared the food; and the youth departed after
                        the first meal.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">This day was passed in the same routine as that which preceded it. The young
                        man was constantly employed out of doors, and the girl in various laborious
                        occupations within. The old man, whom I soon perceived to be blind, employed
                        his leisure hours on his instrument, or in contemplation. Nothing could
                        exceed the love and respect which the younger cottagers exhibited towards
                        their venerable companion. They performed towards him every little office of
                        affection and duty with gentleness; and he rewarded them by his benevolent
                        smiles.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">They were not entirely happy. The young man and his companion often <tei-pb n="[2.55]" facs="pageImages/vol2/55.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> went apart, and appeared to
                        weep. I saw no cause for their unhappiness; but I was deeply affected by it.
                        If such lovely creatures were miserable, it was less strange that I, an
                        imperfect and solitary being, should be wretched. Yet why were these gentle
                        beings unhappy? They possessed a delightful house (for such it was in my
                        eyes), and every luxury; they had a fire to warm them when chill, and
                        delicious viands when hungry; they were dressed in excellent clothes; and,
                        still more, they enjoyed one another's company and speech, interchanging
                        each day looks of affection and kindness. What did their tears imply? Did
                        they really express pain? I was at first unable to solve these questions;
                        but perpetual attention, and time, explained to me many appearances which
                        were at first enigmatic.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.56]" facs="pageImages/vol2/56.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">A considerable period elapsed before I discovered one of the causes of the
                        uneasiness of this amiable family; it was poverty; and they suffered that
                        evil in a very distressing degree. Their nourishment consisted entirely of
                        the vegetables of their garden, and the milk of one cow, who gave very
                        little during the winter, when its masters could scarcely procure food to
                        support it. They often, I believe, suffered the pangs of hunger very
                        poignantly, especially the two younger cottagers; for several times they
                        placed food before the old man, when they reserved none for themselves.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">This trait of kindness moved me sensibly. I had been accustomed, during the
                        night, to steal a part of their store for my own consumption; but when I
                        found that in doing this I inflicted pain on the cottagers, I abstained, <tei-pb n="[2.57]" facs="pageImages/vol2/57.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and satisfied myself with
                        berries, nuts, and roots, which I gathered from a neighbouring wood.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I discovered also another means through which I was enabled to assist their
                        labours. I found that the youth spent a great part of each day in collecting
                        wood for the family fire; and, during the night, I often took his tools, the
                        use of which I quickly discovered, and brought home firing sufficient for
                        the consumption of several days.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I remember, the first time that I did this, the young woman, when she opened
                        the door in the morning, appeared greatly astonished on seeing a great pile
                        of wood on the outside. She uttered some words in a loud voice, and the
                        youth joined her, who also expressed surprise. I observed, with pleasure,
                        that he did not go to the forest that day, but spent it in <tei-pb n="[2.58 - page breaks after 'repair-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/58.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        repairing the cottage, and cultivating the garden.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">By degrees I made a discovery of still greater moment. I found that these
                        people possessed a method of communicating their experience and feelings to
                        one another by articulate sounds. I perceived that the words they spoke
                        sometimes produced pleasure or pain, smiles or sadness, in the minds and
                        countenances of the hearers. This was indeed a godlike science, and I
                        ardently desired to become acquainted with it. But I was baffled in every
                        attempt I made for this purpose. Their pronunciation was quick; and the
                        words they uttered, not having any apparent connexion with visible objects,
                        I was unable to discover any clue by which I could unravel the mystery of
                        their reference. By great application, however, and after having <tei-pb n="[2.59 - page breaks after 're-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/59.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        remained during the space of several revolutions of the moon in my hovel, I
                        discovered the names that were given to some of the most familiar objects of
                        discourse; I learned and applied the words <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(fire)</tei-hi>,
                           <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(milk)</tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(bread)</tei-hi>, and <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(wood)</tei-hi>. I learned also the names of the cottagers
                        themselves. The youth and his companion had each of them several names, but
                        the old man had only one, which was <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(father)</tei-hi>. The
                        girl was called <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(sister)</tei-hi>, or <tei-persName data-origname="persName"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(Agatha)</tei-hi></tei-persName>; and the youth <tei-persName data-origname="persName"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(Felix)</tei-hi>
                        </tei-persName>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(brother)</tei-hi>, or <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(son)</tei-hi>. I cannot describe the delight I felt when I learned the
                        ideas appropriated to each of these sounds, and was able to pronounce them.
                        I distinguished several other words, without being able as yet to understand
                        or apply them; such as <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(good)</tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(dearest)</tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(unhappy)</tei-hi>.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I spent the winter in this manner. The gentle manners and beauty of the <tei-pb n="[2.60]" facs="pageImages/vol2/60.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> cottagers greatly endeared
                        them to me; when they were unhappy, I felt depressed; when they rejoiced, I
                        sympathized in their joys. I saw few human beings beside them; and if any
                        other happened to enter the cottage, their harsh manners and rude gait only
                        enhanced to me the superior accomplishments of my friends. The old man, I
                        could perceive, often endeavoured to encourage his children, as sometimes I
                        found that he called them, to cast off their melancholy. He would talk in a
                        cheerful accent, with an expression of goodness that bestowed pleasure even
                        upon me. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> listened with respect, her eyes
                        sometimes filled with tears, which she endeavoured to wipe away unperceived;
                        but I generally found that her countenance and tone were more cheerful after
                        having listened to the exhortations of her father. It was not thus with
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>. He <tei-pb n="[2.61]" facs="pageImages/vol2/61.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> was always the saddest of the groupe;
                        and, even to my unpractised senses, he appeared to have suffered more deeply
                        than his friends. But if his countenance was more sorrowful, his voice was
                        more cheerful than that of his sister, especially when he addressed the old
                        man.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I could mention innumerable instances, which, although slight, marked the
                        dispositions of these amiable cottagers. In the midst of poverty and want,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> carried with pleasure to his sister the first
                        little white flower that peeped out from beneath the snowy ground. Early in
                        the morning before she had risen, he cleared away the snow that obstructed
                        her path to the milk-house, drew water from the well, and brought the wood
                        from the out-house, where, to his perpetual astonishment, he found his store
                        always <tei-pb n="[2.62 - page breaks after 'reple-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/62.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> replenished by an invisible hand. In the
                        day, I believe, he worked sometimes for a neighbouring farmer, because he
                        often went forth, and did not return until dinner, yet brought no wood with
                        him. At other times he worked in the garden; but, as there was little to do
                        in the frosty season, he read to the old man and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">This reading had puzzled me extremely at first; but, by degrees, I
                        discovered that he uttered many of the same sounds when he read as when he
                        talked. I conjectured, therefore, that he found on the paper signs for
                        speech which he understood, and I ardently longed to comprehend these also;
                        but how was that possible, when I did not even understand the sounds for
                        which they stood as signs? I improved, however, sensibly in this science,
                        but not sufficiently to follow up any kind of <tei-pb n="[2.63]" facs="pageImages/vol2/63.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> conversation, although I applied my whole
                        mind to the endeavour: for I easily perceived that, although I eagerly
                        longed to discover myself to the cottagers, I ought not to make the attempt
                        until I had first become master of their language; which knowledge might
                        enable me to make them overlook the deformity of my figure; for with this
                        also the contrast perpetually presented to my eyes had made me
                        acquainted.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I had admired the perfect forms of my cottagers—their grace, beauty, and
                        delicate complexions: but how was I terrified, when I viewed myself in a
                        transparent pool! At first I started back, unable to believe that it was
                        indeed I who was reflected in the mirror; and when I became fully convinced
                        that I was in reality the monster that I am, I was filled with the bitterest
                           <tei-pb n="[2.64 - page breaks after 'sen-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/64.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        sensations of despondence and mortification. Alas! I did not yet entirely
                        know the fatal effects of this miserable deformity.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">As the sun became warmer, and the light of day longer, the snow vanished,
                        and I beheld the bare trees and the black earth. From this time
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was more employed; and the heart-moving
                        indications of impending famine disappeared. Their food, as I afterwards
                        found, was coarse, but it was wholesome; and they procured a sufficiency of
                        it. Several new kinds of plants sprung up in the garden, which they dressed;
                        and these signs of comfort increased daily as the season advanced.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The old man, leaning on his son, walked each day at noon, when it did not
                        rain, as I found it was called when the heavens poured forth its waters. <tei-pb n="[2.65]" facs="pageImages/vol2/65.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> This frequently took place;
                        but a high wind quickly dried the earth, and the season became far more
                        pleasant than it had been.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">My mode of life in my hovel was uniform. During the morning I attended the
                        motions of the cottagers; and when they were dispersed in various
                        occupations, I slept: the remainder of the day was spent in observing my
                        friends. When they had retired to rest, if there was any moon, or the night
                        was star-light, I went into the woods, and collected my own food and fuel
                        for the cottage. When I returned, as often as it was necessary, I cleared
                        their path of the snow, and performed those offices that I had seen done by
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>. I afterwards found that these labours,
                        performed by an invisible hand, greatly astonished them; and once or twice I
                        heard them, on these <tei-pb n="[2.66]" facs="pageImages/vol2/66.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        occasions, utter the words <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(good spirit)</tei-hi>, <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">(wonderful)</tei-hi>; but I did not then understand the
                        signification of these terms.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">My thoughts now became more active, and I longed to discover the motives and
                        feelings of these lovely creatures; I was inquisitive to know why
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> appeared so miserable, and
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> so sad. I thought (foolish wretch!) that it
                        might be in my power to restore happiness to these deserving people. When I
                        slept, or was absent, the forms of the venerable blind father, the gentle
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>, and the excellent
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, flitted before me. I looked upon them as
                        superior beings, who would be the arbiters of my future destiny. I formed in
                        my imagination a thousand pictures of presenting myself to them, and their
                        reception of me. I imagined that they would be disgusted, until, by my
                        gentle demeanour and conciliating <tei-pb n="[2.67]" facs="pageImages/vol2/67.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> words, I should first win their favour,
                        and afterwards their love.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">These thoughts exhilarated me, and led me to apply with fresh ardour to the
                        acquiring the art of language. My organs were indeed harsh, but supple: and
                        although my voice was very unlike the soft music of their tones, yet I
                        pronounced such words as I understood with tolerable ease. It was as the ass
                        and the lap-dog; yet surely the gentle ass whose intentions were
                        affectionate, although his manners were rude, deserved better treatment than
                        blows and execration.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The pleasant showers and genial warmth of spring greatly altered the aspect
                        of the earth. Men, who before this change seemed to have been hid in caves,
                        dispersed themselves, and were employed in various arts of cultivation. The
                        birds sang in more <tei-pb n="[2.68 - page breaks after 'cheer-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/68.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> cheerful notes, and the leaves began to
                        bud forth on the trees. Happy, happy earth! fit habitation for gods, which,
                        so short a time before, was bleak, damp, and unwholesome. My spirits were
                        elevated by the enchanting appearance of nature; the past was blotted from
                        my memory, the present was tranquil, and the future gilded by bright rays of
                        hope, and anticipations of joy.</tei-p></tei-said></tei-said>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="2.5" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[2.69]" facs="pageImages/vol2/69.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter V</tei-head>







               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                  <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I NOW hasten to the more moving part of my story. I shall relate events that
                        impressed me with feelings which, from what I was, have made me what I
                        am.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Spring advanced rapidly; the weather became fine, and the skies cloudless.
                        It surprised me, that what before was desert and gloomy should now bloom
                        with the most beautiful flowers and verdure. My senses were gratified and
                        refreshed by a thousand scents of delight, and a thousand sights of
                        beauty.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.70]" facs="pageImages/vol2/70.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">It was on one of these days, when my cottagers periodically rested from
                        labour—the old man played on his guitar, and the children listened to him—I
                        observed that the countenance of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was melancholy
                        beyond expression; he sighed frequently; and once his father paused in his
                        music, and I conjectured by his manner that he inquired the cause of his
                        son's sorrow. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> replied in a cheerful accent, and
                        the old man was recommencing his music when some one tapped at the door.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">It was a lady on horseback, accompanied by a countryman as a guide. The lady
                        was dressed in a dark suit, and covered with a thick black veil.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> asked a question; to which the stranger only
                        replied by pronouncing, in a sweet accent, the name of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>. Her voice was musical, but unlike that of <tei-pb n="[2.71]" facs="pageImages/vol2/71.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> either of my friends. On
                        hearing this word, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> came up hastily to the lady;
                        who, when she saw him, threw up her veil, and I beheld a countenance of
                        angelic beauty and expression. Her hair of a shining raven black, and
                        curiously braided; her eyes were dark, but gentle, although animated; her
                        features of a regular proportion, and her complexion wondrously fair, each
                        cheek tinged with a lovely pink.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> seemed ravished with delight when he saw her,
                        every trait of sorrow vanished from his face, and it instantly expressed a
                        degree of ecstatic joy, of which I could hardly have believed it capable;
                        his eyes sparkled, as his cheek flushed with pleasure; and at that moment I
                        thought him as beautiful as the stranger. She appeared affected by different
                        feelings; wiping a few tears from her lovely eyes, <tei-pb n="[2.72]" facs="pageImages/vol2/72.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> she held out her hand to
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, who kissed it rapturously, and called her, as
                        well as I could distinguish, his sweet <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>. She did
                        not appear to understand him, but smiled. He assisted her to dismount, and,
                        dismissing her guide, conducted her into the cottage. Some conversation took
                        place between him and his father; and the young stranger knelt at the old
                        man's feet, and would have kissed his hand, but he raised her, and embraced
                        her affectionately.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I soon perceived, that although the stranger uttered articulate sounds, and
                        appeared to have a language of her own, she was neither understood by, or
                        herself understood, the cottagers. They made many signs which I did not
                        comprehend; but I saw that her presence diffused gladness through the
                        cottage, dispelling their sorrow as the sun dissipates the morning mists.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> seemed <tei-pb n="[2.73]" facs="pageImages/vol2/73.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> peculiarly happy, and with smiles of
                        delight welcomed his <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>, the ever-gentle <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>,
                        kissed the hands of the lovely stranger; and, pointing to her brother, made
                        signs which appeared to me to mean that he had been sorrowful until she
                        came. Some hours passed thus, while they, by their countenances, expressed
                        joy, the cause of which I did not comprehend. Presently I found, by the
                        frequent recurrence of one sound which the stranger repeated after them,
                        that she was endeavouring to learn their language; and the idea instantly
                        occurred to me, that I should make use of the same instructions to the same
                        end. The stranger learned about twenty words at the first lesson, most of
                        them indeed were those which I had before understood, but I profited by the
                        others.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">As night came on, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> and the <tei-pb n="[2.74]" facs="pageImages/vol2/74.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName> retired early. When they separated,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> kissed the hand of the stranger, and said,
                        Good night, sweet <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>. He sat up much longer,
                        conversing with his father; and, by the frequent repetition of her name, I
                        conjectured that their lovely guest was the subject of their conversation. I
                        ardently desired to understand them, and bent every faculty towards that
                        purpose, but found it utterly impossible.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The next morning <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> went out to his work; and, after
                        the usual occupations of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> were finished, the
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName> sat at the feet of the old man, and, taking
                        his guitar, played some airs so entrancingly beautiful, that they at once
                        drew tears of sorrow and delight from my eyes. She sang, and her voice
                        flowed in a rich cadence, swelling or dying away, like a nightingale of the
                        woods.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.75]" facs="pageImages/vol2/75.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">When she had finished, she gave the guitar to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>,
                        who at first declined it. She played a simple air, and her voice accompanied
                        it in sweet accents, but unlike the wondrous strain of the stranger. The old
                        man appeared enraptured, and said some words, which
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> endeavoured to explain to
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>, and by which he appeared to wish to express
                        that she bestowed on him the greatest delight by her music.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The days now passed as peacefully as before, with the sole alteration that
                        joy had taken the place of sadness in the countenances of my friends.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> was always gay and happy; she and I improved
                        rapidly in the knowledge of language, so that in two months I began to
                        comprehend most of the words uttered by my protectors.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">In the meanwhile also the black ground was covered with herbage, and <tei-pb n="[2.76]" facs="pageImages/vol2/76.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the green banks interspersed
                        with innumerable flowers, sweet to the scent and the eyes, stars of pale
                        radiance among the moonlight woods; the sun became warmer, the nights clear
                        and balmy; and my nocturnal rambles were an extreme pleasure to me, although
                        they were considerably shortened by the late setting and early rising of the
                        sun; for I never ventured abroad during day-light, fearful of meeting with
                        the same treatment as I had formerly endured in the first village which I
                        entered.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">My days were spent in close attention, that I might more speedily master the
                        language; and I may boast that I improved more rapidly than the
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>, who understood very little, and conversed
                        in broken accents, whilst I comprehended and could imitate almost every word
                        that was spoken.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">While I improved in speech, I also <tei-pb n="[2.77]" facs="pageImages/vol2/77.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> learned the science of letters, as it was
                        taught to the stranger; and this opened before me a wide field for wonder
                        and delight.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The book from which <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> instructed
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> was <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-title data-origname="title">Volney's Ruins of
                              Empires</tei-title></tei-hi> . I should not have understood the purport of
                        this book, had not <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, in reading it, given very
                        minute explanations. He had chosen this work, he said, because the
                        declamatory style was framed in imitation of the eastern authors. Through
                        this work I obtained a cursory knowledge of history, and a view of the
                        several empires at present existing in the world; it gave me an insight into
                        the manners, governments, and religions of the different nations of the
                        earth. I heard of the slothful Asiatics; of the stupendous genius and mental
                        activity of the Grecians; of the wars and wonderful virtue of the early
                        Romans— <tei-pb n="[2.78]" facs="pageImages/vol2/78.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of their subsequent
                        degeneration—of the decline of that mighty empire; of chivalry,
                        Christianity, and kings. I heard of the discovery of the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="8698314" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">American hemisphere</tei-placeName>, and wept with
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> over the hapless fate of its original
                        inhabitants.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">These wonderful narrations inspired me with strange feelings. Was man,
                        indeed, at once so powerful, so virtuous, and magnificent, yet so vicious
                        and base? He appeared at one time a mere scion of the evil principle, and at
                        another as all that can be conceived of noble and godlike. To be a great and
                        virtuous man appeared the highest honour that can befall a sensitive being;
                        to be base and vicious, as many on record have been, appeared the lowest
                        degradation, a condition more abject than that of the blind mole or harmless
                        worm. For a long time I could not conceive how one man could go <tei-pb n="[2.79]" facs="pageImages/vol2/79.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> forth to murder his fellow, or
                        even why there were laws and governments; but when I heard details of vice
                        and bloodshed, my wonder ceased, and I turned away with disgust and
                        loathing.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Every conversation of the cottagers now opened new wonders to me. While I
                        listened to the instructions which <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> bestowed upon
                        the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>, the strange system of human society was
                        explained to me. I heard of the division of property, of immense wealth and
                        squalid poverty; of rank, descent, and noble blood.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The words induced me to turn towards myself. I learned that the possessions
                        most esteemed by your fellow-creatures were, high and unsullied descent
                        united with riches. A man might be respected with only one of these
                        acquisitions; but without either he was considered, except in very rare
                        instances, <tei-pb n="[2.80]" facs="pageImages/vol2/80.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> as a vagabond and
                        a slave, doomed to waste his powers for the profit of the chosen few. And
                        what was I? Of my creation and creator I was absolutely ignorant; but I knew
                        that I possessed no money, no friends, no kind of property. I was, besides,
                        endowed with a figure hideously deformed and loathsome; I was not even of
                        the same nature as man. I was more agile than they, and could subsist upon
                        coarser diet; I bore the extremes of heat and cold with less injury to my
                        frame; my stature far exceeded their's. When I looked around, I saw and
                        heard of none like me. Was I then a monster, a blot upon the earth, from
                        which all men fled, and whom all men disowned?</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I cannot describe to you the agony that these reflections inflicted upon me;
                        I tried to dispel them, but sorrow only increased with knowledge. Oh, that
                           <tei-pb n="[2.81]" facs="pageImages/vol2/81.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I had forever remained in
                        my native wood, nor known or felt beyond the sensations of hunger, thirst,
                        and heat!</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Of what a strange nature is knowledge! It clings to the mind, when it has
                        once seized on it, like a lichen on the rock. I wished sometimes to shake
                        off all thought and feeling; but I learned that there was but one means to
                        overcome the sensation of pain, and that was death—a state which I feared
                        yet did not understand. I admired virtue and good feelings, and loved the
                        gentle manners and amiable qualities of my cottagers; but I was shut out
                        from intercourse with them, except through means which I obtained by
                        stealth, when I was unseen and unknown, and which rather increased than
                        satisfied the desire I had of becoming one among my fellows. The gentle
                        words of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>, <tei-pb n="[2.82]" facs="pageImages/vol2/82.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and the animated smiles of the charming
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>, were not for me. The mild exhortations of
                        the old man, and the lively conversation of the loved
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, were not for me. Miserable, unhappy
                        wretch!</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Other lessons were impressed upon me even more deeply. I heard of the
                        difference of sexes; of the birth and growth of children; how the father
                        doated on the smiles of the infant, and the lively sallies of the older
                        child; how all the life and cares of the mother were wrapped up in the
                        precious charge; how the mind of youth expanded and gained knowledge; of
                        brother, sister, and all the various relationships which bind one human
                        being to another in mutual bonds.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">But where were my friends and relations? No father had watched my infant
                        days, no mother had blessed me <tei-pb n="[2.83]" facs="pageImages/vol2/83.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> with smiles and caresses; or if they had, all my past life was now a
                        blot, a blind vacancy in which I distinguished nothing. From my earliest
                        remembrance I had been as I then was in height and proportion. I had never
                        yet seen a being resembling me, or who claimed any intercourse with me. What
                        was I? The question again recurred, to be answered only with groans.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I will soon explain to what these feelings tended; but allow me now to
                        return to the cottagers, whose story excited in me such various feelings of
                        indignation, delight, and wonder, but which all terminated in additional
                        love and reverence for my protectors (for so I loved, in an innocent, half
                        painful self-deceit, to call them).</tei-p>
                  </tei-said></tei-said>


            </tei-div>










            <tei-div n="2.6" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[2.84]" facs="pageImages/vol2/84.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter VI</tei-head>







               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                  <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">SOME time elapsed before I learned the history of my friends. It was one
                        which could not fail to impress itself deeply on my mind, unfolding as it
                        did a number of circumstances each interesting and wonderful to one so
                        utterly inexperienced as I was.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The name of the old man was <tei-persName data-origname="persName">De Lacey</tei-persName>. He was descended
                        from a good family in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName>, where he had lived for many years in affluence,
                        respected by his superiors, and beloved by his equals. His son was bred in
                        the <tei-pb n="[2.85 - page breaks after 'ser-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/85.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> service of his country; and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> had ranked with
                        ladies of the highest distinction. A few months before my arrival, they had
                        lived in a large and luxurious city, called <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>, surrounded by friends, and possessed of
                        every enjoyment which virtue, refinement of intellect, or taste, accompanied
                        by a moderate fortune, could afford.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The father of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> had been the cause of their ruin.
                        He was a <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Turkish</tei-foreign> merchant, and had inhabited <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName> for many years, when, for some
                        reason which I could not learn, he became obnoxious to the government. He
                        was seized and cast into prison the very day that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>
                        arrived from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002473" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Constantinople</tei-placeName>
                        to join him. He was tried, and condemned to death. The injustice of his
                        sentence was very flagrant; all <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName> was indignant; and it was judged that his religion and
                        wealth, rather than the <tei-pb n="[2.86]" facs="pageImages/vol2/86.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> crime
                        alleged against him, had been the cause of his condemnation.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> had been present at the trial; his horror and
                        indignation were uncontrollable, when he heard the decision of the court. He
                        made, at that moment, a solemn vow to deliver him, and then looked around
                        for the means. After many fruitless attempts to gain admittance to the
                        prison, he found a strongly grated window in an unguarded part of the
                        building, which lighted the dungeon of the unfortunate Mahometan; who,
                        loaded with chains, waited in despair the execution of the barbarous
                        sentence. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> visited the grate at night, and made
                        known to the prisoner his intentions in his favour. The
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName>, amazed and delighted, endeavoured to kindle
                        the zeal of his deliverer by promises of reward and wealth.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> rejected his offers with contempt; yet <tei-pb n="[2.87]" facs="pageImages/vol2/87.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> when he saw the lovely
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>, who was allowed to visit her father, and who,
                        by her gestures, expressed her lively gratitude, the youth could not help
                        owning to his own mind, that the captive possessed a treasure which would
                        fully reward his toil and hazard.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName> quickly perceived the impression that his
                        daughter had made on the heart of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, and
                        endeavoured to secure him more entirely in his interests by the promise of
                        her hand in marriage, so soon as he should be conveyed to a place of safety.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was too delicate to accept this offer; yet he
                        looked forward to the probability of the event as to that consummation of
                        his happiness.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">During the ensuing days, while the preparations were going forward for the
                        escape of the merchant, the zeal of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was warmed by
                        several letters <tei-pb n="[2.88]" facs="pageImages/vol2/88.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> that he
                        received from this lovely girl, who found means to express her thoughts in
                        the language of her lover by the aid of an old man, a servant of her
                        father's, who understood <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">French</tei-foreign>. She thanked him in the
                        most ardent terms for his intended services towards her father; and at the
                        same time deeply deplored her own fate.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I have copies of these letters; for I found means, during my residence in
                        the hovel, to procure the implements of writing; and the letters were often
                        in the hands of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> or <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName>.
                        Before I depart, I will give them to you, they will prove the truth of my
                        tale; but at present, as the sun is already far declined, I shall only have
                        time to repeat the substance of them to you.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> related, that her mother was a Christian Arab,
                        seized and made a slave by the Turks; recommended by <tei-pb n="[2.89]" facs="pageImages/vol2/89.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> her beauty, she had won the heart of the
                        father of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>, who married her. The young girl spoke
                        in high and enthusiastic terms of her mother, who, born in freedom spurned
                        the bondage to which she was now reduced. She instructed her daughter in the
                        tenets of her religion, and taught her to aspire to higher powers of
                        intellect, and an independence of spirit, forbidden to the female followers
                        of <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n79130881" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Mahomet</tei-persName>. This lady
                        died; but her lessons were indelibly impressed on the mind of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>, who sickened at the prospect of again
                        returning to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000004" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Asia</tei-placeName>, and the
                        being immured within the walls of a haram, allowed only to occupy herself
                        with puerile amusements, ill suited to the temper of her soul, now
                        accustomed to grand ideas and a noble emulation for virtue. The prospect of
                        marrying a Christian, and remaining in a country <tei-pb n="[2.90]" facs="pageImages/vol2/90.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> where women were allowed to take a rank
                        in society, was enchanting to her.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The day for the execution of the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName> was fixed; but,
                        on the night previous to it, he had quitted prison, and before morning was
                        distant many leagues from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> had procured passports in
                        the name of his father, sister, and himself. He had previously communicated
                        his plan to the former, who aided the deceit by quitting his house, under
                        the pretence of a journey, and concealed himself, with his daughter, in an
                        obscure part of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> conducted the fugitives through <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008772" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Lyons</tei-placeName>, and across <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1117354" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont Cenis</tei-placeName> to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7006074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Leghorn</tei-placeName>, where the merchant had decided to wait
                        a favourable opportunity of passing into some part of the
                           <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Turkish</tei-foreign> dominions.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> resolved to remain with her father until the
                        moment of his <tei-pb n="[2.91 - page breaks after 'depar-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/91.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> departure, before which time the
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName> renewed his promise that she should be united
                        to his deliverer; and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> remained with them in
                        expectation of that event; and in the mean time he enjoyed the society of
                        the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>, who exhibited towards him the simplest and
                        tenderest affection. They conversed with one another through the means of an
                        interpreter, and sometimes with the interpretation of looks; and
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> sang to him the divine airs of her native
                        country.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName> allowed this intimacy to take place, and
                        encouraged the hopes of the youthful lovers, while in his heart he had
                        formed far other plans. He loathed the idea that his daughter should be
                        united to a Christian; but he feared the resentment of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> if he should appear lukewarm; for he knew that
                        he was still in the power of his deliverer, if he should choose to betray
                           <tei-pb n="[2.92]" facs="pageImages/vol2/92.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> him to the Italian state
                        which they inhabited. He revolved a thousand plans by which he should be
                        enabled to prolong the deceit until it might be no longer necessary, and
                        secretly to take his daughter with him when he departed. His plans were
                        greatly facilitated by the news which arrived from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">The government of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName>
                        were greatly enraged at the escape of their victim, and spared no pains to
                        detect and punish his deliverer. The plot of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was
                        quickly discovered, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">De Lacey</tei-persName> and
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> were thrown into prison. The news reached
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, and roused him from his dream of pleasure.
                        His blind and aged father, and his gentle sister, lay in a noisome dungeon,
                        while he enjoyed the free air, and the society of her whom he loved. This
                        idea was torture to him. He quickly arranged with the
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName>, that if the <tei-pb n="[2.93 - page breaks after 'lat-']" facs="pageImages/vol2/93.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        latter should find a favourable opportunity for escape before
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> could return to Italy,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> should remain as a boarder at a convent at
                        Leghorn; and then, quitting the lovely <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName>, he
                        hastened to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>, and
                        delivered himself up to the vengeance of the law, hoping to free
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">De Lacey</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Agatha</tei-persName> by this
                        proceeding.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">He did not succeed. They remained confined for five months before the trial
                        took place; the result of which deprived them of their fortune, and
                        condemned them to a perpetual exile from their native country.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">They found a miserable asylum in the cottage in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7000084" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Germany</tei-placeName>, where I discovered them.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> soon learned that the treacherous
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName>, for whom he and his family endured such
                        unheard-of oppression, on discovering that his deliverer was thus reduced to
                        poverty and <tei-pb n="[2.94]" facs="pageImages/vol2/94.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> impotence, became
                        a traitor to good feeling and honour, and had quitted <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000080" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Italy</tei-placeName> with his daughter, insultingly sending
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> a pittance of money to aid him, as he said, in
                        some plan of future maintenance.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Such were the events that preyed on the heart of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>,
                        and rendered him, when I first saw him, the most miserable of his family. He
                        could have endured poverty, and when this distress had been the meed of his
                        virtue, he would have gloried in it: but the ingratitude of the
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName>, and the loss of his beloved
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>, were misfortunes more bitter and irreparable.
                        The arrival of the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName> now infused new life into
                        his soul.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">When the news reached <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7006074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Leghorn</tei-placeName>, that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName> was deprived of his
                        wealth and rank, the merchant commanded his daughter to think no more of her
                           <tei-pb n="[2.95]" facs="pageImages/vol2/95.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> lover, but to prepare to
                        return with him to her native country. The generous nature of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> was outraged by this command; she attempted to
                        expostulate with her father, but he left her angrily, reiterating his
                        tyrannical mandate.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">A few days after, the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Turk</tei-persName> entered his daughter's
                        apartment, and told her hastily, that he had reason to believe that his
                        residence at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7006074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Leghorn</tei-placeName> had
                        been divulged, and that he should speedily be delivered up to the
                           <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">French</tei-foreign> government; he had, consequently, hired a
                        vessel to convey him to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002473" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Constantinople</tei-placeName>, for which city he should sail in a few
                        hours. He intended to leave his daughter under the care of a confidential
                        servant, to follow at her leisure with the greater part of his property,
                        which had not yet arrived at Leghorn.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">When alone, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> resolved in her <tei-pb n="[2.96]" facs="pageImages/vol2/96.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> own mind the plan of conduct that it
                        would become her to pursue in this emergency. A residence in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000144" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Turkey</tei-placeName> was abhorrent to her; her
                        religion and her feelings were alike adverse to it. By some papers of her
                        father's, which fell into her hands, she heard of the exile of her lover,
                        and learnt the name of the spot where he then resided. She hesitated some
                        time, but at length she formed her determination. Taking with her some
                        jewels that belonged to her, and a small sum of money, she quitted Italy,
                        with an attendant, a native of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7006074" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Leghorn</tei-placeName>, but who understood the common language of
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000144" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Turkey</tei-placeName>, and departed for
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7000084" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Germany</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">She arrived in safety at a town about twenty leagues from the cottage of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">De Lacey</tei-persName>, when her attendant fell dangerously ill.
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName> nursed her with the most devoted affection;
                        but the <tei-pb n="[2.97]" facs="pageImages/vol2/97.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> poor girl died, and
                        the <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Arabian</tei-persName> was left alone, unacquainted with the
                        language of the country, and utterly ignorant of the customs of the world.
                        She fell, however, into good hands. The Italian had mentioned the name of
                        the spot for which they were bound; and, after her death, the woman of the
                        house in which they had lived took care that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Safie</tei-persName>
                        should arrive in safety at the cottage of her lover.</tei-p></tei-said></tei-said>







            </tei-div>


            <tei-div n="2.7" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[2.98]" facs="pageImages/vol2/98.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter VII</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                  <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">SUCH was the history of my beloved cottagers. It impressed me deeply. I
                        learned, from the views of social life which it developed, to admire their
                        virtues, and to deprecate the vices of mankind.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">As yet I looked upon crime as a distant evil; benevolence and generosity
                        were ever present before me, inciting within me a desire to become an actor
                        in the busy scene where so many admirable qualities were called forth and
                        displayed. But, in giving an account of the progress of my intellect, I must
                           <tei-pb n="[2.99]" facs="pageImages/vol2/99.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> not omit a circumstance
                        which occurred in the beginning of the month of <tei-date data-origname="date">August</tei-date> of the
                        same year.</tei-p>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">One night, during my accustomed visit to the neighbouring wood, where I
                        collected my own food, and brought home firing for my protectors, I found on
                        the ground a leathern portmanteau, containing several articles of dress and
                        some books. I eagerly seized the prize, and returned with it to my hovel.
                        Fortunately the books were written in the language the elements of which I
                        had acquired at the cottage; they consisted of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-title data-origname="title">Paradise Lost</tei-title></tei-hi>, a volume of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-title data-origname="title">Plutarch's Lives</tei-title></tei-hi>, and the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-title data-origname="title">
                              <tei-ref target="Sorrows_of_Young_Werther_" corresp="Sorrows_of_Young_Werther" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="corresp target"> Sorrows of Werter </tei-ref>
                           </tei-title></tei-hi>
                        <tei-note xml:id="Sorrows_of_Young_Werther" id="Sorrows_of_Young_Werther" target="Sorrows_of_Young_Werther_" type="editorial" resp="editors.xml#AF" data-origname="note" data-origatts="resp type target xml:id">
                           <tei-graphic url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0f/Goethe_1774.JPG" data-origname="graphic" data-origatts="url" data-empty=""/>
                           <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-ref target="https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/g/goethe/sorrows-of-young-werther/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">The Sorrows of Young Werther</tei-ref></tei-hi> is an epistolary novel by
                           Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, first published in 1774. The story follows
                           the life of <tei-ref target="https://www.britannica.com/topic/The-Sorrows-of-Young-Werther" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Werther</tei-ref>, a young artist, who is writing to his friend Wilhelm.
                           Werther falls in love with Charlotte, a woman already promised to his
                           friend, Albert. Despite the agony caused by this love triangle, Werther
                           cultivates a friendship with the couple, until the pain and sorrow of his
                           love overpowers him and he leaves. When Werther returns, he finds the
                           couple now married. He lessens his visits to Charlotte, out of respect
                           for her husband, but ultimately realizes that in order to resolve the
                           love triangle, he must die. He commits suicide, and the novel ends with
                           Charlotte potentially dying of a broken heart. The novel was an amazing
                           hit, creating a wave not only in literary circles but also across fashion
                           and society. As <tei-ref target="https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/13-reasons-why-and-suicide-contagion1/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Patrick Devitt</tei-ref> summarizes, "It was widely believed that von
                           Goethe’s work led to a wave of young men deciding to end their lives all
                           over Europe, many of whom were dressed in the same clothing as von
                           Goethe’s description of Werther and using similar pistols. Some even had
                           the copies of the novel beside their bodies with the page opened to the
                           page of the suicide scene." This became known as the <tei-ref target="https://www.openaccessgovernment.org/the-werther-effect/42915/" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Werther Effect."</tei-ref>The novel was banned in several countries,
                           only escalating its popularity. To learn more about the Werther Effect,
                           see <tei-ref target="http://www.jstor.org/stable/2094294" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">David Phillips’
                              article in <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The American Sociological
                              Review</tei-hi></tei-ref>. The image to the right shows the title page of the
                           first edition of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi>, via Wikimedia Commons.
                           Due to its unbridled passion, valuing human emotion over human life and
                           rational thought <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi> was popular among the
                           Romantics. obvious influence over Mary Shelley’s novel, from the
                           epistolary format of <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> to the
                           reflections on the value of life, not only in creating life but ending
                           life (Victor contemplates suicide and the Creature praises suicide).
                           Finally, Shelley’s novel <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi> is a book of
                           unrequited love: Frankenstein’s bride is killed on their wedding night,
                           the Creature’s love is ripped apart by Frankenstein, and the Creature
                           never receives or love from another. Ultimately, the Creature most
                           identifies with <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi> as he is desperate to feel
                           complete through love. By invoking <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi> in
                           conjunction with her Creature, Shelley is both highlighting and
                           criticizing Goethe’s novel for the theme of love triumphing over all.
                           First, Shelley is critiquing <tei-ref target="https://www.history.com/topics/enlightenment" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Enlightenment
                              thinking</tei-ref> by pointing out that problems cannot always be solved
                           using logic, especially in regards to building a human being as humans
                           are more than a series of automations or mechanical processes—humans are
                           emotional and unpredictable. In the same vein, Shelley is critiquing the
                           idea that love can be engineered to solve problems. Instead, she argues
                           the romantic idea of organically developing love, like that between Safi
                           and Felix, is desirable, unlike the engineered or arranged romances of
                           Frankenstein and Elizabeth (or the Creature’s partner to-be). To read
                           more on the reception and meanings within <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi>
                           see Bruce Duncan’s <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.7722/j.ctt81q50" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"><tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Goethe’s ‘Werther’ and the Critics</tei-hi></tei-ref>. For
                           the influence <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Sorrows</tei-hi> on <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>, see Joyce Carol Oates’’<tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/1343306" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">Frankenstein’s Fallen
                              Angel</tei-ref>, Rebecca Baumann’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein 200: The
                              Birth, Life, and Resurrection of Mary Shelley's Monster</tei-hi>
                           <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt22p7j32.13" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target"> (especially
                              "Case 8: The Monster’s Books")</tei-ref>, and Clayton Koelb’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">The Revivifying Word: Literature, Philosophy, and the
                              Theory of Life in Europe's Romantic Age</tei-hi> (especially <tei-ref target="https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.7722/j.ctt81twn.13" data-origname="ref" data-origatts="target">"Chapter
                              8: "I sickened as I read": Mary Shelley’s <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend">Frankenstein</tei-hi>"</tei-ref>). </tei-note>. The possession of these
                        treasures gave me extreme delight; I now continually studied and exercised
                        my mind upon these histories, whilst my friends were employed in their
                        ordinary occupations.</tei-p>
                     <tei-pb n="[2.100]" facs="pageImages/vol2/100.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-p data-origname="p">I can hardly describe to you the effect of these books. They produced in me
                        an infinity of new images and feelings, that sometimes raised me to ecstasy,
                        but more frequently sunk me into the lowest dejection. In the <tei-hi rend="italic" data-origname="hi" data-origatts="rend"><tei-title data-origname="title">Sorrows of Werter</tei-title></tei-hi>, besides the interest
                        of its simple and affecting story, so many opinions are canvassed, and so
                        many lights thrown upon what had hitherto been to me obscure subjects, that
                        I found in it a never-ending source of speculation and astonishment. The
                        gentle and domestic manners it described, combined with lofty sentiments and
                        feelings, which had for their object something out of self, accorded well
                        with my experience among my protectors, and with the wants which were for
                        ever alive in my own bosom. But I thought <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Werter</tei-persName>
                        himself a more divine being than I had ever beheld or <tei-pb n="[2.101]" facs="pageImages/vol2/101.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> imagined; his character contained no
                        pretension, but it sunk deep. The disquisitions upon death and suicide were
