                     and he turned his thoughts towards the best method of eradicating the remains
                     of my melancholy, which every now and then would return by fits, and with a
                     devouring blackness overcast the approaching sunshine. At these moments I took
                     refuge in the most perfect solitude. I passed whole <tei-pb n="[3.3]" facs="pageImages/vol3/jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> days on the lake alone in a little boat,
                     watching the clouds, and listening to the rippling of the waves, silent and
                     listless. But the fresh air and bright sun seldom failed to restore me to some
                     degree of composure; and, on my return, I met the salutations of my friends
                     with a readier smile and a more cheerful heart.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It was after my return from one of these rambles that my father, calling me
                     aside, thus addressed me:—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am happy to remark, my dear son, that you have resumed
                        your former pleasures, and seem to be returning to yourself. And yet you are
                        still unhappy, and still avoid our society. For some time I was lost in
                        conjecture as to the cause of this; but yesterday an idea struck me, and if
                        it is well founded, I conjure you to avow it. Reserve on such a point would
                        be not only <tei-pb n="[3.4]" facs="pageImages/vol3/4.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> useless, but draw
                        down treble misery on us all."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I trembled violently at this exordium, and my father continued—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I confess, my son, that I have always looked forward to
                        your marriage with your cousin as the tie of our domestic comfort, and the
                        stay of my declining years. You were attached to each other from your
                        earliest infancy; you studied together, and appeared, in dispositions and
                        tastes, entirely suited to one another. But so blind is the experience of
                        man, that what I conceived to be the best assistants to my plan may have
                        entirely destroyed it. You, perhaps, regard her as your sister, without any
                        wish that she might become your wife. Nay, you may have met with another
                        whom you may love; and, considering yourself as bound in honour to your
                        cousin, this struggle <tei-pb n="[3.5]" facs="pageImages/vol3/5.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> may
                        occasion the poignant misery which you appear to feel."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear father, re-assure yourself. I love my cousin
                        tenderly and sincerely. I never saw any woman who excited, as
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> does, my warmest admiration and affection.
                        My future hopes and prospects are entirely bound up in the expectation of
                        our union."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"The expression of your sentiments on this subject, my dear
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, gives me more pleasure than I have for some
                        time experienced. If you feel thus, we shall assuredly be happy, however
                        present events may cast a gloom over us. But it is this gloom, which appears
                        to have taken so strong a hold of your mind, that I wish to dissipate. Tell
                        me, therefore, whether you object to an immediate solemnisation of the
                        marriage. We have been unfortunate, and recent events have drawn us from <tei-pb n="[3.6]" facs="pageImages/vol3/6.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> that every-day tranquillity
                        befitting my years and infirmities. You are younger; yet I do not suppose,
                        possessed as you are of a competent fortune, that an early marriage would at
                        all interfere with any future plans of honour and utility that you may have
                        formed. Do not suppose, however, that I wish to dictate happiness to you, or
                        that a delay on your part would cause me any serious uneasiness. Interpret
                        my words with candour, and answer me, I conjure you, with confidence and
                        sincerity."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I listened to my father in silence, and remained for some time incapable of
                     offering any reply. I revolved rapidly in my mind a multitude of thoughts, and
                     endeavoured to arrive at some conclusion. Alas! to me the idea of an immediate
                     union with my cousin was one of horror and dismay. I was bound <tei-pb n="[3.7]" facs="pageImages/vol3/7.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> by a solemn promise, which I had not yet
                     fulfilled, and dared not break; or, if I did, what manifold miseries might not
                     impend over me and my devoted family! Could I enter into a festival with this
                     deadly weight yet hanging round my neck, and bowing me to the ground. I must
                     perform my engagement, and let the monster depart with his mate, before I
                     allowed myself to enjoy the delight of an union from which I expected
                     peace.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I remembered also the necessity imposed upon me of either journeying to
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>, or entering into a
                     long correspondence with those philosophers of that country, whose knowledge
                     and discoveries were of indispensable use to me in my present undertaking. The
                     latter method of obtaining the desired intelligence was dilatory and
                     unsatisfactory: besides, any variation was <tei-pb n="[3.8]" facs="pageImages/vol3/8.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> agreeable to me, and I was delighted with the
                     idea of spending a year or two in change of scene and variety of occupation, in
                     absence from my family; during which period some event might happen which would
                     restore me to them in peace and happiness: my promise might be fulfilled, and
                     the monster have departed; or some accident might occur to destroy him, and put
                     an end to my slavery for ever.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">These feelings dictated my answer to my father. I expressed a wish to visit
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>; but, concealing the
                     true reasons of this request, I clothed my desires under the guise of wishing
                     to travel and see the world before I sat down for life within the walls of my
                     native town.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I urged my entreaty with earnestness, and my father was easily induced to
                     comply; for a more indulgent and <tei-pb n="[3.9]" facs="pageImages/vol3/9.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     less dictatorial parent did not exist upon earth. Our plan was soon arranged. I
                     should travel to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012346" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Strasburgh</tei-placeName>,
                     where <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> would join me. Some short time would be
                     spent in the towns of Holland, and our principal stay would be in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>. We should return by <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName>; and it was agreed that the tour
                     should occupy the space of two years.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father pleased himself with the reflection, that my union with
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> should take place immediately on my return to
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"These two years,"</tei-said> said he, <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"will pass swiftly,
                        and it will be the last delay that will oppose itself to your happiness.
                        And, indeed, I earnestly desire that period to arrive, when we shall all be
                        united, and neither hopes or fears arise to disturb our domestic
                        calm."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am content,"</tei-said> I replied, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"with
                           <tei-pb n="[3.10]" facs="pageImages/vol3/10.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> your arrangement. By that
                        time we shall both have become wiser, and I hope happier, than we at present
                        are."</tei-said> I sighed; but my father kindly forbore to question me further
                     concerning the cause of my dejection. He hoped that new scenes, and the
                     amusement of travelling, would restore my tranquillity.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I now made arrangements for my journey; but one feeling haunted me, which
                     filled me with fear and agitation. During my absence I should leave my friends
                     unconscious of the existence of their enemy, and unprotected from his attacks,
                     exasperated as he might be by my departure. But he had promised to follow me
                     wherever I might go; and would he not accompany me to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>? This imagination was dreadful in itself,
                     but soothing, inasmuch as it supposed the safety of my friends. I was agonized
                     with the idea of the <tei-pb n="[3.11 - page breaks after 'pos-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/11.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> possibility that the reverse of this might
                     happen. But through the whole period during which I was the slave of my
                     creature, I allowed myself to be governed by the impulses of the moment; and my
                     present sensations strongly intimated that the fiend would follow me, and
                     exempt my family from the danger of his machinations.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It was in the latter end of August that I departed, to pass two years of exile.
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> approved of the reasons of my departure, and
                     only regretted that she had not the same opportunities of enlarging her
                     experience, and cultivating her understanding. She wept, however, as she bade
                     me farewell, and entreated me to return happy and tranquil. <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"We all,"</tei-said> said she, <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"depend
                        upon you; and if you are miserable, what must be our feelings?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[3.12]" facs="pageImages/vol3/12.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I threw myself into the carriage that was to convey me away, hardly knowing
                     whither I was going, and careless of what was passing around. I remembered
                     only, and it was with a bitter anguish that I reflected on it, to order that my
                     chemical instruments should be packed to go with me: for I resolved to fulfil
                     my promise while abroad, and return, if possible, a free man. Filled with
                     dreary imaginations, I passed through many beautiful and majestic scenes; but
                     my eyes were fixed and unobserving. I could only think of the bourne of my
                     travels, and the work which was to occupy me whilst they endured.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">After some days spent in listless indolence, during which I traversed many
                     leagues, I arrived at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012346" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Strasburgh</tei-placeName>, where I waited two days for
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>. He came. Alas, how great was the contrast
                     between <tei-pb n="[3.13]" facs="pageImages/vol3/13.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> us! He was alive to
                     every new scene; joyful when he saw the beauties of the setting sun, and more
                     happy when he beheld it rise, and recommence a new day. He pointed out to me
                     the shifting colours of the landscape, and the appearances of the sky. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"This is what it is to live,"</tei-said> he cried, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"now I enjoy existence! But you, my dear Frankenstein,
                        wherefore are you desponding and sorrowful?"</tei-said> In truth, I was occupied
                     by gloomy thoughts, and neither saw the descent of the evening star, nor the
                     golden sun-rise reflected in the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName>.—And you, my friend, would be far more amused with the
                     journal of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, who observed the scenery with an eye
                     of feeling and delight, than to listen to my reflections. I, a miserable
                     wretch, haunted by a curse that shut up every avenue to enjoyment.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We had agreed to descend the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName><tei-pb n="[3.14]" facs="pageImages/vol3/14.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> in a boat
                     from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012346" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Strasburgh</tei-placeName> to Rotterdam,
                     whence we might take shipping for <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>. During this voyage, we passed many willowy islands, and
                     saw several beautiful towns. We staid a day at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7129524" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Manheim</tei-placeName>, and, on the fifth from our departure from
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012346" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Strasburgh</tei-placeName>, arrived at
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7004449" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mayence</tei-placeName>. The course of the
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName> below <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7004449" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mayence</tei-placeName> becomes much more picturesque.
                     The river descends rapidly, and winds between hills, not high, but steep, and
                     of beautiful forms. We saw many ruined castles standing on the edges of
                     precipices, surrounded by black woods, high and inaccessible. This part of the
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName>, indeed, presents a
                     singularly variegated landscape. In one spot you view rugged hills, ruined
                     castles overlooking tremendous precipices, with the dark <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName> rushing beneath; and, on the sudden turn of
                     a promontory, flourishing vineyards, with <tei-pb n="[3.15]" facs="pageImages/vol3/15.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> green sloping banks, and a meandering river,
                     and populous towns, occupy the scene.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We travelled at the time of the vintage, and heard the song of the labourers,
                     as we glided down the stream. Even I, depressed in mind, and my spirits
                     continually agitated by gloomy feelings, even I was pleased. I lay at the
                     bottom of the boat, and, as I gazed on the cloudless blue sky, I seemed to
                     drink in a tranquillity to which I had long been a stranger. And if these were
                     my sensations, who can describe those of Henry? He felt as if he had been
                     transported to Fairy-land, and enjoyed a happiness seldom tasted by man. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I have seen,"</tei-said> he said, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"the most
                        beautiful scenes of my own country; I have visited the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007492" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">lakes of Lucerne and Uri</tei-placeName>, where the snowy
                        mountains descend almost <tei-pb n="[3.16 - page breaks after 'perpendicu-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/16.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> perpendicularly to the water, casting
                        black and impenetrable shades, which would cause a gloomy and mournful
                        appearance, were it not for the most verdant islands that relieve the eye by
                        their gay appearance; I have seen this lake agitated by a tempest, when the
                        wind tore up whirlwinds of water, and gave you an idea of what the
                        water-spout must be on the great ocean, and the waves dash with fury the
                        base of the mountain, where the priest and his mistress were overwhelmed by
                        an avalanche, and where their dying voices are still said to be heard amid
                        the pauses of the nightly wind; I have seen the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007843" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">mountains of La Valais</tei-placeName>, and the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003763" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Pays de Vaud</tei-placeName>: but this country,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, pleases me more than all those wonders. The
                        mountains of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName> are
                        more majestic and strange; but there is a charm in the banks of this divine
                        river, <tei-pb n="[3.17]" facs="pageImages/vol3/17.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> that I never before
                        saw equalled. Look at that castle which overhangs yon precipice; and that
                        also on the island, almost concealed amongst the foliage of those lovely
                        trees; and now that group of labourers coming from among their vines; and
                        that village half-hid in the recess of the mountain. Oh, surely, the spirit
                        that inhabits and guards this place has a soul more in harmony with man,
                        than those who pile the glacier, or retire to the inaccessible peaks of the
                        mountains of our own country."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>! beloved friend! even now it delights me to record
                     your words, and to dwell on the praise of which you are so eminently deserving.
                     He was a being formed in the <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"very poetry of
                        nature."</tei-said> His wild and enthusiastic imagination was chastened by the
                        <tei-pb n="[3.18 - page breaks after 'sen-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/18.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     sensibility of his heart. His soul overflowed with ardent affections, and his
                     friendship was of that devoted and wondrous nature that the worldy-minded teach
                     us to look for only in the imagination. But even human sympathies were not
                     sufficient to satisfy his eager mind. The scenery of external nature, which
                     others regard only with admiration, he loved with ardour:</tei-p>
                  <!-- question -->
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">------ <tei-quote data-origname="quote"><tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The sounding cataract <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Haunted him like a passion: the
                        tall rock, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>The mountain, and the deep and gloomy wood, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Their
                        colours and their forms, were then to him <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>An appetite; a feeling, and a
                        love, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>That had no need of a remoter charm, <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>By thought supplied, or
                        any interest <tei-lb data-origname="lb" data-empty=""/>Unborrowed from the eye.</tei-quote></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">And where does he now exist? Is this gentle and lovely being lost forever? Has
                     this mind so replete with <tei-pb n="[3.19]" facs="pageImages/vol3/19.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> ideas,
                     imaginations fanciful and magnificent, which formed a world, whose existence
                     depended on the life of its creator; has this mind perished? Does it now only
                     exist in my memory? No, it is not thus; your form so divinely wrought, and
                     beaming with beauty, has decayed, but your spirit still visits and consoles
                     your unhappy friend.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Pardon this gush of sorrow; these ineffectual words are but a slight tribute to
                     the unexampled worth of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>, but they soothe my heart,
                     overflowing with the anguish which his remembrance creates. I will proceed with
                     my tale.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Beyond <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7004446" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cologne</tei-placeName> we descended to
                     the plains of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1003759" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Holland</tei-placeName>; and we
                     resolved to post the remainder of our way; for the wind was contrary, and the
                     stream of the river was too gentle to aid us.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Our journey here lost the interest <tei-pb n="[3.20]" facs="pageImages/vol3/20.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> arising from beautiful scenery; but we arrived in a few days at Rotterdam,
                     whence we proceeded by sea to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>. It was on a clear morning, in the latter days of
                     September, that I first saw the white cliffs of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008653" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Britain</tei-placeName>. The banks of the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011913" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Thames</tei-placeName> presented a new scene; they were flat, but
                     fertile, and almost every town was marked by the remembrance of some story. We
                     saw <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011913" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Tilbury Fort</tei-placeName>, and
                     remembered the Spanish armada; <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011614" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Gravesend</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011805" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Woolwich</tei-placeName>, and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7018915" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Greenwich</tei-placeName>, places which I had heard of even in my country.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">At length, we saw the numerous steeples of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1100093" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">St.
                        Paul's</tei-placeName> towering above all, and the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1100671" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Tower</tei-placeName> famed in English history.</tei-p>"</tei-said>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="3.2" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[3.21]" facs="pageImages/vol3/21.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter II</tei-head>







               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"<tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>was our present point of
                     rest; we determined to remain several months in this wonderful and celebrated
                     city. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> desired the intercourse of the men of genius
                     and talent who flourished at this time; but this was with me a secondary
                     object; I was principally occupied with the means of obtaining the information
                     necessary for the completion of my promise, and quickly availed myself of the
                     letters of introduction that I had brought with me, addressed to the most
                     distinguished natural philosophers.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">If this journey had taken place during <tei-pb n="[3.22]" facs="pageImages/vol3/22.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> my days of study and happiness, it would
                     have afforded me inexpressible pleasure. But a blight had come over my
                     existence, and I only visited these people for the sake of the information they
                     might give me on the subject in which my interest was so terribly profound.
                     Company was irksome to me; when alone, I could fill my mind with the sights of
                     heaven and earth; the voice of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> soothed me, and I
                     could thus cheat myself into a transitory peace. But busy uninteresting joyous
                     faces brought back despair to my heart. I saw an insurmountable barrier placed
                     between me and my fellow-men; this barrier was sealed with the blood of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName> and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>; and to
                     reflect on the events connected with those names filled my soul with
                     anguish.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But in <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> I saw the image of my former self; he was
                     inquisitive, and <tei-pb n="[3.23 - page breaks after 'an-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/23.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> anxious to gain experience and instruction.
                     The difference of manners which he observed was to him an inexhaustible source
                     of instruction and amusement. He was for ever busy; and the only check to his
                     enjoyments was my sorrowful and dejected mien. I tried to conceal this as much
                     as possible, that I might not debar him from the pleasures natural to one who
                     was entering on a new scene of life, undisturbed by any care or bitter
                     recollection. I often refused to accompany him, alleging another engagement,
                     that I might remain alone. I now also began to collect the materials necessary
                     for my new creation, and this was to me like the torture of single drops of
                     water continually falling on the head. Every thought that was devoted to it was
                     an extreme anguish, and every word that I spoke in allusion to it <tei-pb n="[3.24]" facs="pageImages/vol3/24.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> caused my lips to quiver, and my
                     heart to palpitate.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">After passing some months in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>, we received a letter from a person in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002444" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Scotland</tei-placeName>, who had formerly been our
                     visitor at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. He mentioned
                     the beauties of his native country, and asked us if those were not sufficient
                     allurements to induce us to prolong our journey as far north as Perth, where he
                     resided. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> eagerly desired to accept this
                     invitation; and I, although I abhorred society, wished to view again mountains
                     and streams, and all the wondrous works with which Nature adorns her chosen
                     dwelling-places.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We had arrived in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName> at
                     the beginning of October, and it was now February. We accordingly determined to
                     commence our journey towards the north at the expiration of another month. In
                     this expedition we did not <tei-pb n="[3.25]" facs="pageImages/vol3/25.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     intend to follow the great road to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Edinburgh</tei-placeName>, but to visit <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011919" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Windsor</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Oxford</tei-placeName>, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1030005" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Matlock</tei-placeName>,
                     and the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7010206" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cumberland lakes</tei-placeName>,
                     resolving to arrive at the completion of this tour about the end of July. I
                     packed up my chemical instruments, and the materials I had collected, resolving
                     to finish my labours in some obscure nook in the northern highlands of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002444" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Scotland</tei-placeName>.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We quitted <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName> on the
                        <tei-date data-origname="date">27th of March</tei-date>, and remained a few days at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011919" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Windsor</tei-placeName>, rambling in its beautiful forest. This
                     was a new scene to us mountaineers; the majestic oaks, the quantity of game,
                     and the herds of stately deer, were all novelties to us.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">From thence we proceeded to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Oxford</tei-placeName>. As we entered this city, our minds were filled with the
                     remembrance of the events that had been transacted there more than a century
                     and a half <tei-pb n="[3.26]" facs="pageImages/vol3/26.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> before. It was here
                     that <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n79132433" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Charles I</tei-persName>. had collected
                     his forces. This city had remained faithful to him, after the whole nation had
                     forsaken his cause to join the standard of parliament and liberty. The memory
                     of that unfortunate king, and his companions, the amiable <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n83180215" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="key type">Falkland</tei-persName>, the insolent <tei-persName type="lcnaf" key="n85115759" cert="low" data-origname="persName" data-origatts="cert key type">Gower</tei-persName>, his queen, and
                     son, gave a peculiar interest to every part of the city, which they might be
                     supposed to have inhabited. The spirit of elder days found a dwelling here, and
                     we delighted to trace its footsteps. If these feelings had not found an
                     imaginary gratification, the appearance of the city had yet in itself
                     sufficient beauty to obtain our admiration. The colleges are ancient and
                     picturesque; the streets are almost magnificent; and the lovely Isis, which
                     flows beside it through meadows of exquisite verdure, is spread forth into a
                        <tei-pb n="[3.27]" facs="pageImages/vol3/27.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> placid expanse of waters,
                     which reflects its majestic assemblage of towers, and spires, and domes,
                     embosomed among aged trees.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I enjoyed this scene; and yet my enjoyment was embittered both by the memory of
                     the past, and the anticipation of the future. I was formed for peaceful
                     happiness. During my youthful days discontent never visited my mind; and if I
                     was ever overcome by ennui, the sight of what is beautiful in nature, or the
                     study of what is excellent and sublime in the productions of man, could always
                     interest my heart, and communicate elasticity to my spirits. But I am a blasted
                     tree; the bolt has entered my soul; and I felt then that I should survive to
                     exhibit, what I shall soon cease to be—a miserable spectacle of wrecked
                     humanity, pitiable to others, and abhorrent to myself.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[3.28]" facs="pageImages/vol3/28.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We passed a considerable period at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Oxford</tei-placeName>, rambling among its environs, and endeavouring to
                     identify every spot which might relate to the most animating epoch of
                        <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">English</tei-foreign> history. Our little voyages of discovery were
                     often prolonged by the successive objects that presented themselves. We visited
                     the tomb of the illustrious Hampden, and the field on which that patriot fell.
                     For a moment my soul was elevated from its debasing and miserable fears, to
                     contemplate the divine ideas of liberty and self-sacrifice, of which these
                     sights were the monuments and the remembrancers. For an instant I dared to
                     shake off my chains, and look around me with a free and lofty spirit; but the
                     iron had eaten into my flesh, and I sank again, trembling and hopeless, into my
                     miserable self.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We left <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Oxford</tei-placeName> with regret, and
                        <tei-pb n="[3.29 - page breaks after 'pro-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/29.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     proceeded to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1030005" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Matlock</tei-placeName>, which was
                     our next place of rest. The country in the neighbourhood of this village
                     resembled, to a greater degree, the scenery of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName>; but everything is on a lower scale,
                     and the green hills want the crown of distant white <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Alps</tei-placeName>, which always attend on the piny mountains of
                     my native country. We visited the wondrous cave, and the little cabinets of
                     natural history, where the curiosities are disposed in the same manner as in
                     the collections at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1035711" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Servox</tei-placeName> and
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1032562" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Chamounix</tei-placeName>. The latter name
                     made me tremble, when pronounced by <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>; and I hastened
                     to quit <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1030005" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Matlock</tei-placeName>, with which
                     that terrible scene was thus associated.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">From <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7010684" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Derby</tei-placeName> still journeying
                     northward, we passed two months in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011987" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cumberland</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="5000223" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Westmoreland</tei-placeName>. I could now almost fancy myself among the <tei-pb n="[3.30]" facs="pageImages/vol3/30.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Swiss mountains</tei-placeName>. The little
                     patches of snow which yet lingered on the northern sides of the mountains, the
                     lakes, and the dashing of the rocky streams, were all familiar and dear sights
                     to me. Here also we made some acquaintances, who almost contrived to cheat me
                     into happiness. The delight of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> was proportionably
                     greater than mine; his mind expanded in the company of men of talent, and he
                     found in his own nature greater capacities and resources than he could have
                     imagined himself to have possessed while he associated with his inferiors.
                        <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I could pass my life here,"</tei-said> said he to me;
                        <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"and among these mountains I should scarcely regret
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName> and the
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName>."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But he found that a traveller's life is one that includes much pain amidst its
                     enjoyments. His feelings are for ever on the stretch; and when he <tei-pb n="[3.31 - page breaks after 'be-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/31.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> begins
                     to sink into repose, he finds himself obliged to quit that on which he rests in
                     pleasure for something new, which again engages his attention, and which also
                     he forsakes for other novelties.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We had scarcely visited the various lakes of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011987" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cumberland</tei-placeName> and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="5000223" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Westmoreland</tei-placeName>., and conceived an affection for some of the
                     inhabitants, when the period of our appointment with our
                        <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Scotch</tei-foreign> friend approached, and we left them to travel on.
                     For my own part I was not sorry. I had now neglected my promise for some time,
                     and I feared the effects of the dæmon's disappointment. He might remain in
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName>, and wreak his
                     vengeance on my relatives. This idea pursued me, and tormented me at every
                     moment from which I might otherwise have snatched repose and peace. I waited
                     for my letters with feverish <tei-pb n="[3.32 - page begins after 'im-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/32.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> impatience: if they were delayed, I was
                     miserable, and overcome by a thousand fears; and when they arrived, and I saw
                     the superscription of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> or my father, I hardly
                     dared to read and ascertain my fate. Sometimes I thought that the fiend
                     followed me, and might expedite my remissness by murdering my companion. When
                     these thoughts possessed me, I would not quit <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> for a
                     moment, but followed him as his shadow, to protect him from the fancied rage of
                     his destroyer. I felt as if I had committed some great crime, the consciousness
                     of which haunted me. I was guiltless, but I had indeed drawn down a horrible
                     curse upon my head, as mortal as that of crime.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I visited <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Edinburgh</tei-placeName> with
                     languid eyes and mind; and yet that city might have interested the most
                     unfortunate being. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> did not like it so well <tei-pb n="[3.33]" facs="pageImages/vol3/33.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> as <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011931" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Oxford</tei-placeName>; for the antiquity of the latter city was
                     more pleasing to him. But the beauty and regularity of the new town of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Edinburgh</tei-placeName>, its romantic
                     castle, and its environs, the most delightful in the world, <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7465617" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Arthur's Seat</tei-placeName>, St. Bernard's Well, and
                     the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1110561" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Pentland Hills</tei-placeName>, compensated
                     him for the change, and filled him with cheerfulness and admiration. But I was
                     impatient to arrive at the termination of my journey.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We left <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Edinburgh</tei-placeName> in a week,
                     passing through <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1050546" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Coupar</tei-placeName>,
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009562" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">St. Andrew's</tei-placeName>, and along the
                     banks of the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1130681" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Tay</tei-placeName>, to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009702" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Perth</tei-placeName>, where our friend expected us.
                     But I was in no mood to laugh and talk with strangers, or enter into their
                     feelings or plans with the good humour expected from a guest; and accordingly I
                     told <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> that I wished to make the tour of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002444" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Scotland</tei-placeName> alone. <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Do
                           <tei-pb n="[3.34]" facs="pageImages/vol3/34.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> you,"</tei-said> said I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"enjoy yourself, and let this be our rendezvous. I may be
                        absent a month or two; but do not interfere with my motions, I entreat you:
                        leave me to peace and solitude for a short time; and when I return, I hope
                        it will be with a lighter heart, more congenial to your own
                     temper."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName> wished to dissuade me; but, seeing me bent on this
                     plan, ceased to remonstrate. He entreated me to write often. <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I had rather be with you,"</tei-said> he said, <tei-said who="#clerval" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"in your solitary rambles, than with these
                           <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">Scotch</tei-foreign> people, whom I do not know: hasten then, my
                        dear friend, to return, that I may again feel myself somewhat at home, which
                        I cannot do in your absence."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Having parted from my friend, I determined to visit some remote spot of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002444" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Scotland</tei-placeName>, and finish my work
                     in solitude. I did not doubt but that the <tei-pb n="[3.35]" facs="pageImages/vol3/35.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> monster followed me, and would discover
                     himself to me when I should have finished, that he might receive his
                     companion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">With this resolution I traversed the northern highlands, and fixed on one of
                     the remotest of the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7459637" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Orkneys</tei-placeName> as
                     the scene of my labours. It was a place fitted for such a work, being hardly
                     more than a rock, whose high sides were continually beaten upon by the waves.
                     The soil was barren, scarcely affording pasture for a few miserable cows, and
                     oatmeal for its inhabitants, which consisted of five persons, whose gaunt and
                     scraggy limbs gave tokens of their miserable fare. Vegetables and bread, when
                     they indulged in such luxuries, and even fresh water, was to be procured from
                     the main land, which was about five miles distant.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">On the whole island there were but <tei-pb n="[3.36]" facs="pageImages/vol3/36.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> three miserable huts, and one of these was vacant when I arrived. This I
                     hired. It contained but two rooms, and these exhibited all the squalidness of
                     the most miserable penury. The thatch had fallen in, the walls were
                     unplastered, and the door was off its hinges. I ordered it to be repaired,
                     bought some furniture, and took possession; an incident which would, doubtless,
                     have occasioned some surprise, had not all the senses of the cottagers been
                     benumbed by want and squalid poverty. As it was, I lived ungazed at and
                     unmolested, hardly thanked for the pittance of food and clothes which I gave;
                     so much does suffering blunt even the coarsest sensations of men.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In this retreat I devoted the morning to labour; but in the evening, when the
                     weather permitted, I walked on the stony beach of the sea, to listen to the <tei-pb n="[3.37]" facs="pageImages/vol3/37.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> waves as they roared, and dashed
                     at my feet. It was a monotonous, yet ever-changing scene. I thought of
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName>; it was far
                     different from this desolate and appalling landscape. Its hills are covered
                     with vines, and its cottages are scattered thickly in the plains. Its fair
                     lakes reflect a blue and gentle sky; and, when troubled by the winds, their
                     tumult is but as the play of a lively infant, when compared to the roarings of
                     the giant ocean.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In this manner I distributed my occupations when I first arrived; but, as I
                     proceeded in my labour, it became every day more horrible and irksome to me.
                     Sometimes I could not prevail on myself to enter my laboratory for several
                     days; and at other times I toiled day and night in order to complete my work.
                     It was indeed a filthy process in which I was engaged. During <tei-pb n="[3.38]" facs="pageImages/vol3/38.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> my first experiment, a kind of enthusiastic
                     frenzy had blinded me to the horror of my employment; my mind was intently
                     fixed on the sequel of my labour, and my eyes were shut to the horror of my
                     proceedings. But now I went to it in cold blood, and my heart often sickened at
                     the work of my hands.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus situated, employed in the most detestable occupation, immersed in a
                     solitude where nothing could for an instant call my attention from the actual
                     scene in which I was engaged, my spirits became unequal; I grew restless and
                     nervous. Every moment I feared to meet my persecutor. Sometimes I sat with my
                     eyes fixed on the ground, fearing to raise them lest they should encounter the
                     object which I so much dreaded to behold. I feared to wander from the sight of
                     my fellow-creatures, <tei-pb n="[3.39]" facs="pageImages/vol3/39.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> lest when
                     alone he should come to claim his companion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In the mean time I worked on, and my labour was already considerably advanced.
                     I looked towards its completion with a tremulous and eager hope, which I dared
                     not trust myself to question, but which was intermixed with obscure forebodings
                     of evil, that made my heart sicken in my bosom.</tei-p>"</tei-said>


            </tei-div>







            <tei-div n="3.3" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[3.40]" facs="pageImages/vol3/40.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter III</tei-head>


               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">" <tei-p data-origname="p">I SAT one evening in my laboratory; the sun had set, and the
                     moon was just rising from the sea; I had not sufficient light for my
                     employment, and I remained idle, in a pause of consideration of whether I
                     should leave my labour for the night, or hasten its conclusion by an
                     unremitting attention to it. As I sat, a train of reflection occurred to me,
                     which led me to consider the effects of what I was now doing. Three years
                     before I was engaged in the same manner, and had created a fiend whose
                     unparalleled barbarity had desolated my <tei-pb n="[3.41]" facs="pageImages/vol3/41.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> heart, and filled it for ever with the
                     bitterest remorse. I was now about to form another being, of whose dispositions
                     I was alike ignorant; she might become ten thousand times more malignant than
                     her mate, and delight, for its own sake, in murder and wretchedness. He had
                     sworn to quit the neighbourhood of man, and hide himself in deserts; but she
                     had not; and she, who in all probability was to become a thinking and reasoning
                     animal, might refuse to comply with a compact made before her creation. They
                     might even hate each other; the creature who already lived loathed his own
                     deformity, and might he not conceive a greater abhorrence for it when it came
                     before his eyes in the female form? She also might turn with disgust from him
                     to the superior beauty of man; she might quit him, and he be again alone,
                     exasperated by the fresh <tei-pb n="[3.42]" facs="pageImages/vol3/42.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     provocation of being deserted by one of his own species. Even if they were to
                     leave <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000003" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Europe</tei-placeName>, and inhabit the
                     deserts of the new world, yet one of the first results of those sympathies for
                     which the dæmon thirsted would be children, and a race of devils would be
                     propagated upon the earth, who might make the very existence of the species of
                     man a condition precarious and full of terror. Had I right, for my own benefit,
                     to inflict this curse upon everlasting generations? I had before been moved by
                     the sophisms of the being I had created; I had been struck senseless by his
                     fiendish threats: but now, for the first time, the wickedness of my promise
                     burst upon me; I shuddered to think that future ages might curse me as their
                     pest, whose selfishness had not hesitated to buy its own peace at <tei-pb n="[3.43]" facs="pageImages/vol3/43.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the price perhaps of the
                     existence of the whole human race.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I trembled, and my heart failed within me; when, on looking up, I saw, by the
                     light of the moon, the dæmon at the casement. A ghastly grin wrinkled his lips
                     as he gazed on me, where I sat fulfilling the task which he had allotted to me.
                     Yes, he had followed me in my travels; he had loitered in forests, hid himself
                     in caves, or taken refuge in wide and desert heaths; and he now came to mark my
                     progress, and claim the fulfillment of my promise.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As I looked on him, his countenance expressed the utmost extent of malice and
                     treachery. I thought with a sensation of madness on my promise of creating
                     another like him, and, trembling with passion, tore to pieces the thing on
                     which I was engaged. The wretch saw me destroy the creature on <tei-pb n="[3.44]" facs="pageImages/vol3/44.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> whose future existence he depended for
                     happiness, and, with a howl of devilish despair and revenge, withdrew.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I left the room, and, locking the door, made a solemn vow in my own heart never
                     to resume my labours; and then, with trembling steps, I sought my own
                     apartment. I was alone; none were near me to dissipate the gloom, and relieve
                     me from the sickening oppression of the most terrible reveries.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Several hours passed, and I remained near my window gazing on the sea; it was
                     almost motionless, for the winds were hushed, and all nature reposed under the
                     eye of the quiet moon. A few fishing vessels alone specked the water, and now
                     and then the gentle breeze wafted the sound of voices, as the fishermen called
                     to one another. I felt the silence, although I was hardly conscious of its
                     extreme profundity, <tei-pb n="[3.45]" facs="pageImages/vol3/45.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> until my ear
                     was suddenly arrested by the paddling of oars near the shore, and a person
                     landed close to my house.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">In a few minutes after, I heard the creaking of my door, as if some one
                     endeavoured to open it softly. I trembled from head to foot; I felt a
                     presentiment of who it was, and wished to rouse one of the peasants who dwelt
                     in a cottage not far from mine; but I was overcome by the sensation of
                     helplessness, so often felt in frightful dreams, when you in vain endeavour to
                     fly from an impending danger, and was rooted to the spot.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Presently I heard the sound of footsteps along the passage; the door opened,
                     and the wretch whom I dreaded appeared. Shutting the door, he approached me,
                     and said, in a smothered voice—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You have destroyed the work <tei-pb n="[3.46]" facs="pageImages/vol3/46.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> which you began; what is it that you
                        intend? Do you dare to break your promise? I have endured toil and misery: I
                        left <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName> with you; I
                        crept along the shores of the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7012611" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhine</tei-placeName>, among its willow islands, and over the summits of its
                        hills. I have dwelt many months in the heaths of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>, and among the deserts of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002444" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Scotland</tei-placeName>. I have endured
                        incalculable fatigue, and cold, and hunger; do you dare destroy my
                        hopes?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Begone! I do break my promise; never will I create another
                        like yourself, equal in deformity and wickedness."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Slave, I before reasoned with you, but you have proved
                        yourself unworthy of my condescension. Remember that I have power; you
                        believe yourself miserable, but I can make you so wretched that the light of
                        day will be <tei-pb n="[3.47]" facs="pageImages/vol3/47.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> hateful to you.
                        You are my creator, but I am your master;—obey!"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"The hour of my weakness is past, and the period of your
                        power is arrived. Your threats cannot move me to do an act of wickedness;
                        but they confirm me in a resolution of not creating you a companion in vice.
                        Shall I, in cool blood, set loose upon the earth a dæmon, whose delight is
                        in death and wretchedness. Begone! I am firm, and your words will only
                        exasperate my rage."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The monster saw my determination in my face, and gnashed his teeth in the
                     impotence of anger. <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Shall each man,"</tei-said> cried he,
                        <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"find a wife for his bosom, and each beast have his
                        mate, and I be alone? I had feelings of affection, and they were requited by
                        detestation and scorn. Man, you may hate; but beware! Your hours will pass
                        in dread and <tei-pb n="[3.48]" facs="pageImages/vol3/48.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> misery, and soon
                        the bolt will fall which must ravish from you your happiness for ever. Are
                        you to be happy, while I grovel in the intensity of my wretchedness? You can
                        blast my other passions; but revenge remains—revenge, henceforth dearer than
                        light or food! I may die; but first you, my tyrant and tormentor, shall
                        curse the sun that gazes on your misery. Beware; for I am fearless, and
                        therefore powerful. I will watch with the wiliness of a snake, that I may
                        sting with its venom. Man, you shall repent of the injuries you
                        inflict."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Devil, cease; and do not poison the air with these sounds
                        of malice. I have declared my resolution to you, and I am no coward to bend
                        beneath words. Leave me; I am inexorable."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"It is well. I go; but remember, I shall be with you on
                        your wedding-night."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[3.49]" facs="pageImages/vol3/49.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I started forward, and exclaimed, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Villain! before you sign
                        my death-warrant, be sure that you are yourself safe."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I would have seized him; but he eluded me, and quitted the house with
                     precipitation: in a few moments I saw him in his boat, which shot across the
                     waters with an arrowy swiftness and was soon lost amidst the waves.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">All was again silent; but his words rung in my ears. I burned with rage to
                     pursue the murderer of my peace, and precipitate him into the ocean. I walked
                     up and down my room hastily and perturbed, while my imagination conjured up a
                     thousand images to torment and sting me. Why had I not followed him, and closed
                     with him in mortal strife? But I had suffered him to depart, and he had
                     directed his course towards the main land. I <tei-pb n="[3.50 - page breaks after 'shud-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/50.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     shuddered to think who might be the next victim sacrificed to his insatiate
                     revenge. And then I thought again of his words—<tei-said who="#creatureVictor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I
                        will be with you on your wedding-night."</tei-said> That then was the period
                     fixed for the fulfillment of my destiny. In that hour I should die, and at once
                     satisfy and extinguish his malice. The prospect did not move me to fear; yet
                     when I thought of my beloved <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>,—of her tears and
                     endless sorrow, when she should find her lover so barbarously snatched from
                     her,—tears, the first I had shed for many months, streamed from my eyes, and I
                     resolved not to fall before my enemy without a bitter struggle.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The night passed away, and the sun rose from the ocean; my feelings became
                     calmer, if it may be called calmness, when the violence of rage sinks into the
                     depths of despair. I left the <tei-pb n="[3.51]" facs="pageImages/vol3/51.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     house, the horrid scene of the last night's contention, and walked on the beach
                     of the sea, which I almost regarded as an insuperable barrier between me and my
                     fellow-creatures; nay, a wish that such should prove the fact stole across me.
                     I desired that I might pass my life on that barren rock, wearily it is true,
                     but uninterrupted by any sudden shock of misery. If I returned, it was to be
                     sacrificed, or to see those whom I most loved die under the grasp of a dæmon
                     whom I had myself created.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I walked about the isle like a restless spectre, separated from all it loved,
                     and miserable in the separation. When it became noon, and the sun rose higher,
                     I lay down on the grass, and was overpowered by a deep sleep. I had been awake
                     the whole of the preceding night, my nerves were agitated, <tei-pb n="[3.52]" facs="pageImages/vol3/52.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and my eyes inflamed by watching and misery.
                     The sleep into which I now sunk refreshed me; and when I awoke, I again felt as
                     if I belonged to a race of human beings like myself, and I began to reflect
                     upon what had passed with greater composure; yet still the words of the fiend
                     rung in my ears like a death-knell, they appeared like a dream, yet distinct
                     and oppressive as a reality.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The sun had far descended, and I still sat on the shore, satisfying my
                     appetite, which had become ravenous, with an oaten cake, when I saw a
                     fishing-boat land close to me, and one of the men brought me a packet; it
                     contained letters from <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName> ,
                     and one from <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, entreating me to join him. He said
                     that nearly a year had elapsed since we had quitted <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName>, and <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000070" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">France</tei-placeName> was yet unvisited. He <tei-pb n="[3.53 - page breaks after 'en-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/53.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     entreated me, therefore, to leave my solitary isle, and meet him at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009702" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Perth</tei-placeName>, in a week from that time, when
                     we might arrange the plan of our future proceedings. This letter in a degree
                     recalled me to life, and I determined to quit my island at the expiration of
                     two days.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Yet, before I departed, there was a task to perform, on which I shuddered to
                     reflect: I must pack my chemical instruments; and for that purpose I must enter
                     the room which had been the scene of my odious work, and I must handle those
                     utensils, the sight of which was sickening to me. The next morning, at
                     day-break, I summoned sufficient courage, and unlocked the door of my
                     laboratory. The remains of the half-finished creature, whom I had destroyed,
                     lay scattered on the floor, and I almost felt as if I had <tei-pb n="[3.54 - page breaks after 'man-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/54.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     mangled the living flesh of a human being. I paused to collect myself, and then
                     entered the chamber. With trembling hand I conveyed the instruments out of the
                     room; but I reflected that I ought not to leave the relics of my work to excite
                     the horror and suspicion of the peasants, and I accordingly put them into a
                     basket, with a great quantity of stones, and laying them up, determined to
                     throw them into the sea that very night; and in the mean time I sat upon the
                     beach, employed in cleaning and arranging my chemical apparatus.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Nothing could be more complete than the alteration that had taken place in my
                     feelings since the night of the appearance of the dæmon. I had before regarded
                     my promise with a gloomy despair, as a thing that, with whatever consequences,
                     must be fulfilled; but I now felt as if a film had <tei-pb n="[3.55]" facs="pageImages/vol3/55.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> been taken from before my eyes, and that I,
                     for the first time, saw clearly. The idea of renewing my labours did not for
                     one instant occur to me; the threat I had heard weighed on my thoughts, but I
                     did not reflect that a voluntary act of mine could avert it. I had resolved in
                     my own mind, that to create another like the fiend I had first made would be an
                     act of the basest and most atrocious selfishness; and I banished from my mind
                     every thought that could lead to a different conclusion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Between two and three in the morning the moon rose; and I then, putting my
                     basket aboard a little skiff, sailed out about four miles from the shore. The
                     scene was perfectly solitary: a few boats were returning towards land, but I
                     sailed away from them. I felt as if I was about the commission of a dreadful
                     crime, and avoided with shuddering <tei-pb n="[3.56]" facs="pageImages/vol3/56.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> anxiety any encounter with my fellow-creatures. At one time the moon, which
                     had before been clear, was suddenly overspread by a thick cloud, and I took
                     advantage of the moment of darkness, and cast my basket into the sea; I
                     listened to the gurgling sound as it sunk, and then sailed away from the spot.
                     The sky became clouded; but the air was pure, although chilled by the
                     north-east breeze that was then rising. But it refreshed me, and filled me with
                     such agreeable sensations, that I resolved to prolong my stay on the water, and
                     fixing the rudder in a direct position, stretched myself at the bottom of the
                     boat. Clouds hid the moon, every thing was obscure, and I heard only the sound
                     of the boat, as its keel cut through the waves; the murmur lulled me, and in a
                     short time I slept soundly.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[3.57]" facs="pageImages/vol3/57.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I do not know how long I remained in this situation, but when I awoke I found
                     that the sun had already mounted considerably. The wind was high, and the waves
                     continually threatened the safety of my little skiff. I found that the wind was
                     north-east, and must have driven me far from the coast from which I had
                     embarked. I endeavoured to change my course, but quickly found that if I again
