                     made the attempt the boat would be instantly filled with water. Thus situated,
                     my only resource was to drive before the wind. I confess that I felt a few
                     sensations of terror. I had no compass with me, and was so little acquainted
                     with the geography of this part of the world that the sun was of little benefit
                     to me. I might be driven into the wide <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7014206" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Atlantic</tei-placeName>, and feel all the tortures of starvation, or be
                     swallowed up in the immeasurable <tei-pb n="[3.58]" facs="pageImages/vol3/58.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     waters that roared and buffeted around me. I had already been out many hours,
                     and felt the torment of a burning thirst, a prelude to my other sufferings. I
                     looked on the heavens, which were covered by clouds that flew before the wind
                     only to be replaced by others: I looked upon the sea, it was to be my grave.
                        <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Fiend,"</tei-said> I exclaimed, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"your
                        task is already fulfilled!"</tei-said> I thought of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, of my father, and of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>; and sunk into a reverie, so despairing and
                     frightful, that even now, when the scene is on the point of closing before me
                     for ever, I shudder to reflect on it.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Some hours passed thus; but by degrees, as the sun declined towards the
                     horizon, the wind died away into a gentle breeze, and the sea became free from
                     breakers. But these gave place to a heavy swell; I felt sick, and hardly able
                     to hold the rudder, when suddenly <tei-pb n="[3.59]" facs="pageImages/vol3/59.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I saw a line of high land towards the south.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Almost spent, as I was, by fatigue, and the dreadful suspense I endured for
                     several hours, this sudden certainty of life rushed like a flood of warm joy to
                     my heart, and tears gushed from my eyes.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">How mutable are our feelings, and how strange is that clinging love we have of
                     life even in the excess of misery! I constructed another sail with a part of my
                     dress, and eagerly steered my course towards the land. It had a wild and rocky
                     appearance; but, as I approached nearer, I easily perceived the traces of
                     cultivation. I saw vessels near the shore, and found myself suddenly
                     transported back to the neighbourhood of civilized man. I eagerly traced the
                     windings of the land, and hailed a steeple which I at length saw <tei-pb n="[3.60]" facs="pageImages/vol3/60.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> issuing from behind a small promontory. As I
                     was in a state of extreme debility, I resolved to sail directly towards the
                     town as a place where I could most easily procure nourishment. Fortunately I
                     had money with me. As I turned the promontory, I perceived a small neat town
                     and a good harbour, which I entered, my heart bounding with joy at my
                     unexpected escape.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As I was occupied in fixing the boat and arranging the sails, several people
                     crowded towards the spot. They seemed very much surprised at my appearance;
                     but, instead of offering me any assistance, whispered together with gestures
                     that at any other time might have produced in me a slight sensation of alarm.
                     As it was, I merely remarked that they spoke English; and I therefore addressed
                     them in that language: <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My good friends,"</tei-said> said I,
                        <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"will you be so <tei-pb n="[3.61]" facs="pageImages/vol3/61.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> kind as to tell me the name of this town,
                        and inform me where I am?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You will know that soon enough,"</tei-said> replied a man
                     with a gruff voice. <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"May be you are come to a place that
                        will not prove much to your taste; but you will not be consulted as to your
                        quarters, I promise you."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I was exceedingly surprised on receiving so rude an answer from a stranger; and
                     I was also disconcerted on perceiving the frowning and angry countenances of
                     his companions. <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Why do you answer me so roughly?"</tei-said> I
                     replied: <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"surely it is not the custom of Englishmen to
                        receive strangers so inhospitably."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I do not know,"</tei-said> said the man, <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"what the custom of the <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">English</tei-foreign> may be; but it is the
                        custom of the Irish to hate villains."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">While this strange dialogue <tei-pb n="[3.62 - page breaks after 'conti-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/62.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> continued, I perceived the crowd rapidly
                     increase. Their faces expressed a mixture of curiosity and anger, which
                     annoyed, and in some degree alarmed me. I inquired the way to the inn; but no
                     one replied. I then moved forward, and a murmuring sound arose from the crowd
                     as they followed and surrounded me; when an ill-looking man approaching, tapped
                     me on the shoulder, and said, <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Come, Sir, you must follow
                        me to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.Kirwin’s</tei-persName>."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Who is <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName>? Why am I to give
                        an account of myself? Is not this a free country?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Ay, Sir, free enough for honest folks. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                           Kirwin</tei-persName> is a magistrate; and you are to give an account of the
                        death of a gentleman who was found murdered here last night."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This answer startled me; but I <tei-pb n="[3.63 - page breaks after 'pre-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/63.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> presently recovered myself. I was innocent;
                     that could easily be proved: accordingly I followed my conductor in silence,
                     and was led to one of the best houses in the town. I was ready to sink from
                     fatigue and hunger; but, being surrounded by a crowd, I thought it politic to
                     rouse all my strength, that no physical debility might be construed into
                     apprehension or conscious guilt. Little did I then expect the calamity that was
                     in a few moments to overwhelm me, and extinguish in horror and despair all fear
                     of ignominy or death.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I must pause here; for it requires all my fortitude to
                        recall the memory of the frightful events which I am about to relate, in
                        proper detail, to my recollection."</tei-said></tei-p></tei-said>


            </tei-div>






















            <tei-div n="3.4" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">




               <tei-pb n="[3.64]" facs="pageImages/vol3/64.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter IV</tei-head>







               <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"<tei-p data-origname="p">I WAS soon introduced into the presence of the magistrate, an
                     old benevolent man, with calm and mild manners. He looked upon me, however,
                     with some degree of severity; and then, turning towards my conductors, he asked
                     who appeared as witnesses on this occasion.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">About half a dozen men came forward; and one being selected by the magistrate,
                     he deposed, that he had been out fishing the night before with his son and
                     brother-in-law, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Daniel Nugent </tei-persName>, when, about ten o'clock,
                     they <tei-pb n="[3.65 - page breaks after 'ob-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/65.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     observed a strong northerly blast rising, and they accordingly put in for port.
                     It was a very dark night, as the moon had not yet risen; they did not land at
                     the harbour, but, as they had been accustomed, at a creek about two miles
                     below. He walked on first, carrying a part of the fishing tackle, and his
                     companions followed him at some distance. As he was proceeding along the sands,
                     he struck his foot against something, and fell at his length on the ground. His
                     companions came up to assist him; and, by the light of their lantern, they
                     found that he had fallen on the body of a man, who was to all appearance dead.
                     Their first supposition was, that it was the corpse of some person who had been
                     drowned, and was thrown on shore by the waves; but, upon examination, they
                     found that the clothes were not wet, and even that <tei-pb n="[3.66]" facs="pageImages/vol3/66.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the body was not then cold. They instantly
                     carried it to the cottage of an old woman near the spot, and endeavoured, but
                     in vain, to restore it to life. He appeared to be a handsome young man, about
                     five and twenty years of age. He had apparently been strangled; for there was
                     no sign of any violence, except the black mark of fingers on his neck.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The first part of this deposition did not in the least interest me; but when
                     the mark of the fingers was mentioned, I remembered the murder of my brother,
                     and felt myself extremely agitated; my limbs trembled, and a mist came over my
                     eyes, which obliged me to lean on a chair for support. The magistrate observed
                     me with a keen eye, and of course drew an unfavourable augury from my
                     manner.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The son confirmed his father's <tei-pb n="[3.67 - page breaks after 'ac-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/67.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> account: but when <tei-persName data-origname="persName"> Daniel
                        Nugent</tei-persName> was called, he swore positively that, just before the fall
                     of his companion, he saw a boat, with a single man in it, at a short distance
                     from the shore; and, as far as he could judge by the light of a few stars, it
                     was the same boat in which I had just landed.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">A woman deposed, that she lived near the beach, and was standing at the door of
                     her cottage, waiting for the return of the fishermen, about an hour before she
                     heard of the discovery of the body, when she saw a boat, with only one man in
                     it, push off from that part of the shore where the corpse was afterwards
                     found.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Another woman confirmed the account of the fishermen having brought the body
                     into her house; it was not cold. They put it into a bed, and rubbed it; and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Daniel</tei-persName> went to the <tei-pb n="[3.68]" facs="pageImages/vol3/68.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> town for an apothecary, but life was quite
                     gone.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Several other men were examined concerning my landing; and they agreed, that,
                     with the strong north wind that had arisen during the night, it was very
                     probable that I had beaten about for many hours, and had been obliged to return
                     nearly to the same spot from which I had departed. Besides, they observed that
                     it appeared that I had brought the body from another place, and it was likely,
                     that as I did not appear to know the shore, I might have put into the harbour
                     ignorant of the distance of the town of ---- from the place where I had
                     deposited the corpse.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName>, on hearing this evidence, desired that I
                     should be taken into the room where the body lay for interment, that it might
                     be observed <tei-pb n="[3.69]" facs="pageImages/vol3/69.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> what effect the
                     sight of it would produce upon me. This idea was probably suggested by the
                     extreme agitation I had exhibited when the mode of the murder had been
                     described. I was accordingly conducted, by the magistrate and several other
                     persons, to the inn. I could not help being struck by the strange coincidences
                     that had taken place during this eventful night; but, knowing that I had been
                     conversing with several persons in the island I had inhabited about the time
                     that the body had been found, I was perfectly tranquil as to the consequences
                     of the affair.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I entered the room where the corpse lay, and was led up to the coffin. How can
                     I describe my sensations on beholding it? I feel yet parched with horror, nor
                     can I reflect on that terrible moment without shuddering and agony, <tei-pb n="[3.70]" facs="pageImages/vol3/70.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> that faintly reminds me of the
                     anguish of recognition. The trial, the presence of the magistrate and
                     witnesses, passed like a dream from my memory, when I saw the lifeless form of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry Clerval</tei-persName> stretched before me. I gasped for breath;
                     and, throwing myself on the body, I exclaimed, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Have my
                        murderous machinations deprived you also, my dearest
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>, of life? Two I have already destroyed; other
                        victims await their destiny: but you, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, my
                        friend, my benefactor—"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The human frame could no longer support the agonizing suffering that I endured,
                     and I was carried out of the room in strong convulsions.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">A fever succeeded to this. I lay for two months on the point of death: my
                     ravings, as I afterwards heard, were frightful; I called myself the murderer
                        <tei-pb n="[3.71]" facs="pageImages/vol3/71.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>, of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, and of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>. Sometimes I entreated my attendants to assist
                     me in the destruction of the fiend by whom I was tormented; and, at others, I
                     felt the fingers of the monster already grasping my neck, and screamed aloud
                     with agony and terror. Fortunately, as I spoke my native language,
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName> alone understood me; but my gestures and
                     bitter cries were sufficient to affright the other witnesses.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Why did I not die? More miserable than man ever was before, why did I not sink
                     into forgetfulness and rest? Death snatches away many blooming children, the
                     only hopes of their doating parents: how many brides and youthful lovers have
                     been one day in the bloom of health and hope, and the next a prey for worms and
                     the decay of the tomb! Of what materials was <tei-pb n="[3.72]" facs="pageImages/vol3/72.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I made, that I could thus resist so many
                     shocks, which, like the turning of the wheel, continually renewed the
                     torture.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">But I was doomed to live; and, in two months, found myself as awaking from a
                     dream, in a prison, stretched on a wretched bed, surrounded by gaolers,
                     turnkeys, bolts, and all the miserable apparatus of a dungeon. It was morning,
                     I remember, when I thus awoke to understanding: I had forgotten the particulars
                     of what had happened, and only felt as if some great misfortune had suddenly
                     overwhelmed me; but when I looked around, and saw the barred windows, and the
                     squalidness of the room in which I was, all flashed across my memory, and I
                     groaned bitterly.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">This sound disturbed an old woman who was sleeping in a chair beside me. <tei-pb n="[3.73]" facs="pageImages/vol3/73.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> She was a hired nurse, the wife
                     of one of the turnkeys, and her countenance expressed all those bad qualities
                     which often characterise that class. The lines of her face were hard and rude,
                     like that of persons accustomed to see without sympathizing in sights of
                     misery. Her tone expressed her entire indifference; she addressed me in
                        <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">English</tei-foreign>, and the voice struck me as one that I had heard
                     during my sufferings:</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#oldwoman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Are you better now, Sir?"</tei-said> said she.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I replied in the same language, with a feeble voice, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I
                        believe I am; but if it be all true, if indeed I did not dream, I am sorry
                        that I am still alive to feel this misery and horror."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#oldwoman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"For that matter,"</tei-said> replied the old woman, <tei-said who="#oldwoman" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"if you mean about the gentleman you murdered, I believe
                        that it were better for you if you were dead, <tei-pb n="[3.74]" facs="pageImages/vol3/74.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> for I fancy it will go hard with you; but
                        you will be hung when the next sessions come on. However, that's none of my
                        business, I am sent to nurse you, and get you well; I do my duty with a safe
                        conscience, it were well if every body did the same."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I turned with loathing from the woman who could utter so unfeeling a speech to
                     a person just saved, on the very edge of death; but I felt languid, and unable
                     to reflect on all that had passed. The whole series of my life appeared to me
                     as a dream; I sometimes doubted if indeed it were all true, for it never
                     presented itself to my mind with the force of reality.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As the images that floated before me became more distinct, I grew feverish; a
                     darkness pressed around me: no one was near me who soothed me with the gentle
                     voice of love; no dear hand supported me.<tei-pb n="[3.75]" facs="pageImages/vol3/75.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> The physician came and prescribed medicines,
                     and the old woman prepared them for me; but utter carelessness was visible in
                     the first, and the expression of brutality was strongly marked in the visage of
                     the second. Who could be interested in the fate of a murderer, but the hangman
                     who would gain his fee?</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">These were my first reflections; but I soon learned that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Kirwin</tei-persName> had shewn me extreme kindness. He had caused the best room
                     in the prison to be prepared for me (wretched indeed was the best); and it was
                     he who had provided a physician and a nurse. It is true, he seldom came to see
                     me; for, although he ardently desired to relieve the sufferings of every human
                     creature, he did not wish to be present at the agonies and miserable ravings of
                     a murderer. He came, therefore, <tei-pb n="[3.76 - page breaks after 'some-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/76.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> sometimes to see that I was not neglected;
                     but his visits were short, and at long intervals.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">One day, when I was gradually recovering, I was seated in a chair, my eyes half
                     open, and my cheeks livid like those in death, I was overcome by gloom and
                     misery, and often reflected I had better seek death than remain miserably pent
                     up only to be let loose in a world replete with wretchedness. At one time I
                     considered whether I should not declare myself guilty, and suffer the penalty
                     of the law, less innocent than poor Justine had been. Such were my thoughts,
                     when the door of my apartment was opened, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName>
                     entered. His countenance expressed sympathy and compassion; he drew a chair
                     close to mine, and addressed me in <tei-foreign data-origname="foreign">French</tei-foreign>—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I fear that this place is very <tei-pb n="[3.77 - page breaks after 'shock-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/77.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        shocking to you; can I do any thing to make you more
                     comfortable?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I thank you; but all that you mention is nothing to me: on
                        the whole earth there is no comfort which I am capable of
                     receiving."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I know that the sympathy of a stranger can be but of
                        little relief to one borne down as you are by so strange a misfortune. But
                        you will, I hope, soon quit this melancholy abode; for, doubtless, evidence
                        can easily be brought to free you from the criminal charge."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"That is my least concern: I am, by a course of strange
                        events, become the most miserable of mortals. Persecuted and tortured as I
                        am and have been, can death be any evil to me?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Nothing indeed could be more unfortunate and agonizing
                        than the strange chances that have lately <tei-pb n="[3.78 - page breaks after 'occur-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/78.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        occurred. You were thrown, by some surprising accident, on this shore,
                        renowned for its hospitality: seized immediately, and charged with murder.
                        The first sight that was presented to your eyes was the body of your friend,
                        murdered in so unaccountable a manner, and placed, as it were, by some fiend
                        across your path."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName> said this, notwithstanding the agitation I
                     endured on this retrospect of my sufferings, I also felt considerable surprise
                     at the knowledge he seemed to possess concerning me. I suppose some
                     astonishment was exhibited in my countenance; for <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Kirwin</tei-persName> hastened to say—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"It was not until a day or two after your illness that I
                        thought of examining your dress, that I might discover some trace by which I
                        could send to your relations an account of your misfortune <tei-pb n="[3.79]" facs="pageImages/vol3/79.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and illness. I found several letters,
                        and, among others, one which I discovered from its commencement to be from
                        your father. I instantly wrote to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>: nearly two months have elapsed since the departure
                        of my letter.—But you are ill; even now you tremble: you are unfit for
                        agitation of any kind."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"This suspense is a thousand times worse than the most
                        horrible event: tell me what new scene of death has been acted, and whose
                        murder I am now to lament."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Your family is perfectly well,"</tei-said> said <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr.
                        Kirwin</tei-persName>, with gentleness; <tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"and some one, a
                        friend, is come to visit you."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I know not by what chain of thought the idea presented itself, but it instantly
                     darted into my mind that the murderer had come to mock at my misery, and taunt
                     me with the death of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, as <tei-pb n="[3.80]" facs="pageImages/vol3/80.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> a new incitement for me to comply with his
                     hellish desires. I put my hand before my eyes, and cried out in agony—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Oh! take him away! I cannot see him; for God's sake, do
                        not let him enter!"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName> regarded me with a troubled countenance. He
                     could not help regarding my exclamation as a presumption of my guilt, and said,
                     in rather a severe tone—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#kirwin" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I should have thought, young man, that the presence of
                        your father would have been welcome, instead of inspiring such violent
                        repugnance."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My father!"</tei-said> cried I, while every feature and every
                     muscle was relaxed from anguish to pleasure. <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Is my father,
                        indeed, come? How kind, how very kind. But where is he, why does he not
                        hasten to me?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My change of manner surprised and <tei-pb n="[3.81]" facs="pageImages/vol3/81.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> pleased the magistrate; perhaps he thought that my former exclamation was a
                     momentary return of delirium, and now he instantly resumed his former
                     benevolence. He rose, and quitted the room with my nurse, and in a moment my
                     father entered it.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Nothing, at this moment, could have given me greater pleasure than the arrival
                     of my father. I stretched out my hand to him, and cried—</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Are you then safe—and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> —and
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>?"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father calmed me with assurances of their welfare, and endeavoured, by
                     dwelling on these subjects so interesting to my heart, to raise my desponding
                     spirits; but he soon felt that a prison cannot be the abode of cheerfulness.
                        <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"What a place is this that you inhabit, my son!"</tei-said>
                     said he, looking mournfully at the barred windows, and wretched <tei-pb n="[3.82]" facs="pageImages/vol3/82.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> appearance of the room. <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You travelled to seek happiness, but a fatality seems to pursue you. And
                        poor <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>—"</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The name of my unfortunate and murdered friend was an agitation too great to be
                     endured in my weak state; I shed tears.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Alas! yes, my father,"</tei-said> replied I; <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"some destiny of the most horrible kind hangs over me, and I
                        must live to fulfill it, or surely I should have died on the coffin of
                        Henry."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">We were not allowed to converse for any length of time, for the precarious
                     state of my health rendered every precaution necessary that could insure
                     tranquillity. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName> came in, and insisted that my
                     strength should not be exhausted by too much exertion. But the appearance of my
                     father was to me like that of my good angel, and I gradually recovered my
                     health.</tei-p>
                  <tei-pb n="[3.83]" facs="pageImages/vol3/83.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">As my sickness quitted me, I was absorbed by a gloomy and black melancholy,
                     that nothing could dissipate. The image of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> was for
                     ever before me, ghastly and murdered. More than once the agitation into which
                     these reflections threw me made my friends dread a dangerous relapse. Alas! why
                     did they preserve so miserable and detested a life? It was surely that I might
                     fulfill my destiny, which is now drawing to a close. Soon, oh, very soon, will
                     death extinguish these throbbings, and relieve me from the mighty weight of
                     anguish that bears me to the dust; and, in executing the award of justice, I
                     shall also sink to rest. Then the appearance of death was distant, although the
                     wish was ever present to my thoughts; and I often sat for hours motionless and
                     speechless, wishing for some mighty revolution that might <tei-pb n="[3.84]" facs="pageImages/vol3/84.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> bury me and my destroyer in its ruins.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">The season of the assizes approached. I had already been three months in
                     prison; and although I was still weak, and in continual danger of a relapse, I
                     was obliged to travel nearly a hundred miles to the county-town, where the
                     court was held. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName> charged himself with every care
                     of collecting witnesses, and arranging my defence. I was spared the disgrace of
                     appearing publicly as a criminal, as the case was not brought before the court
                     that decides on life and death. The grand jury rejected the bill, on its being
                     proved that I was on the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7459637" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Orkney
                        Islands</tei-placeName> at the hour the body of my friend was found, and a
                     fortnight after my removal I was liberated from prison.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father was enraptured on finding me freed from the vexations of a <tei-pb n="[3.85 - page breaks after 'cri-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/85.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     criminal charge, that I was again allowed to breathe the fresh atmosphere, and
                     allowed to return to my native country. I did not participate in these
                     feelings; for to me the walls of a dungeon or a palace were alike hateful. The
                     cup of life was poisoned for ever; and although the sun shone upon me, as upon
                     the happy and gay of heart, I saw around me nothing but a dense and frightful
                     darkness, penetrated by no light but the glimmer of two eyes that glared upon
                     me. Sometimes they were the expressive eyes of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>,
                     languishing in death, the dark orbs nearly covered by the lids, and the long
                     black lashes that fringed them; sometimes it was the watery clouded eyes of the
                     monster, as I first saw them in my chamber at Ingolstadt.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father tried to awaken in me the feelings of affection. He talked of <tei-pb n="[3.86]" facs="pageImages/vol3/86.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, which I should soon
                     visit—of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, and <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>; but
                     these words only drew deep groans from me. Sometimes, indeed, I felt a wish for
                     happiness; and thought, with melancholy delight, of my beloved cousin; or
                     longed, with a devouring maladie du pays, to see once more the blue lake and
                     rapid <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7023890" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Rhone</tei-placeName>, that had been so
                     dear to me in early childhood: but my general state of feeling was a torpor, in
                     which a prison was as welcome a residence as the divinest scene in nature; and
                     these fits were seldom interrupted, but by paroxysms of anguish and despair. At
                     these moments I often endeavoured to put an end to the existence I loathed; and
                     it required unceasing attendance and vigilance to restrain me from committing
                     some dreadful act of violence.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I remember, as I quitted the prison, <tei-pb n="[3.87]" facs="pageImages/vol3/87.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I heard one of the men say, <tei-said who="#unknown" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"He may be innocent of the murder, but he has certainly a bad
                        conscience."</tei-said> These words struck me. A bad conscience! yes, surely I
                     had one. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, and
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, had died through my infernal machinations;
                        <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"And whose death,"</tei-said> cried I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"is to finish the tragedy? Ah! my father, do not remain in this wretched
                        country; take me where I may forget myself, my existence, and all the
                        world."</tei-said></tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">My father easily acceded to my desire; and, after having taken leave of
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Mr. Kirwin</tei-persName>, we hastened to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7001306" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Dublin</tei-placeName>. I felt as if I was relieved from a heavy
                     weight, when the packet sailed with a fair wind from Ireland, and I had quitted
                     for ever the country which had been to me the scene of so much misery.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">It was midnight. My father slept in <tei-pb n="[3.88]" facs="pageImages/vol3/88.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the cabin; and I lay on the deck, looking at
                     the stars, and listening to the dashing of the waves. I hailed the darkness
                     that shut Ireland from my sight, and my pulse beat with a feverish joy, when I
                     reflected that I should soon see <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. The past appeared to me in the light of a frightful
                     dream; yet the vessel in which I was, the wind that blew me from the detested
                     shore of Ireland, and the sea which surrounded me, told me too forcibly that I
                     was deceived by no vision, and that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, my friend and
                     dearest companion, had fallen a victim to me and the monster of my creation. I
                     repassed, in my memory, my whole life; my quiet happiness while residing with
                     my family in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, the death
                     of my mother, and my departure for Ingolstadt. I remembered shuddering at the
                     mad enthusiasm that hurried me on to the <tei-pb n="[3.89 - page breaks after 'crea-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/89.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     creation of my hideous enemy, and I called to mind the night during which he
                     first lived. I was unable to pursue the train of thought; a thousand feelings
                     pressed upon me, and I wept bitterly.</tei-p>
                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Ever since my recovery from the fever I had been in the custom of taking every
                     night a small quantity of laudanum; for it was by means of this drug only that
                     I was enabled to gain the rest necessary for the preservation of life.
                     Oppressed by the recollection of my various misfortunes, I now took a double
                     dose, and soon slept profoundly. But sleep did not afford me respite from
                     thought and misery; my dreams presented a thousand objects that scared me.
                     Towards morning I was possessed by a kind of night-mare; I felt the fiend's
                     grasp in my neck, and could not free myself from it; groans and cries rung in
                     my ears. My father, who was <tei-pb n="[3.90]" facs="pageImages/vol3/90.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                     watching over me, perceiving my restlessness, awoke me, and pointed to the port
                     of Holyhead, which we were now entering.to give an account of
                  yourself.</tei-p></tei-said>

















            </tei-div>









            <tei-div n="3.5" type="chapter" data-origname="div" data-origatts="type n">


               <tei-pb n="[3.91]" facs="pageImages/vol3/91.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-head data-origname="head">Chapter V</tei-head>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"WE had resolved not to go to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011781" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">London</tei-placeName>, but to cross the country to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011393" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Portsmouth</tei-placeName>, and thence to embark for
                        <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008927" cert="medium" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="cert key type">Havre</tei-placeName>. I
                     preferred this plan principally because I dreaded to see again those places in
                     which I had enjoyed a few moments of tranquillity with my beloved
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>. I thought with horror of seeing again those
                     persons whom we had been accustomed to visit together, and who might make
                     inquiries concerning an event, the very remembrance of which made me again feel
                     the pang I endured <tei-pb n="[3.92]" facs="pageImages/vol3/92.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> when I gazed
                     on his lifeless form in the inn at ----.</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">As for my father, his desires and exertions were bounded to the again seeing me
                  restored to health and peace of mind. His tenderness and attentions were
                  unremitting; my grief and gloom was obstinate, but he would not despair. Sometimes
                  he thought that I felt deeply the degradation of being obliged to answer a charge
                  of murder, and he endeavoured to prove to me the futility of pride.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Alas! my father,"</tei-said> said I, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"how
                     little do you know me. Human beings, their feelings and passions, would indeed
                     be degraded if such a wretch as I felt pride. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>,
                     poor unhappy <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, was as innocent as I, and she
                     suffered the same charge; she died for it; and I am the cause of this—I
                     murdered her. <tei-persName data-origname="persName">William</tei-persName>, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Justine</tei-persName>, <tei-pb n="[3.93]" facs="pageImages/vol3/93.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Henry</tei-persName>—they all died by my hands."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">My father had often, during my imprisonment, heard me make the same assertion;
                  when I thus accused myself, he sometimes seemed to desire an explanation, and at
                  others he appeared to consider it as caused by delirium, and that, during my
                  illness, some idea of this kind had presented itself to my imagination, the
                  remembrance of which I preserved in my convalescence. I avoided explanation, and
                  maintained a continual silence concerning the wretch I had created. I had a
                  feeling that I should be supposed mad, and this for ever chained my tongue, when I
                  would have given the world to have confided the fatal secret. Yet still words like
                  those I have recorded would burst uncontrollably from me. I could offer no
                  explanation of them; but their truth in part relieved the burden of my mysterious
                  woe.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Upon this occasion my father said, with an expression of unbounded wonder, <tei-said who="#father" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"What do you mean, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>? <tei-pb n="[3.94]" facs="pageImages/vol3/94.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> are you mad? My dear son, I entreat you
                     never to make such an assertion again."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I am not mad,"</tei-said> I cried energetically; <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"the sun and the heavens, who have viewed my operations, can bear
                     witness of my truth. I am the assassin of those most innocent victims; they
                     died by my machinations. A thousand times would I have shed my own blood, drop
                     by drop, to have saved their lives; but I could not, my father, indeed I could
                     not sacrifice the whole human race."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">The conclusion of this speech convinced my father that my ideas were deranged, and
                  he instantly changed the subject of our conversation and endeavoured to alter the
                  course of my thoughts. He wished as much as possible to obliterate the memory of
                  the scenes that had taken place in <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1000078" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ireland</tei-placeName>, <tei-pb n="[3.95]" facs="pageImages/vol3/95.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and never
                  alluded to them, or suffered me to speak of my misfortunes.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">As time passed away I became more calm: misery had her dwelling in my heart, but I
                  no longer talked in the same incoherent manner of my own crimes; sufficient for me
                  was the consciousness of them. By the utmost self-violence, I curbed the imperious
                  voice of wretchedness, which sometimes desired to declare itself to the whole
                  world; and my manners were calmer and more composed than they had ever been since
                  my journey to the sea of ice.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">We arrived at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008927" cert="medium" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="cert key type">Havre</tei-placeName>
                  on the <tei-date data-origname="date">8th of May</tei-date>, and instantly proceeded to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>, where my father had some business which
                  detained us a few weeks. In this city, I received the following letter from
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>:—</tei-p>


               <tei-pb n="[3.96]" facs="pageImages/vol3/96.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <!-- question -->


               <tei-floatingText data-origname="floatingText">


                  <tei-body data-origname="body">





                     <tei-opener data-origname="opener">To <tei-persName data-origname="persName">VICTOR FRANKENSTEIN.</tei-persName>
                        <tei-salute data-origname="salute">"MY DEAREST FRIEND,"</tei-salute></tei-opener>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">It gave me the greatest pleasure to receive a letter from my uncle dated at
                           <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7008038" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Paris</tei-placeName>; you are no longer
                        at a formidable distance, and I may hope to see you in less than a
                        fortnight. My poor cousin, how much you must have suffered! I expect to see
                        you looking even more ill than when you quitted <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. This winter has been passed most
                        miserably, tortured as I have been by anxious suspense; yet I hope to see
                        peace in your countenance, and to find that your heart is not totally devoid
                        of comfort and tranquillity.</tei-p>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Yet I fear that the same feelings now exist that made you so miserable a
                        year ago, even perhaps augmented by <tei-pb n="[3.97]" facs="pageImages/vol3/97.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> time. I would not disturb you at this
                        period when so many misfortunes weigh upon you; but a conversation that I
                        had with my uncle previous to his departure renders some explanation
                        necessary before we meet.</tei-p>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Explanation! you may possibly say; what can <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>
                        have to explain? If you really say this, my questions are answered, and I
                        have no more to do than to sign myself your affectionate cousin. But you are
                        distant from me, and it is possible that you may dread, and yet be pleased
                        with this explanation; and, in a probability of this being the case, I dare
                        not any longer postpone writing what, during your absence, I have often
                        wished to express to you, but have never had the courage to begin.</tei-p>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">You well know, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, that our union had been the
                        favourite plan of <tei-pb n="[3.98]" facs="pageImages/vol3/98.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> your
                        parents ever since our infancy. We were told this when young, and taught to
                        look forward to it as an event that would certainly take place. We were
                        affectionate playfellows during childhood, and, I believe, dear and valued
                        friends to one another as we grew older. But as brother and sister often
                        entertain a lively affection towards each other, without desiring a more
                        intimate union, may not such also be our case? Tell me, dearest
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>. Answer me, I conjure you, by our mutual
                        happiness, with simple truth—Do you not love another?</tei-p>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">You have travelled; you have spent several years of your life at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7017035" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Ingolstadt</tei-placeName>; and I confess to you, my
                        friend, that when I saw you last autumn so unhappy, flying to solitude, from
                        the society of every creature, I could not help supposing that you <tei-pb n="[3.99]" facs="pageImages/vol3/99.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> might regret our connection,
                        and believe yourself bound in honour to fulfill the wishes of your parents,
                        although they opposed themselves to your inclinations. But this is false
                        reasoning. I confess to you, my cousin, that I love you, and that in my airy
                        dreams of futurity you have been my constant friend and companion. But it is
                        your happiness I desire as well as my own, when I declare to you, that our
                        marriage would render me eternally miserable, unless it were the dictate of
                        your own free choice. Even now I weep to think, that, borne down as you are
                        by the cruellest misfortunes, you may stifle, by the word honour, all hope
                        of that love and happiness which would alone restore you to yourself. I, who
                        have so disinterested an affection for you, may increase your miseries
                        ten-fold by being an obstacle to your wishes. Ah, <tei-pb n="[3.100 - page breaks after 'Vic-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/100.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, be assured that your cousin and playmate has
                        too sincere a love for you not to be made miserable by this supposition. Be
                        happy, my friend; and if you obey me in this one request, remain satisfied
                        that nothing on earth will have the power to interrupt my tranquillity.</tei-p>


                     <tei-p data-origname="p">Do not let this letter disturb you; do not answer to-morrow, or the next
                        day, or even until you come, if it will give you pain. My uncle will send me
                        news of your health; and if I see but one smile on your lips when we meet,
                        occasioned by this or any other exertion of mine, I shall need no other
                        happiness.</tei-p>


                     <tei-closer data-origname="closer"><tei-signed data-origname="signed"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">ELIZABETH LAVENZA</tei-persName></tei-signed>. <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>, <tei-date data-origname="date">May 18th,
                        17--</tei-date>.</tei-closer>





                  </tei-body>


               </tei-floatingText>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">This letter revived in my memory what I had before forgotten, the threat <tei-pb n="[3.101]" facs="pageImages/vol3/101.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> of the fiend—<tei-said who="#creatureVictor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I will be with you on your wedding-night!"</tei-said> Such
                  was my sentence, and on that night would the dæmon employ every art to destroy me,
                  and tear me from the glimpse of happiness which promised partly to console my
                  sufferings. On that night he had determined to consummate his crimes by my death.
                  Well, be it so; a deadly struggle would then assuredly take place, in which if he
                  was victorious, I should be at peace, and his power over me be at an end. If he
                  were vanquished, I should be a free man. Alas! what freedom? such as the peasant
                  enjoys when his family have been massacred before his eyes, his cottage burnt, his
                  lands laid waste, and he is turned adrift, homeless, pennyless, and alone, but
                  free. Such would be my liberty, except that in my <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> I
                  possessed a treasure; alas! balanced <tei-pb n="[3.102]" facs="pageImages/vol3/102.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> by those horrors of remorse and guilt, which
                  would pursue me until death.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Sweet and beloved <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>! I read and re-read her letter,
                  and some softened feelings stole into my heart, and dared to whisper paradisaical
                  dreams of love and joy; but the apple was already eaten, and the angel's arm bared
                  to drive me from all hope. Yet I would die to make her happy. If the monster
                  executed his threat, death was inevitable; yet, again, I considered whether my
                  marriage would hasten my fate. My destruction might indeed arrive a few months
                  sooner; but if my torturer should suspect that I postponed it, influenced by his
                  menaces, he would surely find other, and perhaps more dreadful means of revenge.
                  He had vowed to be with me on my wedding-night, yet he did not consider that
                  threat as binding him to peace in <tei-pb n="[3.103]" facs="pageImages/vol3/103.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  the mean time; for, as if to shew me that he was not yet satiated with blood, he
                  had murdered <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> immediately after the enunciation of his
                  threats. I resolved, therefore, that if my immediate union with my cousin would
                  conduce either to her's or my father's happiness, my adversary's designs against
                  my life should not retard it a single hour.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">In this state of mind I wrote to <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. My letter was
                  calm and affectionate. <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I fear, my beloved girl,"</tei-said> I
                  said, <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"little happiness remains for us on earth; yet all that
                     I may one day enjoy is concentered in you. Chase away your idle fears; to you
                     alone do I consecrate my life, and my endeavours for contentment. I have one
                     secret, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, a dreadful one; when revealed to you,
                     it will chill your frame with horror, and then, far from being <tei-pb n="[3.104]" facs="pageImages/vol3/104.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> surprised at my misery, you will only
                     wonder that I survive what I have endured. I will confide this tale of misery
                     and terror to you the day after our marriage shall take place; for, my sweet
                     cousin, there must be perfect confidence between us. But until then, I conjure
                     you, do not mention or allude to it. This I most earnestly entreat, and I know
                     you will comply."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">In about a week after the arrival of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>'s letter, we
                  returned to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName>. My cousin
                  welcomed me with warm affection; yet tears were in her eyes, as she beheld my
                  emaciated frame and feverish cheeks. I saw a change in her also. She was thinner,
                  and had lost much of that heavenly vivacity that had before charmed me; but her
                  gentleness, and soft looks of compassion, made her a more fit companion for one
                  blasted and miserable as I was.</tei-p>


               <tei-pb n="[3.105]" facs="pageImages/vol3/105.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">The tranquillity which I now enjoyed did not endure. Memory brought madness with
                  it; and when I thought of what had passed, a real insanity possessed me; sometimes
                  I was furious, and burnt with rage; sometimes low and despondent. I neither spoke
                  or looked, but sat motionless, bewildered by the multitude of miseries that
                  overcame me.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> alone had the power to draw me from these fits; her
                  gentle voice would soothe me when transported by passion, and inspire me with
                  human feelings when sunk in torpor. She wept with me, and for me. When reason
                  returned, she would remonstrate, and endeavour to inspire me with resignation. Ah!
                  it is well for the unfortunate to be resigned, but for the guilty there is no
                  peace. The agonies of remorse poison the luxury there is <tei-pb n="[3.106]" facs="pageImages/vol3/106.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> otherwise sometimes found in indulging the
                  excess of grief.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Soon after my arrival my father spoke of my immediate marriage with my cousin. I
                  remained silent.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Have you, then, some other attachment?"</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"None on earth. I love <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>, and
                     look forward to our union with delight. Let the day therefore be fixed; and on
                     it I will consecrate myself, in life or death, to the happiness of my
                     cousin."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"My dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>, do not speak thus.
                     Heavy misfortunes have befallen us; but let us only cling closer to what
                     remains, and transfer our love for those whom we have lost to those who yet
                     live. Our circle will be small, but bound close by the ties of affection and
                     mutual misfortune. And when time shall have softened your despair, new <tei-pb n="[3.107]" facs="pageImages/vol3/107.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> and dear objects of care will
                     be born to replace those of whom we have been so cruelly deprived."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Such were the lessons of my father. But to me the remembrance of the threat
                  returned: nor can you wonder, that, omnipotent as the fiend had yet been in his
                  deeds of blood, I should almost regard him as invincible; and that when he had
                  pronounced the words, <tei-said who="#creatureVictor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I shall be with you on your
                     wedding-night,"</tei-said> I should regard the threatened fate as unavoidable. But
                  death was no evil to me, if the loss of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> were
                  balanced with it; and I therefore, with a contented and even cheerful countenance,
                  agreed with my father, that if my cousin would consent, the ceremony should take
                  place in ten days, and thus put, as I imagined, the seal to my fate.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Great God! if for one instant I <tei-pb n="[3.108]" facs="pageImages/vol3/108.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  had thought what might be the hellish intention of my fiendish adversary, I would
                  rather have banished myself for ever from my native country, and wandered a
                  friendless outcast over the earth, than have consented to this miserable marriage.
                  But, as if possessed of magic powers, the monster had blinded me to his real
                  intentions; and when I thought that I had prepared only my own death, I hastened
                  that of a far dearer victim.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">As the period fixed for our marriage drew nearer, whether from cowardice or a
                  prophetic feeling, I felt my heart sink within me. But I concealed my feelings by
                  an appearance of hilarity, that brought smiles and joy to the countenance of my
                  father, but hardly deceived the ever-watchful and nicer eye of
                     <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>. She looked forward to our union with placid
                  contentment, not <tei-pb n="[3.109]" facs="pageImages/vol3/109.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> unmingled with a
                  little fear, which past misfortunes had impressed, that what now appeared certain
                  and tangible happiness, might soon dissipate into an airy dream, and leave no
                  trace but deep and everlasting regret.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Preparations were made for the event; congratulatory visits were received; and all
                  wore a smiling appearance. I shut up, as well as I could, in my own heart the
                  anxiety that preyed there, and entered with seeming earnestness into the plans of
                  my father, although they might only serve as the decorations of my tragedy. A
                  house was purchased for us near <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7004446" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cologne</tei-placeName>, by which we should enjoy the pleasures of the country,
                  and yet be so near <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7003746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Geneva</tei-placeName> as to
                  see my father every day; who would still reside within the walls, for the benefit
                  of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Ernest</tei-persName>, that he might follow his studies at the
                  schools.</tei-p>


               <tei-pb n="[3.110]" facs="pageImages/vol3/110.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">In the mean time I took every precaution to defend my person, in case the fiend
                  should openly attack me. I carried pistols and a dagger constantly about me, and
                  was ever on the watch to prevent artifice; and by these means gained a greater
                  degree of tranquillity. Indeed, as the period approached, the threat appeared more
                  as a delusion, not to be regarded as worthy to disturb my peace, while the
                  happiness I hoped for in my marriage wore a greater appearance of certainty, as
                  the day fixed for its solemnization drew nearer, and I heard it continually spoken
                  of as an occurrence which no accident could possibly prevent.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> seemed happy; my tranquil demeanour contributed
                  greatly to calm her mind. But on the day that was to fulfill my wishes and my
                  destiny, she was melancholy, and <tei-pb n="[3.111]" facs="pageImages/vol3/111.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                  a presentiment of evil pervaded her; and perhaps also she thought of the dreadful
                  secret, which I had promised to reveal to her on the following day. My father was
                  in the mean time overjoyed, and, in the bustle of preparation, only observed in
                  the melancholy of his niece the diffidence of a bride.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">After the ceremony was performed, a large party assembled at my father's; but it
                  was agreed that <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> and I should pass the afternoon and
                  night at <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009171" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Evian</tei-placeName>, and return to
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7004446" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Cologne</tei-placeName> the next morning. As
                  the day was fair, and the wind favourable, we resolved to go by water.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Those were the last moments of my life during which I enjoyed the feeling of
                  happiness. We passed rapidly along: the sun was hot, but we were sheltered from
                  its rays by a kind of canopy, while we enjoyed the beauty of the scene, <tei-pb n="[3.112]" facs="pageImages/vol3/112.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> sometimes on one side of the lake,
                  where we saw <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1106285" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont Salêve</tei-placeName>, the
                  pleasant banks of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1032711" cert="medium" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="cert key type">Montalêgre</tei-placeName>, and at a distance, surmounting all, the beautiful
                     <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7617157" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont Blânc</tei-placeName>, and the assemblage
                  of snowy mountains that in vain endeavour to emulate her; sometimes coasting the
                  opposite banks, we saw the mighty <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="1109172" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Jura</tei-placeName> opposing its dark side to the ambition that would quit its
                  native country, and an almost insurmountable barrier to the invader who should
                  wish to enslave it.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">I took the hand of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>: <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You are
                     sorrowful, my love. Ah! if you knew what I have suffered, and what I may yet
                     endure, you would endeavour to let me taste the quiet, and freedom from
                     despair, that this one day at least permits me to enjoy."</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Be happy, my dear <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Victor</tei-persName>,"</tei-said>
                  replied <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName>; <tei-said who="#elizabeth" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"there is, I hope,
                        <tei-pb n="[3.113]" facs="pageImages/vol3/113.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> nothing to distress you;
                     and be assured that if a lively joy is not painted in my face, my heart is
                     contented. Something whispers to me not to depend too much on the prospect that
                     is opened before us; but I will not listen to such a sinister voice. Observe
                     how fast we move along, and how the clouds which sometimes obscure, and
                     sometimes rise above the dome of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7617157" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Mont
                        Blânc</tei-placeName>, render this scene of beauty still more interesting. Look
                     also at the innumerable fish that are swimming in the clear waters, where we
                     can distinguish every pebble that lies at the bottom. What a divine day! how
                     happy and serene all nature appears!"</tei-said></tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">Thus <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Elizabeth</tei-persName> endeavoured to divert her thoughts and mine
                  from all reflection upon melancholy subjects. But her temper was fluctuating; joy
                  for a few instants shone in her eyes, but it <tei-pb n="[3.114]" facs="pageImages/vol3/114.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> continually gave place to distraction and
                  reverie.</tei-p>


               <tei-p data-origname="p">The sun sunk lower in the heavens; we passed the <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7647999" cert="medium" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="cert key type">river Drance</tei-placeName>, and observed its path
                  through the chasms of the higher, and the glens of the lower hills. The <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7007746" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Alps</tei-placeName> here come closer to the lake, and we
                  approached the amphitheatre of mountains which forms its eastern boundary. The
                  spire of <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7009171" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Evian</tei-placeName> shone under the
                  woods that surrounded it, and the range of mountain above mountain by which it was
