                     hours to live.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">His sentence was pronounced, and I could only grieve, and be patient. I sat by
                     his bed watching him; his eyes were closed, and I thought he slept; but
                     presently he called to me in a feeble voice, and, bidding me come near,
                        said—<tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Alas! the strength I relied on is gone; I feel
                        that I shall soon die, and he, my enemy and persecutor, may still be in
                        being. Think <tei-pb n="[3.175]" facs="pageImages/vol3/175.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> not,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Walton</tei-persName>, that in the last moments of my existence I
                        feel that burning hatred, and ardent desire of revenge I once expressed; but
                        I feel myself justified in desiring the death of my adversary. During these
                        last days I have been occupied in examining my past conduct; nor do I find
                        it blameable. In a fit of enthusiastic madness I created a rational
                        creature, and was bound towards him, to assure, as far as was in my power,
                        his happiness and well-being. This was my duty; but there was another still
                        paramount to that. My duties towards my fellow-creatures had greater claims
                        to my attention, because they included a greater proportion of happiness or
                        misery. Urged by this view, I refused, and I did right in refusing, to
                        create a companion for the first creature. He showed unparalleled malignity
                        and selfishness, in <tei-pb n="[3.176]" facs="pageImages/vol3/176.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> evil:
                        he destroyed my friends; he devoted to destruction beings who possessed
                        exquisite sensations, happiness, and wisdom; nor do I know where this thirst
                        for vengeance may end. Miserable himself, that he may render no other
                        wretched, he ought to die. The task of his destruction was mine, but I have
                        failed. When actuated by selfish and vicious motives, I asked you to
                        undertake my unfinished work; and I renew this request now, when I am only
                        induced by reason and virtue."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Yet I cannot ask you to renounce your country and friends,
                        to fulfill this task; and now, that you are returning to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>, you will have little chance
                        of meeting with him. But the consideration of these points, and the well
                        balancing of what you may esteem your duties, I leave to you; my <tei-pb n="[3.177 - page breaks after 'judg-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/177.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        judgment and ideas are already disturbed by the near approach of death. I
                        dare not ask you to do what I think right, for I may still be misled by
                        passion. That he should live to be an instrument of mischief disturbs me; in
                        other respects, this hour, when I momentarily expect my release, is the only
                        happy one which I have enjoyed for several years. The forms of the beloved
                        dead flit before me, and I hasten to their arms. Farewell,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Walton</tei-persName>! Seek happiness in tranquillity, and avoid
                        ambition, even if it be only the apparently innocent one of distinguishing
                        yourself in science and discoveries. Yet why do I say this? I have myself
                        been blasted in these hopes, yet another may succeed."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">His voice became fainter as he spoke; and at length, exhausted by <tei-pb n="[3.178]" facs="pageImages/vol3/178.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> his effort, he sunk into
                     silence. About half an hour afterwards he attempted again to speak, but was
                     unable; he pressed my hand feebly, and his eyes closed for ever, while the
                     irradiation of a gentle smile passed away from his
                        lips.<tei-persName data-origname="persName">Margaret</tei-persName>, what comment can I make on the untimely
                     extinction of this glorious spirit? What can I say that will enable you to
                     understand the depth of my sorrow? All that I should express would be
                     inadequate and feeble. My tears flow; my mind is overshadowed by a cloud of
                     disappointment. But I journey towards <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7002445" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">England</tei-placeName>, and I may there find consolation.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I am interrupted. What do these sounds portend? It is midnight; the breeze
                     blows fairly, and the watch on deck scarcely stir. Again; there is a sound as
                     of a human voice, but <tei-pb n="[3.179]" facs="pageImages/vol3/179.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> hoarser;
                     it comes from the cabin where the remains of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>
                     still lie. I must arise and examine. Good night, my sister.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">Great God! what a scene has just taken place! I am yet dizzy with the
                     remembrance of it. I hardly know whether I shall have the power to detail it;
                     yet the tale which I have recorded would be incomplete without this final and
                     wonderful catastrophe.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I entered the cabin, where lay the remains of my ill-fated and admirable
                     friend. Over him hung a form which I cannot find words to describe; gigantic in
                     stature, yet uncouth and distorted in its proportions. As he hung over the
                     coffin, his face was concealed by long locks of ragged hair; but one vast hand
                     was extended, in colour and apparent texture like that of a mummy. When he
                     heard the sound of my <tei-pb n="[3.180 - page breaks after 'ap-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/180.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> approach, he ceased to utter exclamations
                     of grief and horror, and sprung towards the window. Never did I behold a vision
                     so horrible as his face, of such loathsome, yet appalling hideousness. I shut
                     my eyes involuntarily, and endeavoured to recollect what were my duties with
                     regard to this destroyer. I called on him to stay.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He paused, looking on me with wonder; and, again turning towards the lifeless
                     form of his creator, he seemed to forget my presence, and every feature and
                     gesture seemed instigated by the wildest rage of some uncontrollable
                     passion.</tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"That is also my victim!"</tei-said> he exclaimed; <tei-said who="#victor" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"in his murder my crimes are consummated; the miserable series
                        of my being is wound to its close! Oh, <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>!
                        generous and self-devoted being! what does it avail that <tei-pb n="[3.181]" facs="pageImages/vol3/181.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> I now ask thee to pardon me? I, who
                        irretrievably destroyed thee by destroying all thou lovest. Alas! he is
                        cold, he may not answer me."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">His voice seemed suffocated; and my first impulses, which had suggested to me
                     the duty of obeying the dying request of my friend, in destroying his enemy,
                     were now suspended by a mixture of curiosity and compassion. I approached this
                     tremendous being; I dared not again raise my looks upon his face, there was
                     something so scaring and unearthly in his ugliness. I attempted to speak, but
                     the words died away on my lips. The monster continued to utter wild and
                     incoherent self-reproaches. At length I gathered resolution to address him, in
                     a pause of the tempest of his passion: <tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Your
                        repentance,"</tei-said> I said, <tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"is now superfluous. If you
                        had listened to the voice of <tei-pb n="[3.182 - page breaks after 'con-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/182.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> conscience, and heeded the stings of
                        remorse, before you had urged your diabolical vengeance to this extremity,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName> would yet have lived."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"And do you dream?"</tei-said> said the dæmon; <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"do you think that I was then dead to agony and
                        remorse?—He"</tei-said> he continued, pointing to the corpse, <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"he suffered not more in the consummation of the deed;—oh!
                        not the ten-thousandth portion of the anguish that was mine during the
                        lingering detail of its execution. A frightful selfishness hurried me on,
                        while my heart was poisoned with remorse. Think ye that the groans of
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName> were music to my ears? My heart was
                        fashioned to be susceptible of love and sympathy; and, when wrenched by
                        misery to vice and hatred, it did not endure the violence of the change
                        without torture such as you cannot even imagine."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-pb n="[3.183]" facs="pageImages/vol3/183.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"After the murder of <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Clerval</tei-persName>, I
                        returned to <tei-placeName type="tgn" key="7011731" data-origname="placeName" data-origatts="key type">Switzerland</tei-placeName>
                        heartbroken and overcome. I pitied <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>; my
                        pity amounted to horror: I abhorred myself. But when I discovered that he,
                        the author at once of my existence and of its unspeakable torments, dared to
                        hope for happiness; that while he accumulated wretchedness and despair upon
                        me he sought his own enjoyment in feelings and passions from the indulgence
                        of which I was for ever barred, then impotent envy and bitter indignation
                        filled me with an insatiable thirst for vengeance. I recollected my threat,
                        and resolved that it should be accomplished. I knew that I was preparing for
                        myself a deadly torture; but I was the slave, not the master of an impulse,
                        which I detested, yet could not disobey. Yet when she died!—nay, then I was
                        not miserable. I had cast <tei-pb n="[3.184]" facs="pageImages/vol3/184.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>
                        off all feeling, subdued all anguish to riot in the excess of my despair.
                        Evil thenceforth became my good. Urged thus far, I had no choice but to
                        adapt my nature to an element which I had willingly chosen. The completion
                        of my demoniacal design became an insatiable passion. And now it is ended;
                        there is my last victim!"</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">I was at first touched by the expressions of his misery; yet, when I called to
                     mind what <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName> had said of his powers of eloquence
                     and persuasion, and when I again cast my eyes on the lifeless form of my
                     friend, indignation was re-kindled within me. <tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Wretch!"</tei-said> I said, <tei-said who="#walton" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"it is well that you come here
                        to whine over the desolation that you have made. You throw a torch into a
                        pile of buildings; and when they are consumed you sit among the ruins, and
                        lament the fall. <tei-pb n="[3.185 - page breaks after 'Hypo-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/185.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> Hypocritical fiend! if he whom you mourn
                        still lived, still would he be the object, again would he become the prey of
                        your accursed vengeance. It is not pity that you feel; you lament only
                        because the victim of your malignity is withdrawn from your
                     power."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Oh, it is not thus—not thus,"</tei-said> interrupted the
                     being; <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"yet such must be the impression conveyed to you
                        by what appears to be the purport of my actions. Yet I seek not a
                        fellow-feeling in my misery. No sympathy may I ever find. When I first
                        sought it, it was the love of virtue, the feelings of happiness and
                        affection with which my whole being overflowed, that I wished to be
                        participated. But now, that virtue has become to me a shadow, and that
                        happiness and affection are turned into bitter and loathing despair, in what
                        should I seek for <tei-pb n="[3.186 - page breaks after 'sym-']" facs="pageImages/vol3/186.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> sympathy? I am content to suffer alone,
                        while my sufferings shall endure: when I die, I am well satisfied that
                        abhorrence and opprobrium should load my memory. Once my fancy was soothed
                        with dreams of virtue, of fame, and of enjoyment. Once I falsely hoped to
                        meet with beings, who, pardoning my outward form, would love me for the
                        excellent qualities which I was capable of bringing forth. I was nourished
                        with high thoughts of honour and devotion. But now vice has degraded me
                        beneath the meanest animal. No crime, no mischief, no malignity, no misery,
                        can be found comparable to mine. When I call over the frightful catalogue of
                        my deeds, I cannot believe that I am he whose thoughts were once filled with
                        sublime and transcendent visions of the beauty and the majesty of goodness.
                        But it is even so; <tei-pb n="[3.187]" facs="pageImages/vol3/187.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> the
                        fallen angel becomes a malignant devil. Yet even that enemy of God and man
                        had friends and associates in his desolation; I am quite alone."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"You, who call <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName> your
                        friend, seem to have a knowledge of my crimes and his misfortunes. But, in
                        the detail which he gave you of them, he could not sum up the hours and
                        months of misery which I endured, wasting in impotent passions. For whilst I
                        destroyed his hopes, I did not satisfy my own desires. They were for ever
                        ardent and craving; still I desired love and fellowship, and I was still
                        spurned. Was there no injustice in this? Am I to be thought the only
                        criminal, when all human kind sinned against me? Why do you not hate
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Felix</tei-persName>, who drove his friend from his door with
                        contumely? Why do you not execrate the rustic who sought to <tei-pb n="[3.188]" facs="pageImages/vol3/188.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> destroy the saviour of his child? Nay,
                        these are virtuous and immaculate beings! I, the miserable and the
                        abandoned, am an abortion, to be spurned at, and kicked, and trampled on.
                        Even now my blood boils at the recollection of this injustice."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"But it is true that I am a wretch. I have murdered the
                        lovely and the helpless; I have strangled the innocent as they slept, and
                        grasped to death his throat who never injured me or any other living thing.
                        I have devoted my creator, the select specimen of all that is worthy of love
                        and admiration among men, to misery; I have pursued him even to that
                        irremediable ruin. There he lies, white and cold in death. You hate me; but
                        your abhorrence cannot equal that with which I regard myself. I look on the
                        hands which executed the deed; I think on the <tei-pb n="[3.189]" facs="pageImages/vol3/189.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> heart in which the imagination of it was
                        conceived, and long for the moment when they will meet my eyes, when it will
                        haunt my thoughts, no more."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Fear not that I shall be the instrument of future
                        mischief. My work is nearly complete. Neither your's nor any man's death is
                        needed to consummate the series of my being, and accomplish that which must
                        be done; but it requires my own. Do not think that I shall be slow to
                        perform this sacrifice. I shall quit your vessel on the ice-raft which
                        brought me hither, and I shall seek the most northern extremity of the
                        globe; I shall collect my funeral pile, and consume to ashes this miserable
                        frame, that its remains may afford no light to any curious and unhallowed
                        wretch, who would create such another as I have been. I shall <tei-pb n="[3.190]" facs="pageImages/vol3/190.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> die. I shall no longer feel
                        the agonies which now consume me, or be the prey of feelings unsatisfied,
                        yet unquenched. He is dead who called me into being; and when I shall be no
                        more, the very remembrance of us both will speedily vanish. I shall no
                        longer see the sun or stars, or feel the winds play on my cheeks. Light,
                        feeling, and sense, will pass away; and in this condition must I find my
                        happiness. Some years ago, when the first images which this world affords
                        first opened upon me, when I felt the cheering warmth of summer, and heard
                        the rustling of the leaves and the chirping of the birds, and these were all
                        to me, I should have wept to die; now it is my only consolation. Polluted by
                        crimes, and torn by the bitterest remorse, where can I find rest but in
                        death?"</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-pb n="[3.191]" facs="pageImages/vol3/191.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"Farewell! I leave you, and in you the last of human kind
                        whom these eyes will ever behold. Farewell,
                           <tei-persName data-origname="persName">Frankenstein</tei-persName>! If thou wert yet alive, and yet
                        cherished a desire of revenge against me, it would be better satiated in my
                        life than in my destruction. But it was not so; thou didst seek my
                        extinction, that I might not cause greater wretchedness; and if yet, in some
                        mode unknown to me, thou hast not yet ceased to think and feel, thou
                        desirest not my life for my own misery. Blasted as thou wert, my agony was
                        still superior to thine; for the bitter sting of remorse may not cease to
                        rankle in my wounds until death shall close them for ever."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p"><tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"But soon,"</tei-said> he cried, with sad and solemn
                     enthusiasm, <tei-said who="#creature" data-origname="said" data-origatts="who">"I shall die, and what I now feel be no
                        longer felt. Soon these burning miseries will be extinct. I shall ascend my
                        funeral <tei-pb n="[3.192]" facs="pageImages/vol3/192.jpg" data-origname="pb" data-origatts="facs n" data-empty=""/> pile triumphantly,
                        and exult in the agony of the torturing flames. The light of that
                        conflagration will fade away; my ashes will be swept into the sea by the
                        winds. My spirit will sleep in peace; or if it thinks, it will not surely
                        think thus. Farewell."</tei-said></tei-p>


                  <tei-p data-origname="p">He sprung from the cabin-window, as he said this, upon the ice-raft which lay
                     close to the vessel. He was soon borne away by the waves, and lost in darkness
                     and distance. </tei-p>


               </tei-div>
